content:
r 2, 2014
												Train Simulator 2015 still falls short behind the 2014 release, it offers no actual improvement related to gameplay and quick drive functionality then the previous generations, there is no option to manually set up a route and stops for your self in the Quick Drive screen which is a massive let down. Fog is still bland, you can't set fog distance at all neither any other options for rain or even worse conditions like icing on track or so. The developers attitude still remains the same, utterly disgraceful and they still think this is a family game, because it is not. This game have to get past the "game for kids" attitude by the developers, and they have to keep focusing on making the simulation aspect a lot better, e.g.: they could implement manual startup functions for trains, better sanding, more control functions like the ETCS, radio communication, train station announcements, and there could be a lot more that is actually not in this particual game, and certainly someone who is not a hardcore train fan will find this game extremely boring.The game have so much potential with Quick Drive but players requests are still not being met with equal amount of support to implement better usability for that particularly interesting game mode. I have to note that the lack of custom, fictional maps, there is literally non, other then what Kuju did back in a while but that is freely available on the Steam Workshop. Ah yes, the workshop is integrated horribly badly, you won't ever find what you want to find to be honest it is just a failed method of implementation for this game.Some DLCs for this game is amazing, but the prices do seem a bit overly extortionate especially on tracks and trains that are way out of date and are only updated so that they can roll on the track, e.g.: Metronom, Düsseldorf-Köln, Münich-Augsburg, Ruhr-Sieg line, these are really in bad condition.But yeah, try convince the developers that they are at the wrong when when we are actually experiencing all the bad, they could easily upgrade the Ruhr-Sieg line and make it all cool and dandy like they did with the last two german maps.I must say I'm highly dissatisfied with the company's policies, they are too intrusive, obtrusive and they will ban all their political foes whom speak out against them in what ever manner. Still is today.[2015.02.20] I can only rate this game 3 out of 10. [Only buy when 75% or more discounted!]Edit 2015.07.08: So, according to the news DTG is going to release TS2016 as a brand new game separate from the current 2015 platform, and by that they won't be continuing the current platform upgrade for this game and we don't receive the update. This is actually one hell of a bad idea, but on their part it is very genius, because... If they create a new game, and leave this one here, they can basically delete and eliminate content that doesn't function properly, they can apply fixes to maps and other content that they will re-brand and fix, but next to that they gonna be able to start clean with the rating system on this game by having a clean slate of reviews from users.Well, all I can say right now to DTG is good luck, if they managed to implement in a lot of game experience enhacing effects like more dynamic traffic, alterable path and priority system, then I guess the game could become a massive hit, well I as a game designer I do think that could be great addition to the game and could improve the relation between the company and the userbase.But, if this is gonna be another let down by the company, then their effort to try to start with a clean slate will completely backfire and will get a lot of problems in the end, let's hope for the best, since there are possibilities for it.Okay, so 2016 update.Apparently, it become a pay-ware upgrade! What a shame, how far did we have to sunk, bugged DLCs and still such a broken and utterly unoptimized game, I just can't beleive what the developers are doing to this franchise. God forbid them from ruining Flight Simulator X, I hope Microsoft will revoke their license if that happens.2017.Nothing has changed, and the game is being abandoned, this is disgraceful. The developers are horrible, they are very disrespectful of people. They are failing, I will call them as the failing DTG, horribly failing.

content:
ber 19, 2015
												Train Simulator. It's a promising title isn't it if you love trains and want to be a train driver but otherwise can't, but behind this title, there is a game that although great for it's time, looks so cartoony and sterile with no sense of real-world immersion, and it is more of a game than a simulator, but what realistically what much else can you do with a train simualtor? This isn't FSX, you apply throttle and brake, but there's no real challenge to the game. Train driving is a very responsible job with roles more than just driving a train, but you don't get more than that in this simulator. Some random train faults or signal failures or something would be nice. Or even follow World of Subways with a character to walk about.Passenger AI in this game is a disaster. They have the IQ of a teaspoon when they walk off the platform onto the tracks whilst somehow defying the laws of gravity in the process, and showing no care that a speeding train (or slowing one) is heading for them. Though let's face it, you wouldn't care if the train was just gonna go through you and not leave you with even a scratch. I mean it would be grim to include it, and this isn't Grand Theft Auto, so we can let the lack of an effect slide. It wouldn't be good advertising to show the windscreen wipers smearing blood on the front train window would it?The trains themselves are for the most part nice, and the newer more interactive ones with realistic features such as lights on the front not affecting the lights on the back (you could drive with headlights on at both ends if you so wish, unless I am very wrong). But the sounds are also a disaster, I mean gaining access to depots is very difficult, and if we spent long enough waiting for access, DTG would lose customers cause of the demand for new DLC. Let's just say either waiting ages or forever for a train, or one with atrocious sounds. Whichever suits you best.Routes are the best things in this game without a doubt, because despite the complex tools that most people aren't even bothered to make an attempt to get use to or understand, the outcome is very nice if done properly. In terms of detail and accuracy, routes are the strong point, because the quality assurance is vital in order to make profit. Some routes dominate others, but nowadays they're just getting too small or have too little trains. Germans have it worse, I mean why build something like Munich Augsburg at about 60km when you can build up to about 200km of railway? Time and money of course, but if there is any investors pumping money into DTG to do stuff like this, then by golly they are not paying them enough. There is a route builder and scenario creator in this game, and this is probably the only time you will get something truly different. Unfortunately, most people decide "this is too complex" after spending five minutes trying to figure out how you make a train station or even put a train on the track. The tools are complex, but when you get use to them and become aware of them, then it's a nice little thing to do. Whoever thinks it needs to be simplified, try chatting to Network Rail telling them how hard you find it setting out cetenary wires which are created automatically in game without the need to get smelted iron for the overhead wires, and all the engineering plans and precision. Thought not, let's proceed.Price of DLC is, like most people think, overpriced. Now everyone blames DTG for this, but I think it's Steam who set the price, and I do think this is unfair to pin the blame on DTG. I mean if a tube of Pringles is cheaper in Asda (or Walmart if you're an American reader) than it is in Tesco, clearly the crisp makers themselves aren't setting the prices, cause the one's selling need some cash as well. Unfortunately, unless you're well off and willing to spend a lot of money (which I have, but I'm quite the tight-wad) then you'll have to wait for Steam sales, cause otherwise you might need to have a word with your bank manager for spending over £2000 on Train Simulator DLC. So overall, it's an alright game, but I wouldn't recommend it. Maybe I would've recommended it when it first came out, or even a few years after, but we're nearly in 2016, and with the UE4 version coming very soon, all the energy should really be put into that, kind of taking into account some of my points such as a playable character, less cartoony and more organic (something like dirt and grime and that, I mean this is UE4), more advanced trains with realistic interactivity, longer routes, and maybe more to do than just drive trains. I mean that should be the primary thing, but if every journey is the same, which for a real train driver it isn't cause anything can happen, then you're gonna get bored REAL FAST if you, like me, have no life and have spent around 1000 hours on the game in total already. Final score... 5.5/10 (good, but really needs improvement).

												A dated game with overpriced rubbish DLC and awful devs who only care about money and nothing else.The whole 'omg £3000 for DLC that's stupid lol' misunderstands the simulation genre however. You don't have to buy all the DLC you buy what you want.Microsoft Flight Simulator X hasd individual planes that can cost £100 or more and has thousands upon thousands of addons for example.The difference is FSX addons are all third party, and many are very good quality and priced as such. The trainsim DLC is just bad and expensive, very little work goes into them, mainly the locos.Compare a train made by JustTrains or Armstrong Powerhouse to something the devs have made and you'll see the difference.Having said that, the devs do a good job of the routes which look good but are all too short. They also went with the 'we can't be bothered making scenarios, we'll leave the community to do it!' so you'll get a pitiful amount of missions per route.Most annoying thing is the quick drive, you can't even do multiple stops and there's barely any AI. In my opinion quick drive could have saved this game and made it great but the devs, as incompetent as ever did a terrible job of it.They've been hinting at a new engine/game on the latest  unreal engine, which will probably make all DLC incompatabile, but I'm sure it will be an improvement as the current game is very dated.Unfortunately this is really the only modern train simulator. There is Trainz but that's not on the same level as this game. Maybe if another company made a train simulator and provided competition then this game would improve.

content:
er 9, 2013
												Most probably the most immersive Train Simulator/Game that is "current" and if you love trains, chances are you'd get intoxicated in it like how I used to be.  However:The Developers are perfectly capable of developing stunning and immersive add-ons with the right trains like The Woodhead Line add-on but:- They have a habit of not fixing bugs and issues with their DLCs.  When they fix them, it is often a very poor fix.e.g. 1. The Class 455 comes with unique "shadow-casting headlights" which is a massive fps killer.  Not fixed.e.g. 2. The Class 166 "fix" is a half-hearted one.  It used to take off like a rocket so they quadrupled the power lag to "solve" it.e.g. 3  The Class 450, which has been "fixed" twice but braking is still not sorted.- Obnoxiously priced DLC trains containing just one paint scheme.  They then sell a second paint scheme of the same train at full price.- Duplicate DLCs of the "same" train, adding massive complexity for 3rd-party scenario developers as these duplicates are not compatible with each other.- A good number of default scenarios are rushed, devoid of AI traffic and have niggling bugs.e.g. AI trains collide with each other due to bad routing, Scenario-specific speed restrictions not marked etc.- The TS2014 community can be vile at times, with a proliferation of negative comments aimed at the developer.I've been playing this since June 2011 in the Railworks 2 days when the developers were slightly more humble, and the cost of DLCs less prohibitive.  I still love trains and play this for enjoyment and to get the most out of my sunk costs.However, I recommend new users to stay well away from this sim/game due to its massive cost, bugs and poor developer support.  Due to my previous intoxication with this game, I probably handed over far too much cash and it took an unrelated truck simulator for me to realise how mediocre TS2014 and its support really is.

content:
er 14, 2015
Neutral RatingI'm really on the Fence to give this Game a Positive Thumbs Up, as there are some great qualities to it, but at the same time it also has a lot of Negatives to it... and some are substantial. However, I'd never give it a Negative Review, because I have enjoyed it, and still do on occassion despite my issues I experience.Train Simulator 20xx is without a doubt, the most successful Train Sim out there currently, which is mainly due to the large amount of Content available which gives Players a wide variety to build up their own Collection. For a old Game Engine, it can look really good, most Models are done well, and a lot of the new Content has stunning visuals. The sounds are 'meh' for a lot of the Content, but they have improved slightly on occassion.It is definitely not a Game for everyone, and mostly appeals to Train Fanatics, or Sim Fanatics [like myself]. The hours can be endless depending on said person.As the Steam Store has a lot of DLC created by 3rd Party Developers, I am excluding them completely out of this Review. The DLC created by DoveTail Games can have a YoYo effect when it comes to Quality on their DLC. For an example:- Loco 'A' released in November will have Great Modelling, nice and Crisp Textures, and a wide variety of Features.- Loco 'B' released in December will have Blocky Modelling, Blurry Textures, and a lack of Features.I'm sure this is due to a different Team working on different Content, but there should be Standards to live up to, especially when they are sold at the same Price.Although it is called a "Simulator", it leans more towards a Game. The Features it offers are very Basic, and most of the Switches and Monitors are just there for show [there are some exceptions though]. So if you are looking for a indepth, and highly Realistic experience, then keep looking, or alternatively learn to play without the HUD, and ask about External 3rd Party Content which produce Realistic Loco's [though the Variety is low].Despite how enjoyable it can be, the Game has many issues. I'm only going to name a few, because I'm not into "Bashing" a Game I enjoy [that's what Forums are for]. Such as Features not working Correctly [or at all], Scenario's which cannot be completed due to AI crashing, Dump File errors, and Signals not Functioning correctly.I would say if you want to invest in this Game, then it is essential to do Research before any purchases, and do a lot of Reading on the Forums, and never be afraid to ask any Questions there, even ones you might think are silly.Genre- SimulatorGame Elements- Commuter Train Operator- Freight Train Operator- Shunter Train Operator- Train SpotterAverage Playthrough- UnlimitedLiked- Supports TrackIR- Wide Variety of Content- Good Visuals for an Old Engine- Good Models and Textures- Some interesting Features- Helpful CommunityDisliked- Broken Content- Lack of Bug Fixing- Moderate Sounds- Lack of Advanced Features- Quality YoYo's too much

number of helpful: 57 of 67 people (85%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
4, 2015
												Train Simulator 2016. Beat The Extreme. It's not extreme. At all.The game play is driving a train from A to B, as the title suggests. There are lots of different trains and routes but the thing you do is to drive from A to B.The base game.Pretty cheap for what it offers. The 3 routes and trains are all pretty good. While the UK route is a re-hash of a previous route, made in 2014, it is a decent package.However, in order to get a full experience of the game, you will need to buy some of the mountains of Train Simulator DLC.That in itself is a bore.The next thing you find is that the base game and a few of the collections are actually value for money, the rest is daylight robbery. For the British stuff (which I'm focusing on, I'm not that clued-up on the other countries), all the sounds are terrible except the Class 395. If you've never heard a train before, the sounds are great but otherwise you should go to Armstrong Powerhouse and buy the Sound Packs. Well worth the fiver. There are also many annoing bugs. There are the trivial ones which involve cars going through trains at some level crossings and some bridges blocking the track which you just drive through but there are the ones which are annoying.The game is very unstable on many very good systems meaning crashes happen quite frequently. Sometimes trains will derail even when you are well within the speed limit or just stopped; the game will come up with the error "Game over due to consist tilt" and you will be chucked back to the menu. Once you actually get into this simulator, you will realise that Dovetail Games treat the players not like customers but like walking wallets which they can dip their hands into whenever they have not made enough profit.You will also notice once you get into the franchise a bit more that everything is re-used. A lot of the British rolling stock have the default 455 sounds, which are poor anyway. The re-using of appauling sounds is normal, and something you will have to get used to, I'm afraid. Then there's the routes. They are usually decent, if a bit short, but tend to come with trains that are already in the game. The Midland Main Line is an example of this because it comes with the 66 and 319, both already in the game. Trains that could have been included that are not in the game are the 222 and 387. This is repeated with the Munich to Rosenhiem (101 and 423) and various other add-ons. While I can see this happening if only 2 trains run on the routes, many of them have multiple trains on them, which instead of filling some very large gaps in the game, DTG recycle. And recycle. And recycle. This means various people have to fill the gap.At some point, this game is going to crash because people are going to get fed-up with what DTG are doing. It has been getting worse recently and there are no signs that this is going to improve any time soon. Before you used to get a free upgrade to the next Train Simulator (even though it is just a patch with a new title) but TS2016 was sold as an entirely new game because it had "so many new features" that it warrants everyone paying for a game they already have! Well, it didn't. It had a small extra funciton that helped (like a patch) and a mode that is completly redundant as it's unofficially been in the game for a long time now. So it did not. You will get used to this constant overhyping and mis-selling of content if you get into this game. So don't.The developers keep saying "We are aware of our standard and are trying to improve it" and "we do care [about what you want]". To pick up on the first point, we are yet to see any evidence of this. And to pick up on that last point, the things that we have been asking for for a long time such as a Eurostar route and better default sounds have not happened. Even when they do, it is usually not 100% of what was requested. For example, the Midland Main Line route for train sim only goes from St Pancras to Bedford although originally Elephant and Castle to Bedford was requested. And to pick up on the first point: nice try but nothing has happened yet. Additionally, once a route is finished, there is no chance it will be updated. Gravesend, Finsbury Park, Peterborough, London Bridge and many other stations are in old models which, as a community, we know will never be fixed by DTG. Instead we wait for people to do this stuff for free while DTG sit back and rake the cash in. A combination of "can't be bothered" and "we need to make loads of money" attitudes mean this game is on a downward curve. If nothing is done, it will crash. Hard.It must be said that new members of the game get good value for money when joining. But this changes the moment you dip your toe into the game. DTG will exploit your desire to have your favorite train or route in the game and so you will pay the full price for it (£12 per train, £25 per route with some exceptions). This in nearly all cases is not value for money at all. It must be said that if you know a train very well, you will realise that DTG make good trains rarely. As far as I know, only 1 actually good train exists, that being the class 395, which comes with the very linear London to Faversham High Speed route.So if you want a very realistic train simulator that gets everything right, this is the only one around. Although it doesn't get nearly everything right, as outlined above. But be prepared to spend thousands of pounds. And I mean thousands. There's more than £3,000 worth of DLC for you to waste your money on.Form your own opinion.Felix.

content:
er 30, 2014
												TS2015 can be broken down in to the Positive and Negative aspects:Positive:- During sales, it is cheap to absurdly low levels, even in special editions. This makes it easy for anyone to pick up and play it.- (Almost) full controller support.- Wide abundance of downloadable content from nearly all parts of the world.- Some DLC content is also free (Including re-released routes on the Workshop).- The game has a very active community, with many groups to join.- Highly acclaimed as a very detailed, expansive, and fun train simulation game.- Many third-party addons to expand the collection further.- Amazingly concentrated and detailed physics, geography, and train movement.--------------------Negative:- The game is a DLC-pumping machine. This manages to pump out more useless DLC than PAYDAY 2 does. AND THAT GAME HAS LESS DLC.- A lot of the time, the game breaks laws of motion, physics, and gravity.Examples:


YouTube™ Video: (TS2015) Yeah, here it comes again 

			Views: 670		

			Every time, every single time. You can't escape it. ---- © 2014 Gavin McLennan Make sure to Subscribe if you can, or check out these links below: deviantART: http://railbrony.deviantart.com Facebook...		




YouTube™ Video: Physics.mp4 

			Views: 345		

			11/10 best train physics ---- deviantART: http://railbrony.deviantart.com Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/raildriverpony Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/GavinMPhotography Subscribe!		




YouTube™ Video: (TS2013) Jet Train for RW 

			Views: 553		

			*ignore the lag, I was running TeamSpeak* ---- deviantART: http://railbrony.deviantart.com Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/Raildriver2/ Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/GavinMPhotography...		

http://youtu.be/QJEjzqxgW3khttp://youtu.be/412wwyO-nRAhttp://youtu.be/IUYxe-pnqyUhttp://youtu.be/HgwfO5kWIjo- Unless you have /a good amount of cash/ on you, a lot of the routes and locomotives you won't be able to acquire until a sale. $40 is the standard price for most routes, and $20-30 being the standard for locomotives.- A lot of the sounds on locomotives sound cheap and stocky, and most of the time are inaccurate to GREAT detail.- Only until TS2015 did models such as people and vehicles improve to nearly tolerable and "realistic" levels. Before that they were about as detailed as any passengers you'd see in Trainz 2004 or in any low-poly interior (which there is a lot).- A lot of the tools are confusing to figure out at first, and a lot of tutorials offer little help, as the game changes around every September. Sounds a lot like a good amount of games today. Isn't that right Ubisoft, EA, and whatever COD is?- With each game, the system requirements change. I get this is common in technology, but a lot of us don't change like everyone else does.- I've been interested in this game since Rail Simulator, and as of this release, I'm starting to want to revert back to Trainz. Or even venture into Run-8. (Protip: Don't buy Run-8.)In short, if you want to get the game, get it. I'd prefer you get it on a /deeply/ cheap sale, however. I'll probably get comments of autists spewing their views, and you're more than welcome to.Like my videos and screenshots I post of this game, I'm not responding to it unless it deserves being responded to.Cheers, - Fancypants

ber 24, 2016
												TS2017 is a mixed bag of beansWhile chugging along in a train can be relaxing and surprisingly fun, this game is also a source of aggravation. You lose points. One minute too late at the station? Kiss ANY points you might have accrued goodbye.Also DLCs are extremely expensive.Would I recommend this game? If it's for sale under $10, yes.Full price? No.

Nobody wants to play a game that drops to 4fps every 30 seconds loading a station or new stretch of track.900+ achievements and thousands of dollars worth of DLC? Usually, you are given warning that the speed is changing ahead on the track.  But on some missions, when you are pulling into the final stop, the speed limit abruptly drops, and screws you out of points because now you are speeding, and slamming on the brakes makes you lose even more points.  Goodbye (insert x amount of time the run took you) and goodbye perfect 1000 point score.  FORGET THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 50 of 59 people (85%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ber 19, 2015
												This review is written treating the game as a simulator, which is how it's titled after all. Firstly every year the name of the game changes from 2012,2013,2016 ect, that game is actually the same with a few very minor changes. The game hasn't really changed since 2012. Different DLC are included in different years but you need to purchase the game every year to receive them. So it updates for free to the latest year but you don't receive any DLC that comes with that year unless you pay again. The biggest gripe with this game is DLC content is priced at an extremely high and unreasonable level. You could easily pay £3000 to buy all DLC. Dovetail say that you only buy what you like, but routes cost around £24 and trains £12. Considering the level of detail and there inaccuracy’s this pricing is just beyond a joke. As a simulator of driving trains in the UK it is really terrible. As a train driver who has driven trains and routes that appear in the game I have to say it is very unrealistic. It certainly isn’t a simulator. Almost all the trains have massive aspects of there function, and operation missing. The operation of AWS and TPWS which are integral parts of driving trains are either missing or integrated incorrectly. AWS magnets at signals often don't even register. Most of the buttons in the cab don't work. The starting of engines and even down to the basics of simply pulling away is completely wrong. If you think you are driving a train when you play this then you are mistaken. Obviously it has to be basic so it can be played by people of varying degrees of knowledge but there isn’t even an option to play a realistic mode.The routes are never updated; the signals are mostly in the wrong place and act in un-characteristic ways. Platforms lengths, scenery, junctions are generally works of fiction. The performance characteristics of the trains are also inaccurate. It’s impossible to drive the train in a safe manner and keep to the timetable. Games like this only exist because people pay good money for rubbish. This game could be so much better and bigger and make even more money if its production company put a little effect in and weren’t so greedy.  There is a massive gap in the market for a realistic train simulator, probably community developed, when that happens the train simulator franchise will be dead.

content:
ber 17, 2015
												Let me start by saying I actually like this game.It's fun to play, and you can spend hours and hours in it without getting bored. At least, if this is your thing. This is not a fast-paced shooter. It's a game simulating trains. Obviously.However, despite me liking this game, there are some serious reasons why I would NOT recommend it.First of all, the basic game is already quite expensive. You can have some fun with what comes with it by default. But a little more would never hurt. When you're done with the vanilla content, and turn to DLC's, things get really expensive, really fast.The amount of DLC available is huge, and I applaud that. But the prices for these packs are not just high, they are exhuberant. In my opinion, the prices are at least three times what they should be at most.A very, very big downside that shows itself in this DLC library, is that much of this DLC was made for older versions and weaker PC's, and has never been brought up to modern standards. But it's still sold at the same very high prices.So you end up with a large library, but of very varying quality, especially in the visual department.Another downside is that it's hard to tell how realistic or how deeply simulated a given locomotive is. Some require quite a bit of study, others are hardly more than visual skins over a very simple simulation. Again, hard to tell the difference beforehand.And another problem I have encountered, is that even old, well known problems never get patched.So, my advice?If you like trains, and there's a sale going that will get you this game at -75% or so, by all means go for it. I did.But at full price? I'd stay away if I were you. There's better things you can do with your hard earned cash.

content:
er 4, 2013
												Train Simulator 2014, a remake of Train Simulator 2013, which was just a remake of Train Simulator 2012. In fact nothing much has changed to this ‘simulator’ since the very first incarnation of it back in 2007. So what has it got to offer? For a start the graphics are brilliant, so you really can enjoy the scenery as you drive through it. Another plus would be the world editor, allowing users to create new routes and upload them to the steam workshop for free. That’s just as well because once you have got through the small amount of content that come with it the official DLC’s are extremely expensive and usually of low quality. Unfortunately there are major problems with this simulator; the train physics are unrealistic, AI trains powered by rockets (or so it seems), a very limited range of on train systems are simulated, with some trains not even having such simple things as DRA! The list goes on. I would urge anyone looking to purchase this simulator/game to think again, many other options are available.

content:
ber 11, 2016
												It’s really sad that the only fleshed out Train Simulator on PC these days is this poor excuse of a videogame.I won’t even speak much of the thousands of dollars’ worth of DLCs - some of which are little more than a badly made 3d model being sold for a full game price. There are plenty of other reviews that cover that.It started out fun. I enjoyed it enough to invest in some extra content (the route bundles are the least overpriced). Then I made the "mistake" of upgrading my computer.This game, which is called Train Simulator 2016 is almost unplayable on a 2016 computer, thanks to frequent crashes, consistently low framerates, ugly visuals, and FPS drops that are almost rhythmic with the movement and sound of the train. I tinkered with the settings, between highest and lowest. It made no difference.I emailed the developer. They replied after a massive delay, "but it runs perfectly on our much weaker computer!", and promptly closed the issue within days before I could get a chance to respond.I asked the community for advice. They tried to convince me that it was most unreasonable of me to expect this 2016 release to run on my 2016 computer. Or how my set-up is "unbalanced" or "not good enough" despite running every other game flawlessly. Some referred to their real-life experience of driving trains, and how that has made their opinions on computer hardware and software paramount. But credit where its due - most of their passive-aggressive sermons began with hello and ended with thank you.For people who have spent hundreds and thousands of dollars in this game, and are now unable to enjoy them, the dev's solution is to release a new game engine, which of course, will NOT support said hundreds and thousands worth of content. Meanwhile, they keep repackaging this broken software as a "new release" every year, and keep selling a thousand dollars more of DLCs, WITHOUT any warnings to buyers about the horrible expected performance, and without any commitment to give players their money's worth.If you are still living in the last century, you might love this. Everyone else, (and I wish I could suggest a better alternative) wait for the new game engine next year.

content:
y 3, 2015
												I really tried to like this game.. I really did but:.....1.  All that really matters in this game is the speed indicator.  In order to do some of the missions you have to go a little bit faster than the speed limit (i.e. going 35.5 instead of just 35) in order to make it on time.  Problem is... if you go 36 you get penalized. With trains that have a lot of cars, the speed get very irregular. You may go 3 mph under the speed limit and all of a sudden in a matter of milliseconds be going 3 mph over the speed limit which results in penalties. Since the only thing that matters in this game is the speed limit indicator, it is such a shame that the people who developed... say the scenery wasted their time cuz you can't enjoy the scenery with your eyes literally GLUED to the speed limit indicator.2. I love steam trains... and they are still bugged from the 2013 version. 3. Saving your game is detrimental. I don't know if the developers didn't save the states of the junctions, but I have noticed that when I reload a saved game, the game bugs out and I can't get onto the correct track or other trains end up running into me, or light won't change because I am not where I am suppose to be.  They have a save game option for each scenerio, but it is a gamble if you use it.4. Expensive expansion packs. With as buggy as the game is, why would I want to pay more for expansions when the base game is buggy?It does have its good points, but the more I played this game, the more I realized that the suck sucks way more than the good points. Beautiful as this game is, I can't recommend this game to someone when everytime I install and try to play this game, I am reminded why I uninstalled it in the first place!

content:
ry 4
												Train Simulator is - at least to me - the most realistic train simulator out there. The variety of the DLC's that you can buy allows you to play in the most known railways in the world. The controls are, for me pretty nice and realistic. But this game has flaws. Way too many flaws...Pros- Realistic train controls- Nicely modeled trains and environments- Huge variety of contentCons- The base game brings only a few scenarios and trains to drive- The DLC's, where you can bring more scenarios and trains, are often expensive- There's a huge flaw that makes the game crawl when it needs to load the scenario - not on the loading screen, but while you're driving- While loading the scenario, the games becomes almost inresponsive, so if you try to brake there's a huge chance that that's not going to happen- Some scenarios are almost impossible to achieve the 1000 points mark, the max you can get. For instance, with the Train Simulator: LGV: Marseille - Avignon Route Add-On DLC you have a scenario where you need to wait on a red signal before stopping in the last station, making you get a penalty due to arriving at the station late- This one is new for me There's a probability where after resuming a scenario, the save corrupts Proof- When, for any reason, the game crashes, it can lock your computer. In my case I have to disconnect the HDMI cable, connect it again, press CTRL + ALT + DELETE and open the Task Manager, press WINDOWS + TAB and set the Train Simulator window in another Desktop - otherwise I can't click on anything -, go to the Task Manager and close the Train Simulator there.ConclusionIf you like trains, and like simulators, then this might be the game for you - I don't know other train sims out there that can beat this one, to be honest -, but keep in mind that you'll probably need to spend a lot of money in DLC's, deal with freezes and crashes that the workaround is not acceptable - or play in windowed mode.

content:
y 25, 2014
												Well, Iv'e had had this 'product' for a few months now, originally a gift for my 50th, it then updated to the current version, as I tried to get to grips with it I noticed lots of silly faults... Wrong speed markers or missing speed markers on routes (sherman hill being the worst), scenarios that simply didn't load (Isle of Mann). After repeatedly contacting the now dovetail manufacturer, all you ever get is some stock answer that they are aware of the issue, but never, I repeat never, do they actually fix the game. Surely there are rules to prevent any company selling a product that does not work, oh! of course there are, it's called trading standards. In any other walk of life if you have a faulty product you take it back and demand a working one - simple!!!Not being very computer savvy, I then bought the Steam version during the sale, got a few more DLC's whilst they were cheap, only to find the same old problems still existed. Look at all the reviews, mostly negative ones, they are all correct, there can be some enjoyment from this game/simulator, if only it worked. There's nothing worse than spending an hour of concentration, keeping to speed limits, folowing the instructions, trying to keep to time, only to hit a 30mph zone, at 29mph I might add, to suddenly see the 'speeding -6' repeating and all your efforts wasted as the speed allowed is actually 20mph. Surely the manufacturer 'tested' the product before releasing it. Apparantely not. The only way to get this sorted and have a game that fulfils it's expectations is if all the users banded together, created a petition and approached trading standards with a 'class action' against Dovetail to repair all the issues within the game and put it right once and for all. If half their efforts (Dovetail) went into fixing the game instead of trying to censor the 'true' comments of concerned users, who are simply trying to get a working product, then all would be well.I'm also sure Steam are well aware of all these issues, yet they too seem impervious to users concerns, surely they should stop selling the product as it clearly is defective and not fit for purpose, Oh!, perhaps they simply make too much money out of it to be bothered.I have an old copy of Trainz (2009) on disc bought for a couple of quid, does the job, loads of stuff to do, and it works...Don't waste your money until you see that the game is fixed and works.

												I know theres people geniuinely interested in trains and I know theres people that buy this just for thousands of dollars DLC meme.I- got this because it sounds fun to me, was I disappointed? Not a whole lot.Is it a good simulation/game? It does have its right to existence and frankly I did enjoy the time I got to spend with it and being slightly overwhelmed by the powerful map editor. To me this is just missing one thing that would make the experience so much more worth it: Atmosphere, or immersion even... The sounds are weird and it doesnt present itself well, heck the passengers still consist out of like 32 polygons with a face slapped onto their flesh colored cubic head. If they manage to, at some point get this right and make it actually look good and make the whole world look more alive, I would absolutely recommend this to anyone, really this could be the ETS2 of trainsims. But for now, I sadly can't... unless you are very passionate about this.

content:
27, 2016
												So I have hesitated in getting into train sims for a while now. I have read reviews, and watched youtube videos. I read all of the complaints and the to-do about the expensive DLC. It made me not want to try this game because of all the negative reviews. The recent Steam sale gave me the opportunity to get into the game cheaply. Figured if it sucks, I lost the price of a pizza. Having played the game now let me add my 2 cents from the prospective of someone completely new to Train Simulator games. About the DLC pricing: I'll compare it to one of the most successful game franchise.. The Sims. Nobody complains about the Sims add on content, or Flight Sim X add on content or any other game that pops you for $20 bucks for an "expansion". I mean if you bought the Sims 3 game today at full retail price with all the expansions you are looking at $600. But by comparison look at how many "stuff" and "expansions" packs are available for this game compared to the Sims game... So of course it is going to cost more to get all the content. As far as the old graphics and bugs, I see it as DTG doing their best to keep the 6 year old content users have bought still compatible and therefore usable in the new version of the game. I think they should have split the games into each year and set out compatible DLC for each edition. You want the next generation graphics... gotta by the new game. (See EA's Sims, Sims 2, Sims 3, Sims 4 model) Nobody is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that their Living Large expansion pack for Sims 1 doesn't work on the Sims 4 game today. Yet Dovetail has tried to give their customers equity in the DLC they buy. They have tried to update the game without completely changing the game engine so that previous content can still work. Imagine how crappy Sims 4 would be if EA was still making it compatible with Sims 1 stuff. That being said, I caught the Steam sale and pulled the trigger on buying the game to try it. I have to say, it is not going to be for everyone. There is nothing shooting at you. There is nothing for you to shoot. You don't race anything... Except maybe the clock on a time schedule. It's a Train simulator... You drive trains. That's it. Its not the most exciting thing in the world. But then again neither is Flight Simulator in between take offs and landings. And even ETS2 and ATS can get boring in the long haul between pickup and delivery points.But the game does have a certain quality for those who like simulator games. Driving a big train in and out of yards is great fun. Operating a heavy coal train in the driving snow down a slippery slope is challenging. The workshop community has tons of free scenarios for you to run with your purchased DLC, giving this game an unbelievable amount of play time. I have played for 72 hours and have not even began my career mode yet. I have my favorite trains and my favorite kinds of routes and scenarios. But I have yet to really explore any of the UK, German, or Asian routes and trains yet. I've been running freight across North America, and have not gotten into passenger trains yet. 72 hours, and I have barely scratched the surface. I think I am getting my money's worth.If you are new to train Sims like me and just want to know what is a good place to start, I have a suggestion. Wait for a sale.. Then buy the TS2016 Steam edition. You get an extra route and more trains and content then with the base game. Then pickup the Aurora_Chicago route add on. This will give you a good mix of freight and passenger train scenarios to try. That's really all you need and should get at first. Try out the different types of scenarios, try out the different countries. Drive the different trains. Find out what interest you. Then target your DLC purchases around that. I went in thinking I would like the high speed European passenger trains, but I have fixated on the American freight trains so far. I have almost 70% of the DLC for North America now. That's quite a few pizzas, but I am happy with most of the DLC. Just like with the Sims stuff packs, sometimes you get something that leaves you feeling like there should be more to it for the money you just spent on this piece of DLC. But then there are plenty of others that are like getting 100% more game! So you need to try the different types of trains and activities to find out what you like. That is really the only way to get started with this game and the mountain of DLC. Hey if you want all $3000 worth of DLC for the game then go for it. But chances are 60% of it is not going to intrest you that much. Kind of like the Katie Perry expansion for Sims 3. What the hell do I want with a lollipop couch and a hot fudge futon?I know there are plenty of people on here and other sights that have been with this game since TS2009 and before. I can sympathize with their grief over all the yearly "updates" and roll out difficulties. I would be frustrated too if I was forced to upgrade a game that has been playing fine, and that I finally got all the bugs worked out of. Especially if I knew that the update would screw things up and introduce conflicts and errors and make my working game crash forcing me to start all over.  But they still play the game and that should tell you something. And the news is that Dovetail is not going to be "upgrading" TS2016. They are finally going to make their "Sims 2" version with TS2017. But Dovetail has promised to continue to support and produce DLC for TS2016 for the foreseeable future. So maybe not such a bad time to finally get into this game.As far as performance issues, I cannot be of much help. As a Computer Engineer, I am baffled by the number of people who believe meeting the MINIMUM system requirements means they will be able to run the game on high graphics settings. Understand this, as it pertains to any game: If your system just meets the listed minimum system requirements, this means the game will run but at the lowest graphic settings and everything turned off. That is why it is called the MINIMUM system requirements. I have not experienced any crashes nor drops in frame rate or rendering problems with this game. I run all games on maxed graphics settings and all options turned on. Why? Because I am well beyond the minimum system requirements with my gaming platform. I run all my games on both my PC and my gaming laptop, switching between the two weekly because I travel. My system specs are included below for reference.Gaming PC: Win 7 Ultimate 64-bitMSI 970 Gaming ATX motherboardAMD FX-8350 8-core Processor (Black Edition) 4.0 GHz32 Gig Kingston HyperX Fury DDR3 @ 1866MHzMSI GTX 960 Graphics card (4Gig)WD Black 1TB 7200 RPM SATA hard driveLaptop: Win 7 Ultimate 64-BitAlienware M17x R4Intel Core i7-3610QM 2.3 GHz32 Gig DDR3 Ram (DELL)Using Intel HD onboard graphicsSeagate 1TB hard drive

number of helpful: 29 of 32 people (91%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
r 16, 2016
												For what can already be a dull and slow-paced genre, this game somhow manages to muck all that up.The Problems:- The graphics, even on highest setting, really aren't that great. For a genre that is heavily graphics-based, this is a huge letdown.- The train models aren't that great either, and look dated.- While kudos for including some okay American assets with the game, the included selection as a whole is limited. This game is obviously a DLC driver, which is severely overpriced (to the tune of $20 for a single locomotive).- Suffers from intermittent framerate drops, even on decent hardware. Game will run at 70fps most of the time, and randomly dip down to 30fps.- The trackside camera (the one you're likely to use the most, other than the cab view maybe) is repetitive, unimaginative, and often puts you in weird places (like spawning inside of a hill, where you can't see anything).- The sounds are repetitive and poorly edited (some of the train horns clearly repeat loops, etc.). Plus, there seems to be a near lack of ambient sounds to try to enliven the already dull environments.- The environments as a whole feel dead, and are poorly decorated (everything looks too clean).- There are pop-in issues, and the draw distance is not that great (sometimes there's just nothing drawn on the horizon).- While tutorials getting you started driving are included, not everything is explained properly (in one scenario, for example, the train randomly keeps stopping with no explanation).- While driving a train in real life probably is difficult, I feel like there should be better options to "control the difficulty" (for example, assisting you in helping your train keep moving up a snowy mountain without stalling or slipping, as some of us just want to drive the train).- The main game interface is okay, but could be improved. Same for the OSD.- The DLC is mega expensive.There is just too much wrong or poorly done with this game for me to recommend it. If you really really like train simulators and this is on sale then you might want to give it a go, but otherwise leave it alone.

10, 2015
												Simulator?  Hardly!  Do not buy this product if you expect it to be very much like running an actual train,  I have run both freight trains and passenger trains and I can assure you that there is so much more that could be added to this game to make it a really great simulator.  I could type up a complete list of items that need to be rectified and/or added but I have better things to be doing.  A short list would be little details like the whistle posts on the CP Mountain Sub are diamond shape, not square.  Approach signals are usually staggered and display proper sequences, for example: not clear to slow then medium to stop.  Train braking physics are way off as well.  Do not pay full price for this game, wait for it to go on sale first.  @Steam, if you read this, I am very sure there are some experienced Locomotive Engineers that are using Train Simulator that would be more than happy to give you input for improvements, I know I would offer advice.

number of helpful: 36 of 44 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2013
												With great disappointment, I'm not able to leave a positive review.I love trains, and I love simulators -- what could be better than a combination of the two? There was a time when I believed this game would be. Don't make the same mistake as me. I sometimes find myself playing this just to make myself feel better about how much money I wasted on it.To put it in perspective, I was able to use Microsoft Flight Simulator X to practice advanced topics for my real life pilots license, the base FSX software came with almost every airport in the world and a wide range of aircraft. In contrast, this GAME, by itself comes with virtually no content, the content it does come with is mediocre at best, and the realism level is severely lacklustre. Sadly, I've been foolish enough to spend more on this than on FSX, hoping it would eventually come remotely close in terms of delivering.If you want to experience any variety in locomotives or scenery, you will have no choice but to purchase DLC. In my experience, the DLC is often as bare-bones as the base game and usually buggier, though seldomly priced less than entire full featured games. If my understanding is correct, you can't get additional skins for a locomotive, you have to pay full DLC price for each skin you want. If your interest is in observing the spectacular outcome of a high speed derailment without all the loss of life, don't waste your time. As soon as the train derails the "simulation" ends and you're presented with a menu. Also, when you switch between front and back of the train cameras, the angle stays the same so you have to re-adjust every time you switch cameras.You get an upgrade every year but I seldom find any observable improvement. If its possible to get any closer to a piece of software that performs zero function at all with the exception of allowing you the option to buy more of their software, Im sure it will be the only "improvement" in the 2015 edition. I'm convinced they really just change the name to something containing the current year so they can create the illusion that the game is new and justify charging exorbitant prices.I honestly mean to be constructive because I wish the devs would take advantage of the game's potential. I will say that the graphics are pretty decent. Par for the era. If noticable improvements in realism were made, and content prices were more realistic and reasonable -- combined with a dramatic change in how the company treats the customers (ie. fixing problems instead of covering complaints up, not charging sucker prices for questionable professionalism) the game could definitely have a future, but based on the current state of the above, I have to say 3/10.

number of helpful: 34 of 41 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2013
												Where to start!,if you thought EA was bad then this company and game makes them look good. For starters the game is so unpredictable, one minute the game is fine the next it is suffering random crashes. The amount of bugs and glitches in the game, you would think that you was playing a very early alpha release. The company prides itself on been the best Train SImulator, which is not true in some respects but there is not much competition out there to rival the fact.As you start to play the game its fairly good and has a fresh approach to the genre, although as you start to immerse yourself into the game and the community things start to change. This is a game which is very moddable, where users can create things and share there creations with the community. But there seems to be a trend where every modder wants to charge you for there work. Unlike Skyrim, GTA iv etc where the user content is varied and free, in this game you will find a lot of greed where people only do it to get money. So it is a very money orientated game. Even the freeware site that provides free content is subscription based, although you can download for free if you  want to wait an hour in a que.It is this greed factor that contributes to the feeling of contempt every time you start the game, immediately faced with promotions to buy overpriced DLC that has bugs or does not work. You will also in time have to contact support as this is inevitable, everyone I have spoke to has done this. And you get an automated response, one of which outlines how there not that bothered.If you are planning on doing some freeware projects for this game like I have done in the past, I would advice against it. As you will be faced with a barage of hate from a majority of the community. In short the game is just bad in game as well as out of it. The only major freeware project was the ecml, and the creator was abused on so many levels. So there idea of creating content was for me a big no, and one of the reasons why I stopped developing.This is one game you should avoid at all costs, not only for your sanity but also for your wallet. If Steam has any credibility in protecting it's customers then it would be in there best interest to remove this game from there store.Overall has potential, but the greed,bad customer service, bugs and glitches and a majority of the community let's it down.As a side note to show you what you can get for the same price as there DLC's including 3rd party DLC'S ( comparisons current from date of this review ):A second hand Rolex WatchLG 60" HD TV + XBOX One + Playstation 4Top of the range Alienware Desktop Pc150+ Full priced Steam Gamesand if your a train fan, 6 Luxury Train Holidays in the UK.Quick Edit: This company have changed there name to Dovetail and have appointed a new executive from EA, says it all really. And to top things off this company have tried to hide negative comments by marking them as ' off topic '. Shows how much they do not want you to hear the negative side of things. Every game gets negatives but thats part and parcel of games, but i have not seen other companys trying to ignore customer feedback on Steam as much as these.

content:
er 4, 2013
												I've been considering Train Simulator for a while now. Up until now, the main reason I didn't get it, was the price. However, during Steam's recent autumn sale, the christmas DLC was 80% off, and since it didn't need the (expensive) core game to play, I decided this was my chance to try it out and see for myself how I like it.Well, the game itself could be fun for a while, but my overall experience wasn't all on the positive side. While the game doesn't seem too complicated, the interface isn't very comfortable, to say the least. It took me a while just to figure out where exactly I'm supposed to stop to complete a scenario. You'd think it should be really simple, right? Well, so would I. At first I thought that maybe I was just being stupid and impatient, so I gave it some time and soon enough I figured it out. Regardless, I was feeling a little cheated, sort of like "Okay, I got it, I completed the scenario, but what now? Is that supposed to be it? Where's the fun!?".Still not being sure whether I should give this little game more time or not, I figured I'd go read reviews on Steam, see what other people think, and then I encountered the reason for my decision not to get the game. It seems like the moderators the developers assigned to moderate the reviews to their game are quite the dictators. Watch how they mark this review as "off-topic", just like they did with the other negative reviews this game received. While those reviews described flaws and drawbacks regarding the game, they were fair, to the point and as on-topic as you can get. It seems like the developers of this game would go quite far to hide any negative criticism, justified as it may be. If this is how it works, it makes me wonder - what are they so worried about? What are they working so hard to hide from everyone? I don't know about you, but if I ever find out, I promise you - it won't be by playing the game itself. Those guys are not getting any of my money. Not only because I have doubts about the game (and I do still have doubts), but mainly because I feel I'm being manipulated and left in the dark.In conclusion, while I'm still not completely sure about the game itself, the attitude of the developers made me decide to stay away from this game, and I suggest to you to stay away as well.

A community with such a love for the game; or rather for what the game could have been. A community increasingly frustrated with the lack of support from the developer.Do I regret buying it? No, not really. Would I reccommend it? No, I can't.Call it stupid, call it naïve, but I really want to believe that there is a brighter future for this game. I really want to believe that this game one day will become what it has potential to be. Right now however, even though there is talk about them working with a new game engine for next year's release, nothing indicates that that will come true.Though I sincerely hope that I will have to rewrite this review one day.

content:
er 16, 2013
												I have payed this game every day since I got it, almost logging in more hours than I should, but this game has been worth it....or has it? I got this game for me and my father to play together since we have been rail fans for years. Ever since I can remember. My passion was HO models while his was G-scale. Anyways, when I got this game i was expecting....more. I dont like the simplicity of the free roam, how it has only one set map (even after I got two others) and creating (truly) can be fun to some, but sadly I'm to busy to spend days on end just making a map. I live in Garden Grove California, not far from the actual Pacific Surfliner, heck I see that thing almost daily on the Amtrak/Metrolink line. Anyways, the point I'm trying to get across is "Why is there only one map and one set of trains allowed in Free Roam?" I'm a HUGE fan of steam trains, my personal favorite is the UPBB 4-8-8-4. I even got to see the 4014 (Soon to be the only running one of its kind) and I was amazed. Now to drive that thing down the Surfliner track in free roam would be amazing! But... the downside is....I can't. Why? well, i believe the developers made it abit more...realistic in the sense of that most of the tracks in the game are all urban areas, not freight or rural areas like the Pass. I can kinda see the point there. But seriously. I wanna just.....PLAY! Not have a task list. Being able to go from San Diego to LA without having to worry about other trains and scenario finishers. I wanna be able to control where my train goes. The pass is fun, sure, but there's such long distances between most of the switch tracks that you hafta choose right at the beginning by checking your map (again, the Pass is a rural area through the mountains so cant really B**ch) and the closest thing TO a quick drive free roam is the Holiday Express. You can control the track at least in there....but still, the map is so tiny....nothing really to do there.. You cant go anywhere cause of the lack of FREE ROAM! Seriously....The word FREE is in it.... 0.0 Shouldn't there be more? Unless this is a ploy to make us waste our money away on nothing but scenarios and trains and no GOOD free roam maps.... Anyways. I still wanna see the rest of the maps. I haven't even been able to see that skew off on London-Faversham. There's a whole lengthy track I've never seen! that probably no one has ever seen. Why? Cause there's no Free Roam for it. Only A-B.... Anyways, I've rambles your ears off and you're probably tired of reading. Just asking for a lot more for the money I've put into the game for me and my dad to enjoy a game where you can only do 2 things.... (The standard game + 6 DLCs: 4 trains and 2 maps).(Update as of May 06, 2015):    Is it just me or are the prices going UP for the DLC of this game? I'm looking around and they are STILL ridiculously over priced. Yet I do see something....strange.  Or o it just me. Some of the DLC are saying: You do NOT need Train Simulator 2015 to play this game. Now to me that's just plain weird... Are you telling me that your so-called ADD-ONS are also STAND ALONE GAMES? Dafuq is the use of that? Hmmmm. Dovetail...have you ever thought of, oh I dunno... reducing the price of your DLCs to below $20 USD period and maybe...just MAYBE you'd get more people to buy yo sh*t?    I....really don't think so considering the developers of this game either 'hide' the negative reviews or just plain ignore them. I dunno what kind of company they are, but they are doing a bad job promoting such an unbelievable amazing game. I bet if their DLCs were cheaper and not trying to be sold as Stand-Alone content, a lot more people may find this game more enjoyable and want to play more of it and, oh I dunno... SPEND MORE MONEY MAYBE! TAKE THE HINT! It also may hafta do with them being British...or not from the US....Dunno. Just a theory...

content:
y 22
												Ok let me start with this - If you're in the UK do NOT purchase Train Simulator through Steam. Purchase it through Amazon UK downloads instead as its far cheaper (I payed 75% less), Amazon will give you a redemption code to use on Steam.Now onto the game itself, it's an incredible train simulation game - there's no doubt about it. Everything about the simulation is great! Sure, I would like to have a few more features such as train announcements and lifelike NPCs - but the game is still enjoyable. Also the Steam Workshop is a fantastic feature for this game.So why the 'Not Recommend'?Well first, the DLC. There is WAY too much of it and the prices are ridiculous (for some). Now the extra routes are justifiable for £10-20, but over £20 and you're getting ripped off. Then we have the trains which you can unlock, they're priced stupidly. There should be no train DLC over £10 AT ALL! Yet there is, and there is loads of it. Half of these trains should've come included with the base game yet they didn't. So yeah, the DLC is a rip off.Maybe the DLC could be justifiable for a game that has no performance problems, and that brings me to my second point - performance. If this game worked flawlessly then maybe I could justify the DLC but it DOESN'T! In fact, this is one of the worst performing games I've ever had. I have a GTX 970. i7 Quad and 16GB RAM. This game should run at easily 60fps on high settings - does it? NOPE! What about 50fps? NOPE! 45fps? NOPE! 44fps, that's the most stable it can run on this PC. So you're probably thinking, "Why doesn't he just turn the settings down?" I did - did it change anything? NOPE! And this isn't the worst part, constantly there are frame rate dips to 10fps, these are happening almost every 30 seconds, pretty much making the game impossible to play! Is there a fix to this? NOPE! There are countless amounts of forums with people with the same issues, nobody can fix it. It's literally impossible.Dovetail haven't even addressed these issues, they are literally ignoring their fanbase. This is totally unacceptable. These issues have been happening since 2013! 2013! That's 4 years! 4 years and what have Dovetail Games done? Shoved a load of DLC in your face which - surprise surprise - ISN'T OPTIMISED EITHER!I just can't recommend this game for those reasons, even though this game is a perfect simulation game. All I can say is Dovetail Games, you've really let me down...

number of helpful: 29 of 35 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2013
												Not sure if my hours will show up in the corner of this, but I have logged what seems to be a very impressive 973.4 hours since purchasing TS2013 back in July. While I do run a below bottom end computer, the game initially lived up all my hopes and dreams despite the horrific framerate (which after disabling TSX and dropping many other graphical settings usually hovers between 14-15, occasionally going higher to 24 or more, which is good enough for me). Though I quickly lost interest in route building after realizing how time consuming it was.Well my opinion of the game has been changing since then and I feel like I also need to share what I think of the game noow and add to the growing list of negative reviews despite this being my first review ever and my sloppy writing style.While I don't hate the game, I've become disappointed to the point I no longer recommend it to anyone or scramble for the DLC.One of my biggest issues isn't the pricing (not saying I don't have issues about it), it's the quality. The routes tend to be very good in my opinion despite the lack of TSX and reduced density in my case, but the same isn't as true with the locomotives and that was the first thing that made me start thinking "Is this really the game I wanted for over two years?"While driving around on Sherman Hill I noticed the sounds, specifically the horns, weren't consistent enough. One locomotive would have a loud horn, but another may have a horn that was dramatically lower in volume. Vastly different bell sounds and quality also disappointing, like the Challenger having such a bell that sounds much too high pitched. Lights are another common disappointment. The variation in all the different styles quickly becomes an eyesore when you start mixing and matching units. Especially with the new headlight glare from the upgraded locomotives (though it does look awesome). The Cab Forward takes the lighting issue to another level with not even having the textures for one of the marker lamps in the correct locations.The best example of lack of quality in my mind is the A4 pack. While the driving programming is decent, the unrealistically quiet whistles kills much of the fun of driving them. Then there's Dominion of Canada. I was highly disappointed that not only did the sound not match the whistle's appearance, but also the bell didn't function (though I recognize that bells aren't usually needed in the UK).Graphics and sound aside, you then come to functionality. While all the basic functions are simulated, how well they are simulated varies. The brakes aren't realistic across all locomotives (though the Marias units are well simulated with their dynamic braking). I'm told that independent brakes are the best for stopping locomotives running light, but I have yet to see independent braking make a difference at all, in fact I wrecked on my first scenario because of it. Then there's throttle operation on some diesel locomotives where the amps instantly jump to one point and the rpms slowly catch up, I would only find this realistic when reducing power not increasing power. I've discovered that the operation of certain features aren't consistent inside and outside of the locomotive, such as the case of the road locomotive included with Marias Pass where all wipers are moving outside the locomotive, but one of the wipers isn't moving on the inside. My latest disappointment is also my biggest, how Railsimulator treats its community, trying to keep the bugs in the dark to the point where reviews are targeted. If a company is taking extreme measures to try keeping bugs and glitches in the dark instead of fixing them, then their products aren't worth buying regardless of price.Until they stop trying to censor and start fixing bugs and issuing the patches free of charge (for everything and I don't mean introducing another version you have to pay for just to get one problem fixed), I don't recommend you invest in this game. No company should ever treat their community like this and expect to get away with it. If they straighten up their act and start fixing this game like the community wants, then I will start recommending this game again and with much more effort than I ever did.

number of helpful: 35 of 46 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2013
												So, as a lover of Train simulator from Microsoft; I went ahead and purchased this game....well I can't really say that it is a bad purchase, but it is not a good one either.It is true that I didn't play 100 hours or so; but if I was able to spot the issues after few hours, either I am really attentive (maybe because I used to work as QA?), or for most, these issues are not really issues that can be considered a deal breaker.As is, the game is worth probably not more than 10-15 USD.Let's clarify more in details, so you can have an idea.Overall the menu is clean; the options thou are quite confusing, so it will take you a bit to understand how can you make a new route or check which add-on you have. there is a quick drive option, which will be useful to give you an idea of the game, and also some tutorials that explains you the controls.All right IF you can survive the hate against the in game purchase screen....the game won't leave you be if you change train or track in the free roaming mode, pushing you to buy more.The graphic is OK; overall it feels like a bit antiquated at times, but it is clean and overall does its job. There are some issues with the textures, where they flicker (especially if you are on maps that has water; you can see flickering where the water meets the land, but there are various instances all over the game); but overall the game is not showing tremendous corruption.The train itself are made quite nicely; lots of details on the outside; inside they are so-so, with some good textures but overall very simplicistic and not super detailed. Considering that they are the main point of the game, I would expect something similar to other products in the simulation realm  (like airplane or car simulators; just to mention few...this is a simulator after all, so it has to be compared to other sims).The object on the side of the route are many and well done; not super but they do their good immersion job.The arrangement of the objects and scenery thou may vary from map to map...some are quite stunning, with light effects and awesome arrangement; while others (like the mountain maps with snow), are so dull and bland.Also you can see in the distance the issue with object placements, where tree just disappear, and you see basically the area that goes from tree populated, to bald.The human 3d models are quite atrocious: their animations are approximate, there is very little variation among the meshes and textures, and also the collision and AI is quite disappointing....at times they just go for a spin, walking around the same spot like a dog running behind its tail. This is more evident if you just sit in a station and set the external camera. After a bit they just go trough scenery items, or start to act totally weird.The cars are OK; after all you don't have to have many different ones, since you rarely see them, but at the crossing they are there, and you can see that the variation is limited to 2-3 types. Also their collision with the ground is uneven...in some maps you see them sinking in the ground plane....The engine seems to work decently, but using high speed trains, you can see the framerate getting choppy (2x8 core processors, Radeon 5870, which is able to run more demanding games with impeccable performances); it feels like the engine is not that optimized, or maybe is based on old technology (I didn't follow the whole story of the company honestly, I just know that they are around since quite some time). At times feels like an indie game made with these free SDK like Unity or UDK, instead than a dedicated engine (nothing wrong with indie SDK; but you need to know your limitations).But I can live with these issues in the end, altho the main problems are on the central gameplay itself.You are basically a conductor (engineer), and the main point is the career, where you go trough scenery after scenery, which has different tracks and trains, and get rated based on your performace on 3 categories : - comfort of passengers (basically how good you are with accelerating and breaking)- Speed limits compliance- time table complianceThe idea is fabulous; but the implementation is full of issues.I tried few scenarios, and there is an underlying problem with speed: there is a screen that show you where the speed limits are, so you can act accordingly and set the train to the right speed. Once you pass the limit by 1 MPH, you get the alert of speeding and you start to loose points.This is where the issues start.The first problem is that the limit does not allow you any kind of room to fail....either you time perfectly your brake and acceleration, or you start to slow down too early, which makes you loose time (which reflects on the time table compliance; since the schedule is quite tight ). No room for errors, which is unrealistic (isn't this a sim?)Any person that drive a train knows, that you are allowed to exceed the limits to stay on schedule, by a certain percentage; while here the developers decided to set it to 1 MPH. Now the justification is "it is to make it harder and more realistic"; while the truth is that is easier to just set things in this way, instead than work around a flexible way to allow speeding; and give different kind of penalty to players.The second issue is due to the incorrect sync of the speed limit between the map and the main view. You are nicely riding, look at the map, see the signal and prepare to slow down...and then out of the blue, the limit change and you find yourself speeding when you are few miles away from the signal.This happened to me almost in any scenario that I tried so far; basically the map that you see on your display, is not synced with the track, giving you incorrect data. Playing like that is like to drive a submarine with an elementary school map not in scale.You will loose a ton of points, get frustrated and overall, end up not enjoying the game.In one instance; I had a limit of something like 225 KPH, I was at 190 KPH, then at one point, while approaching a station (after playing for 30 minutes or so); the limit changed out of the blue, and the train engaged the emergency alarm. I ended up being stopped in a tunnel, 2 miles away from the station, and no chance to have the train to restart (the alarm was on; even after resetting the alarm, it would not allow me to move the train no matter what). I had to restart the mission and throw a couple of things from my desk on the wall, for the frustration. Nobody mentioned that you need to put in neutral, then pull the brake control all the way back, then start again...not even the manual.Then let's talk about the content itself: the base game is limited to few tracks; so if you want a career, you need to buy DLC (20-40 USD a pop). Which is absurd, after spending money for the main game. Imagine Final fantasy where after the first mission ask you to go buy the DLC to continue the game.Last disappointment: the editor for the various scenarios and tracks; I was not able to even use it. The camera was stuck under the floor.Overall, I give this game a 5 out of 10; avoid at full price; may be worth at discounted price. I doubt that they listen to their customers, and this show already from how their site is organized: the king is DLC and screenshots, while there is no forum, no FAQ, no support area, other than an email. You know how a company works when you see at how they setup their site.You may enjoy it for an occasional train ride (maybe for your little ones), but as simulator this game is insufficient on many aspects.

By today's standards, It doesn't look all that great graphically. The User Interface feels like it was designed by a fresh year student as a home project. There isn't much content and overall, the game is pretty boring.Maybe total die hard train simulator fans have no choice but to buy this game but for anyone like me, who just wanted to play with trains, this game isn't worth it. Stay away.
