content:
ber 17, 2015
												Are you sitting comfortably - then I'll begin.Once upon a time back in September 2007 Kuju and Railsimulator.com made their introduction to the scene of Rail Simulators, and at that time, both Microsoft and Trainz had, or were in the process of, folding.At this time, Railsimulator.com, driven by Messers Siddell and Lucas, were a very approachable company, and quite frankly, they lifted up this game 100% in the first 4-5 years.Then, in marched Mr Jackson, an ex Manager from EA and also a supposed Railfan. Alarm bells rang with me then, but I gave them the benefit of the doubt, and I persisted with this game through to 2015, even though the company, by now called Dovetail, had effectively closed off any sort of communication with themselves, were selling, selling, selling - but made no visible effort to correct any of the major bugs now being sold to us.As someone else here said, while it can satisfy the rail fans wish of driving a train (at least virtually), it doesn't do it very well. A plethora of never to be fixed bugs, a greedy development team and addons which are overpriced, fluctuate in quality and usually have some part (such as sounds) either recycled from older addons or completely inaccurate. I've played this game for about 8 years now and while it looks visually like its improved, its actually gotten worse. The only thing that saves this game is the third party developers that create far better addons as well as offer better service, especially Thompson.So if you buy this, please bear these points in mind, and make your own mind up about the truth of it all. I will be buying this for myself, but am pretty sure this will be the final year, unless they pull their socks up, and realise that any successful company ALSO needs Customer Support.ADDENDUMJust found out the reason for all the hype whilst not telling us too much - that is because it will cost UK users £99.99!! ($150, or 120euros approx!!) This means I am gone, as no way I'm going to fork that out in one lump, and going by recent Twitch reveiws, what do you get for it - Stevens Pass (which I actually wanted), a China Clay pit and an "olden times" Dawlish Riviera - otherwise the game is the same as we have already. For that price, I would want a real engine to drive. :)

												Played Euro Truck Simulator? Great isn't it? Made by a reputable company renowned for rewarding its loyal fanbase with superbly crafted, highly polished games. And all delivered at reasonable prices too.Now meet Train Simulator. There's literally pages of diatribe I could write about this game, but I really can't be bothered. So let me break it down into a few sentences - The developers of this game have a monopoly on the Train Simulator market and they're ripping off train enthusiasts with this dreadfully under-produced and overpriced game.Train Simulator is a joke. It really should be better when you think of how many enthusiasts are out there and how much money has been poured into this. Dovetail Games are a joke. Hopefully a quality Developer like SCS Software will see an opportunity and release their own version.Considering how popular they've managed to make a truck simulator, they'd make a killing on a train simulator.

content:
er 26, 2013
												It's really hard to recommend this game. I've played it for several hours learning how to drive those trains, and found out how buggy this game can be.First of all - I like simulations. I already own Truck Simulator and have had my fun with it. Train simulator is great deal different, but i still like the idea of driving these heavy machines. I also have patience to learn through trial and error, so with this in mind:- A loco, having towed 20 cars doesn't have wheel slip, then all of a sudden, while towing 10 of them it HAS ENORMOUS wheel slip, so you have to apply ony 20-25% power and accelerate to 80kph, can't apply more power or wheel slip at e.g. 40kph. What's the deal with that? Sunny day, by the way.- You know how side track view (the one at the bottom) shows speed limits, then all of a sudden one of them grows just in front of my train, there's no way I could have slowed down as not to cause my train to enter emergency-brake mode or incur a penalty.- Red lights ocassionally show up right after a 90 degree turn with no indication beforehand. This is in one of these scenarios with intermodal train, Hamburg - Hanover route, fourth difficulty level.Game loading speed is abysmal. My kettle boils water faster. I have decent PC, mind you, games are on 4x2TB Raid drive. Should be fast, right? Other games load fast. Lots of texture flickering on screen. Game looks like it had no anti-alias at all. And in 1080p resolution. Truck simulator has an option which can increase detail at distance if you had enough power. Here said distance is minimal, try changing FOV in order to observe distant train - it sometimes even appears half-way under ground, which is funny.... not. And what the heck is it with all these route or loco DLCs carrying whole game price tag... I mean you can have fun with only these 3 routes provided... but not for long.Anyway, wasted potential, for a simulator. The fact that I have bought it at Christmas Sale price saves it a bit though.

r 4, 2016
												TS has been the best actual simulator of railroads, but has offered numerous frustrations which I've tolerated. But upon hearing the release plans for TS2017+, I am depressed that it is no longer a viable use of my time and I have wasted hundreds of dollars for years for nothing.I'm extremely disappointed in:- the yearly releases that don't add or fix anything for existing players, without requiring those players to fork over extra money for new routes- the astoundingly overpriced DLC which has many bugs- the extraordinary lag even on new computers with dedicated GPUs (you can disable lighting but that actually ruins nighttime visibility on some routes and actively removes scenery from others, making them as useless as wireframe)But most of all, I'm disappointed that every bit of content I bought is now worthless in the "World Edition" which we're being asked to buy. How do the developers expect me to keep gigs upon gigs of binaries & content which I can only play in my old version, and get a new edition comprising gigs upon gigs which I can only play separately? This demonstrates the utter lack of support for existing users of this product: the team has stated they're completely uninterested in backwards compatibility AND even in rebuilding prior routes -- such as, say, Northeast Corridor -- for the new edition. And if they ever DID rebuild a route for "World Edition" you can guarantee it'd cost you tons of money to re-obtain it.New gamers beware: I can't recommend buying 2017 because you'll have to keep it as a separate game and have to install a future edition that won't play any of the routes you received (or ANYTHING else currently available for sale - look it up, it's true).Existing gamers, which are bread-and-butter for competitor developers like Auran, already know that this team's behavior is pathetic. This is just the nail in the coffin.

number of helpful: 58 of 90 people (64%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
0, 2016
What is it?A simulation that exists somewhere between 'game' and 'realistic'.  There is a variety of driving offered, from high-speed modern electrics operating fast passenger routes, diesel shunting in rail yards, to vintage steam locos.  Train driving itself isn't so much of a challenge as operating to a tight timetable without giving your passengers a severe case of whiplash or screeching to a stop about three miles beyond the station platform!  A range of difficulties and lengths of play are offered in both career and non-career missions.Is it difficult?Driving a more modern train included in the base game is easy: start, stop and a few speed settings in between when using basic controls.  You can opt for more advanced controls and difficulty options (like your train being forced into an emergency stop if you run a red signal - it will take you about 900 years to get back to speed again so kiss goodbye to your timetable)!  The difficulty comes in maintaining safety while keeping to a brutally tight real-world timetable.  Steam locos are considerably more difficult, but this is where Train Simulator is really immersive.  The levels and dials are best operated in 3D for a full simulation experience, and you probably won't be able to see clearly where you're going - that's IF you're going, rather than chugging out a lot of black smoke!Also included in the product are all the tools to make your own routes.  You are rather left to your own devices with what appears to be a very confusing interface at first.  However, quite a few of the DLC routes now sold through Steam started life as fan-made routes using the tools.  There are likely some decent user-created guides out there by now (this game started out as Rail Simulator many years ago so it's been around for a long time now).What regions does it cover?The UK, US and Germany are heavily supported (the base game was originally only these countries and players who went on to make DLC routes tended mostly to be from those same countries).  There is (slowly) increasing support for other countries through third-party developers offering coverage of some routes in Canada, China, Netherlands and South Africa for example.  Mostly, this has been left to gamers to provide this content, but much of it is every bit as high quality as the base game assets, if not better - and has started to earn its creators some money.Why the poor reviews?Mostly, the negativity has been because of the DLC pricing, with some claiming that it will cost you in the region of $5000 to buy it all.  But they miss the point.  You're not meant to 'buy it all' (and if you did, there probably wouldn't be enough years of 'useful life' of your PC, your version of Windows or life-span on Planet Earth to play it all).  No, the idea is that there might be 2-3 routes that interest you in addition to those provided in the game, and a few locos that you like or which suit your routes.  As a guide, since 2009, I've acquired in the region of 7 routes, and perhaps twice that number in locos, and have had literally hundreds of hours of play from them.  Although DLC locos are sold with missions that might depend on a particular DLC route, if you don't have the route you can still place the loco on one of your owned routes.  There are hobby sites such as UKTrainSim as well as Steam Workshop that offer free content, and plenty of third-party sites like JustTrains that sell advanced DLC.  The DLC made by the game's developers is usually half-price during Steam sales, with mega-bundles being an excellent way to grab a lot of content relatively cheaply.In a highly moddable game such as this, there are also the inevitable bugs.  In the base game, these are fairly minimal, but additional content from third-party creators can be the cause of crashes and failing routes (as usual with any game that supports player content, mods can clash or cause crashes, and not all creators update their creations to keep in line with each iteration of Train Simulator).  Finally, performance is a constant bugbear.  This game has always been a mixed bag on performance, with some heavy city locations with busy rail traffic and overhead catenary slowing even the best of PCs to a crawling framerate.  Mostly though, the game plays very well on a gaming-grade PC.  It is both CPU and GPU heavy, and places similar demands on your system as MS Flight Simulator FSX does, so the majority of players find that they're dialling down a few settings for better performance.In summaryThis won't be a game for everyone.  It's a rather niche product with a dizzying array of DLC (much of it expensive - wait for sales) and it needs a beast of a PC if you can't live without using SSAO graphics settings!  However, picking a few favourite locos and a couple of routes in addition to the decent amount of content in the base game will keep you happy (if not your passengers - poor things) for some time to come without breaking the bank.And if you are the first person ever to have bought ALL that DLC, can I have a new car please?!  One of those swanky sporty things that millionaires have...  I would catch a train instead, only I crashed the last one.

Some of the scenarios appear just impossible to complete with unachievable timescales unless you are driving 'Concorde' - do the developers/testers actually try out all of these before publishing/selling to the paying public ? To be fair, some scenarios ARE actually quite interesting/challenging and fun though ! If only they were all like that ! Where has the 'recently released' WCML Trent Valley route gone ? ; it's not in the DLC list anymore ! Lastly : who will actually use the "Add all DLC content to cart" button on the main page ?

content:
22, 2014
												So far I have had an incredibly frustrating experience with this game. First off, no manual whatsoever. The tutorial is a very short run on a generic electric train that only shows you the very basic controls. It doesn't tell you that there are speed "limits" (which you get penalized if you exceed by 2 km/h and "suggested" speeds that if exceeded by "too much" (how much is anyone's guess because there's nothing explained about them) suddenly slams on the emergency braking system (which they also don't tell you how to de-activate) which results in you being penalized first for having the emergency systems activated and then because you are decelerating quickly, then penalizes you for poor ride quality. Did I mention there's no manual for any of this? Or that this mission after the tutorial is the easiest? Oh yes, when you start the second mission it neglects to tell you that you must raise the arm to conact the overhead power lines, or which control does this. If you look at the outside of the train with the chase cam at the front of the train, you will not see the arm raise or lower because the one at the BACK of the train is going up and down. So unless you happen to click the right camera view there is no indication that you are hooked up or not.The "suggested" speed comes on from 225 km/h and says to slow to 200, then to 170, then straight to 100... and if you'r enot already braking hard from 170 down ( why would you there's no indication you would have to...) it slams on the brakes...The HUD shows your speed in MPH and the dashboard shows it in km/h... And the two don't have a precise match. So, if you are enjoying your run outside the train with one of the chase cams, you can easily start speeding and get penalized for it. There's also no way (that I can find because there's no manual... Did I mention that?) to change the units the HUD displays. When you pause it it gives you 2 options in the menu. Turn the HUD off, set it to minimal or full. The other option is the opacity of the HUD. That's it. The people that walk in the station look like pigeons strutting around, wih no natural walking motion whatsoever. They also appear to be walking on spongy concrete and clip into the station floor. Here's the best part, the run they pick for the first 2 missions is in England. It involves driving through a LOT of underground tunnels. Guess what there is to see in a tunnel... NOTHING! So you spend minutes at a time driving a train through a dark tunnel. Even if you turn the lights on you still can't see anything. What idiot was responsible for picking a run that puts you in the dark for your learning missions? Why not put you on a run somewhere open and bright and allow you to enjoy the scenery, mechanics of the engine etc.?  Oh yes, when it rains, you can wipe the window with the wipers and it clears a patch where the wipers are. But... When you speed up and achieve over 200 km/h, that apparently has no affect on the rain still on the windscreen.I haven't played the free roam mode yet, but if they make the beginning this frustrating, I have really no interest in the rest. I should say that I am an avid rail fan and I have been since I was little. I have ridden the cab of steam engines on excursions, I have chased iconic trains through the Rocky mountains, watched the train climb the Spiral tunnels in the Rockies and a lot more. This is a bitter disappointment and I'm glad I only paid 10 bucks for it.

number of helpful: 26 of 34 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 24, 2015
												So I finally got the pleasure of downloading the 1.4GB update to TS2016. I went to load my custom consist with SD70s on Union Pacific's Sherman Hill, one of my favourite routes. I haven't read into it enough to know whether or not this is supposed to be a beta, I hope it is because this new version is just awful. Instead of background music you only hear the continuous winter wind blowing on the menu screens from the introduction video. Exciting. There's no loading bar or screens to showcase recently released routes/trains as there was in the past, you get to stare at a black screen for several seconds/minutes and hope your desired route/scenario is still loading. The SD70 which was my favourite locomotive for being one of few with excellent audio, has been 'improved' to now sound nothing like a train. Rolling stock over the tracks sounds are even more terrible. On top of it all, the stupid brake decrease glitch - which I first discovered driving Soldier Summit's SD40-2 which requires you to spam the decrease button to shut the brakes off - has now also plagued my beloved SD70.This is an embarrassment. Not only for Dovetail, but for me, having spent so much money on this. They've even seemed to have taken a step backwards as far as optimization goes, as this is now the only game I play where I can't achieve 60FPS (I don't even know if I'm getting 30) with an i5 and a GTX970 ACX2.0 on a 1440p monitor. If you haven't already, I highly suggest you do not update and resume playing TS2015. In my eyes, after this update, this game has fallen to "shovelware" (Google it if you don't know what that means) like quality. I'm not a person to rant, but this is an abomination. I pity the folks who have spent even more than I have on Dovetail's now even ♥♥♥♥♥ier DLCs. If I'm off my wagon and this is supposed to be some kind of Beta (Alpha??) or if there's other routes that have seen real improvements, please let me know. I'd like to have some sort of hope that the Train Sim I've enjoyed in the past has some potential to be playable again.As far as the "All the DLC would cost over $3,000, that's stupid!" I don't really see the point of complaining about that, you certainly don't need to purchase more than a couple routes to enjoy the game. With that said, paying $44 CAD for a route I expect it to not have the poor optimization and bugs that they have. Even on sale they still cost too much for what they are. This wouldn't be the case if they worked like they should and didn't have any issues - these things you don't learn about until after you've spent your money. So yes, folks are right to complain about the price because most of them don't see how bad the routes are until after thay've made the purchase.The icing on the cake is the beautiful video they have showcasing the UP Turbine, which features absolutely no in-game footage. Their beautiful In-Detail videos on YouTube and screenshots are appealing, but hide the truth about how horrible this game is/has become.In conclusion, I'm disappointed to say that this update has officially killed the game for me. The sheer amount of bugs, glitches, and scenery issues would be tolerable if the game cost $10 and DLCs cost $5, but the state that Dovetail has released this game and at the pricepoint it and the DLCs, in addition to the ways that they advertise the game as mentioned above, is more than wrong, it's immoral. I do not recommend anyone spends any money on this game and supports these people for what they are doing.

number of helpful: 23 of 29 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												This game...is...of debatable quality.TL:DR:Bad physics. Unrealistic timetables. Basically DLC Simulator 2016.The Good ThingsBeing a hell of a rail-fan, this game has ways to deliever. The graphics are fairly good overall, but I think tweaks here and there are needed. In terms of controls, they are fairly realistic to my knowledge in terms of setup. The wheelslip is fairly accurate, as starting a train on a snowy hill side is a pain in the ♥♥♥ (as it should be).Routes are fairly accurate in detail.The Bad ThingsFor starts, this game is spammed with DLC. And it isn't done correctly. I payed nearly twenty bucks for this thing when it was on a sale exceeding 50%. Given my tight as hell budget, that was pushing it. I hoped that it would be worth it. Wrong. For starts, you get maybe three different overall routes, about a total of a dozen senarios (not including tutorals),  a little over a half-dozen locomotives (half of which cannot be drived outside of Quick-Drive), and next to nothing in terms of passenger services. Freight, freight, frieght. Last time I checked, that was what it was like in most of the US. While I am from the US, I do wish to remind you that I live in Illinois, an area which sees a good amount of public transport being by train. And I know as far as Europe that it is practically a nessisaty. So in order to get more content, I need to get DLC. And it isn't the $1.99 type of DLC either. I'm talking full price. If you want another route, more engines, freight, etc. and maybe 4-5 more scenarios, then expect to pay at least $20...more likely it will be above that. How many Steam engines come with this game? One. And it is in the stupid Academy paint scheme. It looks real dumb when you want to drive one, and the only way to do that is to play a quick drive and try to ignore all the electric and diesel trains that flash past you, making you look kinda stupid. Now, with wheelslip. Is it something that people like? Hell no. But last time I checked, wheelslip is usually something that is out of a driver's control. I'm sorry I gotta start on a steep hill with a 50 car train; that light was red. But I don't think I should be forced to give next to no throttle and allow my train to slide down helplessly, or risk recieveing huge-♥♥♥ penalties. Now I know you guys are not exactly aiming for a 100% realistic road simulator. I mean, that's kind of a given to me. But on the other hand, I don't think most railroad crossings have the lights going off well before the gates even go off. And I mean that your train is doing 30 miles an hour, up a steep hill, and still close to a mile from the crossing. Then on top of that, the middle of the train will still be crossing through when the gates will go up. I mean do you know how stupid it looks when that happens? And then lets have them drive through the train like it's a hologram.The speed limit is kinda crazy. I think most people will go five over and not have much of a penalty. But when you are are triple-digit speeds, the tenth-of-a-mile in the speedometer goes away. And if you suddenly are going 121 miles an hour instead of 120, then say good-bye to your points. Also, a little hard for most trains to go down a steep as hell hill with a massive freight train, and manage to spend the entrie time at a slug-like pace of a mere 25 miles an hour. I'm sure more then one engineer have gotten bored with the sluggishness and went a little bit over on the straightaways to cut down some time. They aren't being reckless.Derailments are horrible in terms of accuracy. I understand that you are not wanting to focus on such a thing, but face it; these things happen. That said, four railcars derailing should not make the entire 50-car train derail as well. That's kinda stupid.It's a good game. It has potental. But poor physics, next to no content without paying hundreds of dollars, abnormally-strict rules, among other things make what could be a fantastic game into a mediocure-at-best pile of ♥♥♥♥.

content:
er 8, 2013
												This is a hard one.  I like trains, I like train simulators (OpenBVE being by far the best and is free) but Train Simulator 2014 (2012 when I bought it) is so...lacklustre.Don't get me wrong, the visual detail ranges from adequate (ground textures, houses, cars) to impressively realised (stations, viaducts, overall scenery) however it is in how you drive the train which is very uninteractive.  I draw comparisons to OpenBVE because everything has a button and each diesel/electric train has throttle *positions* rather than a throttle that cannot be set to go at a certain percentage (and goes through the power level percentages extremely smoothly), the sounds recorded by amateurs for OpenBVE have the realism that Train Simuator lacks (trains sound like they are idling, even when the throttle is at 100% and going up a gradient) and if you care about the little details (such as replying to the guard's buzzer) then you're going to notice their conspicuous absence.For the most part you will be sat there doing nothing, whereas in OpenBVE you would be constantly adjusting throttle and braking to ensure best possible speed, time and passenger comfort (should you be doing a passenger run) or taking into account how the freight changes the handling.  This is the kind of pressure that's present in Euro Truck Simulator (which is disappointing on a different level, but not in terms of the actual driving of the trucks) but not here in Train Simulator 2014.I even bought the Settle-Carlisle pack during the sale, just to see if the experience would be any different to those included as standard.  The answer, rather resoundingly, is no as the trains still sound awful (the horns may as well be weak synth or foleyed car horns, the steam engine noises are equally weak), the amount of interactivity is negligible and when there is pressure on the more difficult routes? Be prepared for awful controls and trains that need to go to their virtual depot for either scrapping or rebuilding from scratch as they are that poor in terms of performance.I would have loved to have said that Train Simulator was - at least - good.  But it isn't.  Until Train Simulator receives a thorough reworking, it is best that you avoid this and either go buy a train set; play OpenBVE/Transport Tycoon or volunteer at your local heritage railway.  You'll save a lot of money (especially where all the DLC combined costs over £1000 prior to a Steam sale) and you'll have a far more enriching experience.

												TS2017 review:Welcome to the vintage graphics train simulator, that gets rebranded every year, but not really updated to latest standards.Same crap as bellow, just rebranded with new ultra expensive DLCsStill runs like s**t during constipation, still runs on an aged, ancient, vintage DX9 graphics engine, no HBAO, no SSAO, no dynamic lights, and all other stuff we are used to from modern games.Same as many years before, same bugs as years before, same bugged DLCs as years before, I still cannot recommend this game, even I do play an aged ETS2, but at least those devs care and it looks waaaay better than this joke of a train sim.Its cheaper and much more fun to build your own model railway, believe meTS2016 review:They just slightly rename and resell this old crap over and over every year, with over 6 years old graphics (DX9) and physiscs engine and same DLC bugs that will never be fixedThis old game engine needs to be deleted and they need to create a new one as this game is so stale and outdated in every angle, that I am very surprised anyone still buying this game and DLCsTS2015 review:I am not going into detail as this is not a bug report, i am not happy as some of the dlcs i have are no longer working properly, icons/thumbnails are missing, plus i keep finding old bugs from ages ago, many trains still don't have interior light, and much more, so generally i am not pleased, sorry but i don't see any real improvement besides a new packaging.I would rather downgrade back to TS2014 even i lost interest in this game a while ago since i emailed the support many times and its been 8 months and no replies at all, was just ignored, so i was hoping that TS2015 will fix the issues i reported and those reported by others, i was wrong, and to all that they offer same old bugy (never fixed) dlcs for same price, for the "new" base game.I love trains and i always will, but they lost a customer here, i don't think that ill ever buy any of dovetail products again, even if the quality of latest dlcs seems to be a lot better, but i wanted the old ones to get updated too, i was interested in many of them.An updated base game won't fix old DLC bugs and as i said many old bugs are still not fixed and of course new bugs arrived.TS2014 review:Outaded graphics, poor physics, Ultra expensive DLCs that sum up over 2000GBP without which the base game is almost empty.Seems to be the same sales strategy as Sims 3.If you have some spare space at home, better invest in a model railway, lot more fun, fun to build and its not just virtual plus you can sell it later.This game has almost the same old graphics as the old Railworks 1 & 2, but those at least had lot more content in the base game, here without DLCs not much to play, 3 routes couple scenarios and thats it.Textures may look ok in some places, but it needs a new game engine, HD textures, highpoly meshes and dx11 support, the train is the only thing that actually looks good in game.Many old bugs mainly in older DLCs never got fixed, poor copy-paste e-mail response from support team, so a poor support not willing to comunicate with customer.Any negative views and posts on the steam discussion will get deleted and may get you banned from discussion forums by DoveTailGames as they keep some censorship rules.Another thing are the ultra super extremly long loading times, many times it puts me off from playing, just thinking that it will take up to 15 minutes to load a scenario and it lags a lot in game sometimes.What you get here is a many years old game in a new packaging, not recommended at all.This is just my opinion, if you don't like it do read profesional reviews online before buying.I already spend over 170£ on this game and it still feels empty, so for poeple like me (causual players) still not much to play with as i don't have time to make scenarios or even download and test the ones on steam workshop plus you would need a lot more than 1 DLC to play thoseand DLCs are not worth the money they ask for them, i love trains, but this is getting more expensive than a model railway.

er 22, 2013
												About the "Trains vs zombies 2" add-on scenario:One may expect much from something picturing large heavy motorized vehicles lashing out against hordes of soft squishy stumbling flesh-bags ; one might also be so, so very wrong.So here is trains vs zombies 2 for Train Simulator 2014, a deceiving name really as most of the confrontation will take place with  steam's support when you might ask for a refund. In fact, they should've called it, "Trains and zombies, friendship is magic" as, most of the time, zombies will just engage in social talk on the boarding station or make happy parties around burning wreckages.Anyhow, scenario goes like this: You drive a train in New-York suburds, weather goes bad (or so they tell you), random walking NPC's skin turns green, oh god zombies (or so they tell you again) , you must get as far as possible, fearing that people might laugh at you for cosplaying Green Giant®. Most of the fun you will ever get from this game should be made by you, goofing around unrailing your train and trying two wheelers. Going from a quality perspective, graphics are horribly simplistic (especially for a game which, in the end, is only sightseeing), pacing feels like everyone in the world has went to "special people" school, music is inexistant and glitches are frequent occurence as NPC's do tend to park their car around 50 meters above ground, in mid-air.

content:
er 8, 2013
												It's OK(ish). However - The graphics and believability for the scenery and environment are quite poor (Looks too legoish and repetitive). The add-on's are way, way overpriced. £12 - £17 for 1 Loco to run up and down the same line that you're now getting bored with is absolute extortion.Worse still - It doesn’t come with many routes. So you will be looking at spending around £25 per route, once you have completed all the scenarios for the few existing routes that you got with the game.You can download free stuff from steam for this game e.g. routes, scenarios etc, but be warned - You will find that you still need to buy more routes and add-on packs to actually play them and make them work.I downloaded the 56xx GWR Steam Loco add on for this game in loving memory of my Dad who always wanted to drive a steam train (I thought I'd complete his ambition for him). When I went to the tutorial list for this class of loco - I found that I could not play any of the scenarios or use the tutorial because I don't have the "Memories Of Maerdy" route add on priced at £17.99What's also annoying for me is not all of the listed scenarios in this game are playable using the loco's that you already have with the original game. If you attempt to play one - You just get greeted with an in game pop-up advising you that you need to purchase yet another route to play this scenario.It's full of bugs too - e.g. people walking across the track at a stations, people walking through scenery, people walking through each other, cars hovering above the road at rail crossings, the game randomly crashing etc. Unless you are an absolute die hard rail fan - Best not to bother because you'll end up spending far too much money trying to improve this game with over priced add-on's to make it more interesting, before you realise that it's just not worth it.I purchased this when it was on special offer, and after playing it for quite a while now - I still think that it was over priced then for what it is.To me - A simulator should fully immerse you inside it, making you forget what reality you are actually in for a while. And also, to a certain extent; teach you how to fly, drive a truck, race a car properly or a train etc...I’m afraid that this game just makes me feel like I am playing with an over priced virtual train set. And that is a great shame!I really want to love this game. I keep giving it another go, hoping that it will click with me, but it’s just not happening.It just doesn't have that come back factor for me. And I am a big simulator fan.Overall - 5/10

content:
2016
												I cannot recommend this for anything outside of the German rail routes.  And, even some of those are bugged out.General Issues:- Routes suffer from 2 locomotive, 3 car syndrome.  Any more costs money, and usually have to be manually added in via modding if you want to actually see them on a train other than the one you yourself are driving.- Expensive DLC.- No indication if the dead man's switch is alarming from outside of the cab view. - Cannot disable the dead man's switch.- Seems to not be well optimized:  has periodic performance issues on even high end hardware.- Some of the scenarios have long introductiory npc scripts where you end up waiting for 5-10 minutes just for the first block to clear.Bugs:  - DLC routes are often missing from 1 or more of the game modes.- Dead mans switch fails to operate correctly.  It sometimes just fails to deactivate without explaination and eventually kicks on the emergency brake.- Emergency break kicks on unexpectedly, even if keeping up on the dead man's switch, and sometimes cannot be reset, breaking some scenerios.- Game will insist that you are exceeding a speed limit, even when you are not- Game will sometimes not tell you that the speed limit changes ahead until it's too late.- The times between stops in scenerios are often so tight that you cannot reasonably make it in time.  This is sometimes so obvious that you can't make it even with full throttle, full brake, and breaking the speed limit.- Switching on main lines in some scenerios and on free roam will inexplicably be routed into sidings and into parked NPC trains.- Dialog missing/nonsensical on some scenerios, even on introductory ones on flagship routes.- Occasionally a scenario will fail because of a hickup while coming to a stop:  Complaining that you went underway again without completing the objectives of the stop.Other thoughts: They at least fixed the bug where you got penalized for sounding the horn when going past a whistle post.

												Mixed feelings. It's fun to play the game just until you get bored with the bundled scenarios and all the bugs coming with them.Have you ever tried the shunting scenarios in Köln? It's absolutely ridiculous that the game glitches after cupling like 4 or 5 wagons and you have to save the scenario, quit the game, rebuild the game cache and return just to complete this mission. I've also experienced some weird AI collision without any actual AI present on the map (had to restart the scenario).The same applies to the bundled ICE missions where the whole signalling is just broken. Stuck in the depot while waiting for the red signal to turn green (waited for like 5 minutes) also had fun time applying emergency brakes just because some ghost speed-limit from 160 to 80 kmph. My virtual passangers thanked me at the end of the drive for sure! :)And for this whole DLC model. It's insane. Their in-game store lists some locos for €6.99 but when you click the Steam checkout button you can see that they want to charge you €13.99.Also €20-30 for routes containing 3-4 scenarios with 30 minutes of drive-time per each is utter BS. You can find highly detailed, realistic, non-glitching maps for MSTS for FREE. Almost forgot to mention that you can drive full-routes on those not just 4-5 stop services starting on deserted main-stations and ending in some random town in the suburbs.For €7 it was OK to buy the game (seen worse for that much of money) but I absolutely wouldn't recommend spending even an eurocent more on that.

content:
ber 13, 2016
												OK, with 569 hours:1. This is a marvelous game. It simulates not just driving trains, but the experience of being in them, around them, and the countryside through which they roar in all four seasons. Some look and sound so good you can almost smell the deisel. Stop at a station along the way - get out and have a cucumber sandwich and a cup of tea from your thermos.2. Don't be put off by the DLCs. This is a train enthusiast's game; a hobby. Like a train set in your attic. If you want a new loco, buy it. Add it with pride as a new thing for your collection; it's not like a patch for a broken game. Buy a train because you like it, you want it - to look at, and learn about, and drive, and watch and hear rushing by. And if you want a route, buy it to EXPERIENCE it; spend time on it. 3. The experience can range from excitement of a high speed run, to a peaceful, even cathartic experience chuffing through hills and dales and towns and cities which so well represent the lands portrayed.I cannot recommend this game more highly.

Well, besides the price tag, what else the game offers? not many things.Let's start complimenting theese guys on making a visually good game. By visually good, I say it by making textures for dirty windows, rain drops on the windows, and other enviromental stuff, but, the textures on both interior and exteriors aren't that much good looking, as on a resolution of 1366x768 I can't read some of the things written in the cab controls. About controls, they have support for a controller, but you can't customize the controls, and what about the conductor to help you out?Another down side of this game is the missions, with and EXTREMELY short timetable. A second more or less to press the load/unload command and you're already late and loosing points, not to say that you have to figure out the exact distance to start braking from the speed limit to stop wit the entire train on the station, toherwise you're loosing points too. Physics? they have some good things but bad things, but I'd say they still have some work to do.What about the IMMENSE number os DLC's? they throw you off from playing this game, they give you a loco on the tutorial that ISN'T EVEN AVAILABLE TO PLAY!, what the heck are you doing people? Still, work to polish your engine, I'm running it on a decent and considered high end machine and it lags, that shouldn't be happening IMO.This is my first review on a game, and it's a negative one. I gave you a chance on this, and I'm not happy with it, you lost a possible client. For everyone else up to buy it, get it on a heavy discount, it's not worth it unless it's 75% off or more, maybe don't even buy it, save for something better

												I have had a love for trains since I was a child and own a few different versions of Train Simulator, along with other train games, but I have to say, I am a bit annoyed at the design of this current game. I am the type of person to explore and then create my own world with these games, but I was a bit shocked at the way the current game operates. The graphics and sound, scenarios, and overall gameplay is fine, but do I need to see advertisements when loading, do I need to have scenarios show up and then tell me to buy them? Sure, its fine to promote DLC, but do it in a sub menu or somewhere else. I feel like I purchased advertisment spam more than a game. Now comes editing. Seriously need to rework the key bindings here and make it a default for zoom to the mouse scroll. Arrow keys vs. the WASD common movement assignments? REALLY! I'm sorry, but honestly I can't see myself enjoying this version over previous ones. I hope my opinion changes as I play, but first impressions leave it a bit low...

2, 2014
												The world’s favorite train simulator eh? I sadly must disagree. I bought this game thinking it would be cool. But apparently, all I purchased was a “demo” with a cool background. Over half the missions require maps that you don’t even have. And these DLC maps aren’t cheap. Each of these DLC maps cost $20+. It’s basically just a demo. You don’t even have half of the necessary content to play this game as if it’s the real thing. I was very disappointed. Once you get in the game, you see a store with a very cool background. So basically all you purchased for $60 is a demo with a few maps and a DLC map store (don’t forget the very cool background), so that you can spend more money. If you really like trains, go ahead and buy some of the DLC. But I recommend staying away from this game. To “upgrade” your game to the full version, you would need to buy all of the DLC to make the game fully functional. This could cost up to $1000. The gameplay is very nice, but there isn’t much to do at all without the DLC. I have some of the DLC content but it doesn’t make much of a difference if you don’t buy all of the necessary DLC. I hope that there are better train simulators, or that this one will make all the DLC free. If the DLC came with the game, this would be a very good train simulator. Until they make it free, I’ll be watching that very cool background.

content:
, 2014
												Giving Train Simulator 2014 the thumbs down is a difficult decision, but I'll explain why I feel I am compelled to do so.I first purchased TS2014 when it was TS2013 / Railworks 3. TS2014 is essentially an updated version of last year's game with a new menu interface and some minor patches. The same routes available prior to the conversion are compatible with the current version.First, I'll evaluate TS2014 as a game. Graphically, it is probably one of the best looking simulators in the genre, and while the visuals are not cutting edge by any sort, they adequately represent the locomotives, rolling stock, and scenery. Some locations and trains are impeccably detailed and create wonderful scenic panoramas; others are nothing special, but still pleasing, while some models and locales are devoid of details, incomplete, or just plain ugly. Some graphical bugs present themselves, usually missing or clipping textures, but this is largely dependent on the route or locomotive. Certain assets are far more polished than others. Sounds are overall nothing spectacular. They work for the most part, and some locomotives are equipped with awesome sound packs, replete with CB radio voiceovers, the hum of the engines, and great horns and bells. Unfortunately, other trains were not given the same treatment, and sounding the horn is an anticlimactic experience when the sound is muffled or lacks an echo, and instead cuts off the second the key is depressed. Much like visual detail, quality varies with sound and is dependent on the developer of a given asset.Gameplay is fairly standard for a train simulator; there are no interesting new features or design quirks, and let's be honest, I didn't expect there to be. The standard by which simulators are judged the most is realism, and by and large TS2014 provides a fairly realistic experience. Steam locomotives, as expected, scale in difficulty compared to their diesel and electric counterparts. You are expected to obey signalling and dispatcher orders and are penalized harshly for failing to heed these warnings. Points are awarded for timeliness and subtracted for recklessness and tardiness. There is enough challenge in most scenarios to keep you on your toes; of course, you can free drive, disable all the realism settings, and run the game like MLG PRO EXTREME TRAINZ SIM 420 and surf on rails if you wish.With all being said, Train Simulator 2014 is a decent game. It looks nice and will engage players who are interested in railroading and simulators in general. However, it is a terrible value, and I hope to illustrate why.In the Standard Edition, which retails for 39.99 USD, you get the game itself plus three routes (the specific routes have changed since when I purchased the game). These routes range anywhere from a few dozen km (15-20 miles or so) to 300+ km (180+ miles) and provide usually no more than 3 trainsets (some are generous enough to give you 4 or 5) along with anywhere from 5 to 12 scenarios, on average. You're paying a bit over 13 dollars per route in addition to the base game. Fair enough. Where Dovetail Games (formerly RailSimulator.com Ltd.) will suck you dry is through the numerous DLC available for the game, and I would consider Dovetail one of the, if not the absolute worst offenders on Steam in the practice of pumping out overpriced and underwhelming DLC.Consider that the typical price of a new route add-on is 39.99 USD. I bought the base game and three routes for that same price. What justifies a ludicrous markup of over 200% on additional routes, when some are smaller or less detailed than those included with the game? Moving on to locomotives, you can purchase the Amtrak California Zephyr F40PH (a common diesel found on North American railroads) for 19.99. It comes with one livery and a few missions for a DLC that, thankfully, is now included in the base game, but at one time was a separate purchase. Even more pathetic is the attempt to sell the BR Class J74 tank engine for 7.99 with a few scenarios. But the most egregious example of how bad TS2014's DLCs can get is the listing on Railsimulator.com for a silver livery for the PRR GG1 locomotive for 4.99. Yes, for 5 dollars, you can be the proud owner of one skin. Locomotive not included. This is absurd.I understand that a lot of content in this game is developed by third parties, and that they need to be paid for their hard work. Yet the price gouging set in place by Dovetail can hardly be justified, especially when the developer's quality control team has a history of overlooking minor and not-so-minor bugs in the DLC they allow to be published, resulting in a wide variation in the quality of the addons. Do they want their game to have a reputation for uncertainty? The exhorbitant prices combined with the developer's curt attitude to criticism by the fanbase drives potential players away and hurts the rating of what otherwise is a decent simulation. The Steam Workshop and the intensely devoted railfan community have the potential to improve this game by leaps and bounds if the developers understood that mod friendliness and accessibility can only help their product.If you are a railfan and value your money, just go and build a model railway. You will meet more people, gain more useful skills, and enjoy the experience much more than if you buy this game and the accompanying DLC. After all, the cost of all the DLC combined could finance a fairly large-sized model railroad. Besides, you will have more creativity at your hands and create more lifelong memories with that than by investing that money into Train Simulator 2014.

content:
y 12, 2014
												Few games manage to get worse when the developer continues to work on them. But this is one of them.For whatever reason, the developers of Railworks Train Simulator changes things that doesn't need changing, adds things that doesn't need to be added, and yet, doesn't fix what needs to be fixed.In my opinion, this game is not worth buying. When i first got onto this game, it was the 2012 edition, with the 2013 edition being better in a few ways, but this 2014 edition is awful. There is a career system with icons and graphics that look like they were quickly made in MS-Paint, nothing has improved as far as i can tell, and old routers/scenarios are still bugged. For the casual player who wants to have fun driving a train, i honestly wouldn't recommend this at all. It's frustrating trying to get a good score, when suddenly with no warning the speed limit changes, which seems to happen on alot of routes. Saving and returning to the game isn't fun when the load times are this long.And for whatever reason; i have performance problems. My game runs on a AMD Radeon 7970 GHz edition, FX-6300 OC'd, and is on a Corsair SSD, but, when i drive a train at a high speed the map sort of loads in "chunks", meaning every 20 secounds there's a slowdown in FPS. What the hell?!Every now and then i fire up this game, feeling like driving a train, enjoying the view (which the new limited camera view has ruined, but whatever). However, i am met with bugs, anger, and frustration. This could have been a great, realistic game, with the look and feel of the real thing, but the graphics havn't gotten much better since the 2012 edition, the only additions has been casual features such as controller support and career-mode. The terrain feels dead and people still look ugly. i do not regret the day i purchased this game, however, i do regret having ever purchased any dlc once this game hit 2013 edition. It is a giant, giant mess of a game, with so much DLC it has gotten out of control, not because there's too much to chose from, but because none of it gets fixed.

number of helpful: 102 of 177 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
y 16, 2014
												If you want laser-cannon firing trains that shoot out spikes to kill aliens, then don't bother. But if you want a game that is strangely absorbing and relaxing at the same time, requiring almost no skill to enjoy but weeks of practice to really be an expert, TS ticks all the boxes. I can see why the shoot-em-up fans don't 'get' this game, but I really do. You struggle to get up a hill with a thousand tons of freight behind you, then worry about running away down the other side. Or you have to pick up on time at every station, stopping literally within a couple of feet of the marker on the platform. Or drive along a country route enjoying the scenery and watching out for interesting trains coming the other way.It's pretty much the only Steam game I play, it's got so much extendability - driving a freight train in the snow is VERY different to driving the same tracks with an express train at night in the rain. It not only makes me respect train engineers/drivers much more, it provides me with a lot of pretty harmless fun. Oh, and unlike so many games, it's one that I'm perfectly happy to let my son play. He is SO impatient but he is quite happy to take a two-hour trip on TS.Highly recommended (unless you think GTA V is the bestest experience of your life, in which case probably not).

content:
er 1, 2014
												Updated 26 Feb 15 following comment and release of the Isle of Wight fixes.You might think it would be fun, or at least different, to be able to drive a steam train, or indeed any train through rolling countryside, perhaps relaxing and a change from killing stuff. If so please look elsewhere.The idea is good and I know simulations are not for everyone but the implementation is dire. There are repeated bugs and crashes and every update seems to introduce new problems without fixing the old ones. There are 2 sides to this game. Driving stuff and building stuff in the editor. Driving first.Having never driven a train I cannot say if the simulation side is accurate, what I can say is that the missions and game play can be frustrating. You get a handful of trains and routes from the outset and can purchase any number of additional DLC from Dovetail (or whatever they are calling themselves now) and 3rd party devs. There are missions where you have to take a train from one place to another in a tight time-table without speeding, falling of the tracks,crashing or going through a red signal which is harder than it sounds. Trains do not stop quickly, or like rain, hills etc so running on time is tough and it is very easy to miss a speed restriction resulting in a failure (or no awarded points). Missions can last over a hour and you will loose if you go through a red signal, or make a serious mistake,. There is a quick save (press F2 - thanks paned) but to reload you have to quit the mission and then reload from the mission select screen. Some of these routes are very long and take quite a time to load. You only get one save slot per mission and so even doing a reload may not save you if you are about to pass a red signal. Get it right and there is a sense of achievement ( or relief ) but the bugs just get in the way. There are other computer controlled trains on the line and you can be perfectly on time, top scoring only to have one of these crash miles away from you for the mission to fail. You did nothing wrong, the game bugged. remember how long some of those missions are? Imagine that happening 45 mins into one. It will.You might like to purchase some of the nice shiny DLC, in a word don't. There is zero, zilch, nada, zip, guarantee that an update won't break it without warning, and never be fixed. When I first wrote this review in Dec 2014 the Isle of Wight career scenarios were totally bugged and would not load and had not since the 2014 update. Well at this has at last been sorted along with over 100 other bugs and glitches for one, rather old, route. OK congrats for at last sorting the problems devs, but you have released countless new bits of DLC in the meantime many of which have their own bugs. One of my 3rd party routes (can't remember which) has you so that you are embedded in the roof of the train cab making driving 'interesting'. That broke in 2012. Since the original review I have found that some of the wooden post semaphore signals from the UK set have the signal arm at the bottom of the post (so embedded inm the ground), rather than where it should be at the top. I have no idea how long these have been broken, but given the devs priories (new DLC, new DLC etc) don't expect these to be fixed soon if ever.BuildingHanker after your old train set, want to build a virtual one? Look elsewhere or the bugs and frustration will get you here as well.The editor is complicated, and you have to do a lot of background reading before you start. Signals are complex things and getting them wrong with cause you no end of problems. This would not be a problem if editor loaded and didn't crash, and allowed you to move a track without sicking buffers all the way along it and has a sane way to build tunnels and didn't crash if you raised a track for a hill and... In short it's bugged as well. As for the documentation welll....To sum up its a nice idea ruined. The graphics are nice (and bugged - check fully leaved trees that cast the shadows of bare branches, solid walls that have light flooding under their bases etc), and it could be a relaxing way to spend a few hours.If it worked.

content:
r 13, 2014
												EDIT: The fact the Dovetail Games does not really have much competition in the train sim genre kind of begs the questions why sell the DLC as these ridiculous prices, let me tell you why, there numbers are dropping and they struggle to maintain healthy continous playing users, lets looks at another game like Euro Truck Simulator 2, they have DLC not many but they have some and are all ridiculously cheap and they even give players free noticeble game changing updates, Dovetail Games doesn't, SCS have one thing that Dovetail Games doesn't a strong continuous player base that play most of the time, look at the numbers for yourself on the steam stats they are one of the top 10 games that get played daily, train sim doesn't have that player capture towards a game that Euro Truck is, and this is why Dovetail games struggle and force the high DLC prices just to stay alive, they are expanding there company having over 100 employees that very difficult to maintain if the numbers are not showing and now they have DTG Fishing and FSX under their belt. This is why Ladies and Gentlemen Dovetail Games have these high DLC prices and this why the game haven't significantly changed from day 1 all those years back, DTG have grown to comfortable with this routine of pumping out medicore DLC at these high prices as its the only thing they can do to just keep them in busniess, if they had more players playing the game daily like Euro Truck has DLC wouldn't be that expensive. DTG need to get the next train sim right, they need to listen to the players for once (not saying they dont) but the whole model of the game needs to change from where it is now! Well time for me to contribute my review for Train Simulator as a whole franchise.First even though I do recommend the game it isn't the perfect simulator everyone expects however.Lets go over the positives about this game to not sound to anti Train Sim:PROS:- This game overall is very good and solid for a Train Simulator; it does all the basics you would want from a simulator; get in train different trains on different routes (all covered)- Graphics are genrally pretty good (but I will elobrate a bit more in the cons)- It is now a very user friendly game and new comers will find it extremely easy and fullfilling to get into the game and start driving- The Steam workshop intergration is one of my biggest pros for this game (it in some ways saved the game from being forgotten about) you have access to free community made scenarios which are far better then ones Dovetail Gmaes try and make with each DLC route, there is always someone you can find on the steam workshop- It is sort of immersive I guess....- For the DLC collection they have to offer it isn't that bad but more can be done (I will talk about pricing in the cons)and well.... thats all I can really think of for the pros currently, it a solid simulation that is great for new players to get into ... But I am not a new player so for long lasting players maybe some of the pros I mentioned are relateble.Now the CONS (sit tight)- DLC pricing.... This is a whole topic for itself: Since the beginning of Train Simulator DLC weren't the cheapest but were reasonable, in the present day I personally think DLC is way overpriced for what you do get. The standard game has also increased so more money to spend if you are getting into Train Sim. Dovetail games has increased as a company and has a much larger player base then it once had, I do not understand why that should mean to increase DLC price it is obsurd! A route generally costs £25 with any additional trains (that they do not bother to add with the standard route) adding on another £11 to £15.............. this is just way too much money to keep investing into, the most smartest/desperat time for players to get DLC is during steam sales (imagine if they didn't exist?) - DLC Routes & Trains: Adding on from the pricing point of view.... Routes and train have come a long way through the history in Train Simulator no one can deny that detail has gotten better over the years. But I do not think it is good enough, routes to me do not feel very unique most assests are copied over from other routes e.g. most station exteriors and interiors are just plain simple and copied, they only add sometimes big nice fancy details to show of a particular place in one area of the route. Trains are even more disgusting to think about sure again things have improved but not enough (WHY DO WE HAVE 3RD PARTY WEBSITES like Armstong Powerhouse [which they do a fabulous job] having to step in to fill the gaps dovetail games miss out?) The Class 321 is probabaly the best exmaple of this the one dovetail game released was a total shambles, and then AP released their version with better visuals and sound (especially), it makes you wonder why can't dovetail games include these more improved features? We pay large prices for them? And then you have AP who does a better job for the fraction of the price...... - GRAPHICS ENGINE: Ok this is proabably my most passionate point and I know that TS 2016 is the year where an upgrade to Unreal Engine 4 is due but let me elaborate my concerns for the past few years with this current engine we have! The graphics engine is just too old now. This game have been out for 6+ years and we have been faced with the same PhysX engine and frankly its showing it age! When I said the game is quite detailed I ment only to a point, of course is massively better then an 8-bit game but in the present day with many advancing graphic engines and great game looking games being produced you would think something like a simulation game as one as popular as Train Simulator can have the same treatment. The current engine prevents dovetail games from making far larger maps (which is something many complain about), high 0fidelity of textures is something that cannot be achieved in the current engine; certain assets and textures currently look so terrible and can be compared to a game of ten years ago, Dovetail games only focus on certains things to catch your eye from the reality of the surrounding game! MULTIPLAYER: This actually links to the graphics engine issue, the current engine apparently wouldn't be able to handle lets say "a open world multiplayer" which I think is so needed in a popular simulator like Train Sim (I have talked in my youtube video about the lack of connecting the community and friends together with this game, it discourages a connection between player and the achievement system in the game now is just such a bad attempt of dong something to make it look like your friends are involved with your gaming experience. Any the whole multiplayer issue is much deeper than this so I won't carry out but you get the point.ANNIMATIONS: Again to the with the engine, dovetail games promised better passenger animations in TS 2015 but I think thats a total lie, nothing has really changed and they kind of lied when they released a post about the new features only turning out to only be implemented with the 3 routes thats come with TS 2015, so thats a bit cruel. Many bugs and glitches are still present within the game and its quite shocking that they haven't fixed them for how long the game has been out.That raps up my opinions of TS as a whole, I will edited this review if anything else come to mind.I do recommend this game if you are someone new and wants to get into a Train Sim but beware of the over priced DLC's you will get into (wait for sales if you are tight with money), and people like me who are long serving players and who want change within game franchise we shall wait till next year for TS 2016 where will see the pinicle moment for TS if dovetail games bring it to the table of completely collapse on their face. (DLC for nexts years game is also something very controversial....)Thanks for reading my review! I am QwertyAfro (Sam) I bid you good day!

content:
er 28, 2013
												Visually this is a great game.  For me, that's about where the positives ended.  I like a variety of games and don't need constant action but this was tedious.  I especially enjoyed when I arrive at stations and had to sit and wait for 3-5 minutes (real time) to elapse to leave the station on time.  The controls for the trains I have require me to have to either constantly hold the throttle or keep losing speed then have to shift back down to not lose points for speeding.  I guess the people who made the real trains these are modeled after never found a way to have linear controls that would stay in place so instead you have 25, 50,75 and 100% power or you hold the throttle in place at a mid point for 3-10 minutes as you travel.  Don't read the speed limit signs or follow their map or you will lose points for speeding when you hit the occasional bug in the game where the programing doesn't match the visual cues.  I can't bring myself to do a single scenario that will take 3-4 hours.To buy all the DLC for this game when it is all on sale gave a price of over $1,500, I think this may be the most expensive game in existance.

												A few versions ago I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this game, but Railsimulator.com have taken their position for granted and have become sloppy. Railsimulator.com are currently more interested in bending you over for the DLC rather than fixing the core game. Until they wise up I can't currently recommend this game to interested parties.

content:
y 6, 2014
												Its a quite fun game if you dont feel like doing anything but there are simply not enough routes incuded with the standard package (which I bought) or with the Steam edition. For this reason (and the ones stated below) I can't reccomend the game. If you really want to buy the game, wait till its on sale. Plus the over £2,000 of DLC is just insane.There are many reviews saying that the game has bugs, and it has many of them; engine + break sounds on DB Ice train sound seriously unrealistic (they're not smooth, they go in incriments), the Hamburg to Hannover route ends abruptly, the thing that shows if you're going to tip goes from middle to side really fast if you go past the orange zone and the people walk  incrediby unrealistically, or are just seriously hungover and have serious knee problems.td;lr of below: This game doesnt feel like a simulator or like you're driving a heavy train, is missing tons of features, is really buggy and feels more like an arcade game.There are many other problems such as not most of the inside of the train isnt controllable which dissapoints me (I like pressing random buttons and watching the warning screens go mental), the route builder is just unintuitive, menu's are complicated, there is no loading menu procentage (however this is minor compared to the rest of the problems), no weather effects when out of cabin view, train textures go really bad once you go out of the cabin view, animation glitches (one of them is the blinds on the DB train merge through the roof) and world textures sometimes are awkward because they dont graduate from other ones.I also feel that the physics engine is not there, the speed settings seem to have max speeds they can go (no engine torque simulation from my experience), the derailment looks awkward. It quite simply doesnt feel like you're driving a heavy train (brakes are instant and its really quick to throttle up).The point system is a good idea but too mean (I mean, speeds randomly changing from 60>40>60 and you're getting penalised for the sudden, unshown change) and the drive quality penalty makes no sense as it doesnt feel like you're going too harshly around the corners.The world doesnt seem too real either; the sounds are off. When I'm in a city I expect to hear cars, when I'm in the countryside I expect to hear birds and wind blowing and its just not there. On the subject of weather, the droplets (even though done nicely with the dropping animation) are square and seem to ignore wind and the "smearing" effect of the wind and nothing looks wet.Overall out of the 14h played it was fun to the extent of pressing the A and D keys and occasionally the Q key when the British highspeed train (class 395) starts beeping like something's about to blow up. If you're looking for a game which feels "arcadey" and not doing much this is the game for you.Edit 1: Corrected some grammar/spelling errors.

content:
ber 10, 2015
												Train Simulator offers realism, but often without showing you what you need to do, making scenarios a vague case of trial and error even after having completed every training scenario. So many times I've bumped into a "mistake" that undid 15 minutes or more gameplay. Even a successfully completed scenario can result as unsuccessful. Where gameplay should be intuitive and rewarding after 4 hours, by poor design the experience leaves you in the dark and frustrated even 8 hours in. While I have enjoyed this sometimes relaxing game, it's too rough around the edges to be consistently enjoyable enough for me to be happy with it overall. The learning curve isn't worth the needlessly difficult climb to figure out what you need to do unaided, just so you can sit at a station for several minutes waiting for a red light to turn green and wonder what the next problem will be. The trains are cool and seem accurate, but the gameplay has room for improvement.

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2013
												It's kind of a love-hate-relationship. On the one hand it very likely is the worst simulator in history and not a good game either. It suffers from lots of bugs - huge ones in a simulator like wrong acceleration values of a simulated train resulting in rocket train behaviour or plain wrong diesel tank volume because the devs messed up the liters-gallons-conversion to smaller ones like switches being flipped upside down etc - and super low quality assets like textures with a 90s look an resoution and bad modelling like a round switch not beeing round but an octagon. Also the developer rarely EVER updates the simulated stock so when a DLC has a bug it will stay that way. Another HUGE issue is the sound department as most sound assets are laughably bad. Like heavy freight wagons often having no sound at all. Seeing them glide by like hover cars will make you cry and laugh at the same time.On the other hand DLC from thrid parties (like Reppos GP20, like the Constallation from Smokebox, like the Class 90 from Armstrong Powerhouse, ...) is brilliant with proper sound, proper realism and proper attention to detail and good quality assets. Driving one of those on a nice route (Stevens Pass for example) that is a labor of love from a third party developer and not the usual rushed and buggy junk is incredibly fun.Overall I cannot reccomend this game. While there are combinations that shine (Smokebox Constellation over Marias Pass or Class 90 along the West Coast Main Line from Keith Ross or the Meshtools Jinty on the Western Lines of Scotland), the majority of content ist ... sadly though ... junk. Badly buggy with worse sound and low quality textures and modelling. While you will get a nice collection of worthy content you will also collect a huge amount of content straight of RSCs trashbin.And it's not even about the price of DLC as ther is quite some DLC that is worth the full price like the already mentioned stuff and other 3rd party content. It's the attitude with which RSC treats you and this sim. They don't give a damn, they release buggy DLC over and over and over again. They are not interested in improving. They are not listening or updating their own stuff, they just want to sell you new stuff.While the core might be a nice but badly aging platform for third party developers that actually care, the affiliation with the main developer RSC poisons this whole sim. So one can only reccomend to stay far far away.

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
er 20, 2013
PROS:- Convincing simulation: In cab controls (lots of dials/switches/buttons), conducting each train feels different and unique enough to be a new experience- Built-in scenario/map creator- Difficulty scalable from practical free roam to very strict failure- Trains are modeled nicely, pretty to look at- Variety of camera controls- Tutorials (can even learn a lot about how trains function IRL)- Tons of DLC to add variety (this is a PRO assuming that money is not an obstacle)CONS:- Base game feels bare and stripped of content, DLC almost required to keep interest- Sound is unpolished/unfinished: trains virtually silent, very little ambient/cabin sound (no immersion via audio at all)- Graphics specifically pertaining to scenery are awful (trains look great, but you're going to spend hours staring at fugly low quality scenery)- Performance: even on a high end machine, you can count on regular FPS drops and chattering of all sorts- Game play (almost by nature) is very repetitive, with long periods of do-nothing.  After ~20 hours, I'm done with it.- Technical difficulty galore... occasionally patches will break the game and leave it unplayable for months on end.- Very little to no developer/community relationship and communicationGOOD BUY?I regret buying this game even at the sale price at the time.  If you absolutely love trains, I would still wait for a deep deep sale.RECOMMENDATION SUMMARYI can't recommend because the cons outweigh the pros by a fairly large margin.  The core of the game is great fun, but where the idea is nice, the execution and details completely fall through.  Adding salt to the wound:  terrible community relations, technical support (most of my emails/tweets/communication went completely unanswered - still have pending support request unresolved from a half year ago).  Even though the game has its fun moments, it's fraught with holes, and is not good value.

content:
er 5, 2013
												First off, I really enjoy the game. The game itself is enjoyable, controlling the speeds, directions, hooking up cars, switching tracks, etc. It really is enjoyable. I bought the Holiday Express pack during the sale for only $3.00. Well worth three dollars. I'm glad I didn't pay the full twenty. There were only a handful of scenarios which took no time to complete. Plus, being the Holiday pack, I only got the Holiday train, despite Steam now insisting I own the full version. Here's the first problem.To have anything else to do, I have to be willing to spend $20 to $30 to unlock more trains and locations. If they are as basic as the Holiday set, total ripoff. And since the total to purchase all of the DLC is over $3000, I can pretty much guess the small amount of content in each pack. Shame too.If this game would include a more broad scope and not be so limiting in the initial purchase, I could see playing this for quite some time. Unfortunately, there really isn't enough to do. And if you are thinking "Workshop mods", forget it. Most of them require a DLC pack of some sort, especially seeing as how I somehow don't have access to the default sets, despite Steam's insistance that I own the base game. EDIT: I was able to acquire the full version from a 3rd party for only $20. It added a few more engines and three routes. While fun, the only real claim to any sort of "time investment" is that each of the scenarios take anywhere between 45 minutes to over two hours to complete. There still really isn't a whole lot of diversity without paying for each individual DLC. It came with an 80% coupon for a select number of DLC, so I will probably pick one to buy for only a few dollars.. Beyond that, I can't ever see justifying the asking price of the DLC.

number of helpful: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2014
												I really wanted to like this "simulator" especially since I had invested so much money in the previous versions. But since the update to Train Simulator 2013 and now TS - 2014, the playstyle has been dumbed down to a point where I feel using the word "simulator" in the same paragraph should be considered a felony! The physics would be comical if the title didn't try to present itself as being "realistic." Unfortunately I find myself describing them as "WTF?" A single sd40-2 puling a 70 car coal drag up a 5% grade at 40mph with no hesitation or stalling? While at the same time a 4-8-8-4 Big Boy struggles with 40 boxcars on level terrain? Riiiiggghhhtt!!! The sounds for most locomotives, expecially North American models are completely inaccurate, although this may be nitpicking considering there are way worse problems such as over-simplified train controls and buggy scenarios. Long heavy freight trains are also ridiculously quiet, not the thundering beasts that we generally associate them to be. Developer attention was spent on rain and snow effects on the windshields and making the cab rock back and forth instead of making sure it behaved and operated like, you know, a TRAIN!! The one thing this "simulator" does do right is graphics. For the most part it is very visually appealing and overall a "pretty" game. But for people looking for a serious railroad "simulator" consider looking elswhere. (Run 8) This title is for those who want their railroading simulation spoon-fed to them!

4, 2016
												Admittedly, the huge amount of paid dlc put me off at first. And this game really is just about driving trains, performing some tasks and not messing up. I do however like trains, and so far I've enjoyed myself learning to drive them. The dlc is something I choose to see as collecting a model train set. In that sense, comparing it to dlc of an average game where more gives you often a fuller experience, does not work.If you are considering this game you likely are looking to just experience driving trains, drive through some nice scenery, enjoy controlling something that requires some proper timing. This game offers that properly in my opinion.Moreso than with other games your purchase will depend on how you regard the pricing scheme. You will likely want some new routes or trains to play with after a while. Do you consider the large offering of paid routes and trains as essentials that should have been (much) cheaper? Then perhaps better stay away. Do you consider this a hobby that will likely require or at least warrent future investments (which you can afford and feel reasonable enough, possibly during sales), then this is indeed a good simulator of what it claims to be in my opinion.
