content:
30, 2014
												RSC now DTG their product TS2014 , while looking slick with nice Hd graphic's & other tricks, this product is not a Simulation.The history of this game date's all the way back to Microsoft Train Simulator & Kuju Entertainment, when MS dropped the project Kuju Entertainment returned with the simulation Called Rail works 1 & 2 .At this point RSC brought the game rights from Kuju Entertainment & took over the project re-naming it Train Simulator they also carried over all the bugs effecting the Sim too.The product moved onto the Steam platform to make it much simpler to update the game year in year out, so TS2012/13/& 14 are just evolutions & not a new product,Many of the same bugs have been carried over with each update, also each update had led a  nightmare of broken add-on's that have stopped working of simply fail to show up in the menu both from 3rd parties & DTG DLC too.Most of the update have seen the the game go from been a more Sim based product to a arcade feel game.Add to that the fact that DTG Support as a well documented history of been poor at best, there forums are not much better.There is also the endless stream of what would call over price DLC most of which just add's to the list of errors & bug's already effecting the gameI would steer clear of this product If you are looking for a real Train Simulation & not just a over priced digital Train set at best.If you are into simultions you will be let down by this one for sure.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
												The only remotely "good" things are the graphics and sounds, nothing else including game play, physics, editor and AI makes up for this.It's all a "cash Cow" Scheme to catch the gullible people out.The entire time I spent my 45 hours on, was just driving missions on my favourite route, once they were done with there was nothing left to do, so I left for its cousin, Open Rails.This was the biggest waste of money I have ever had to deal with.Oh yeah, did I forget to mention, the graphics are all to do with the model's detail and the quality of the sound recordings of real trains and thus, should NOT be associated with the actual game.The editor is clunky and it's really hard to make any decent railway layout with it since the limitations are so strict (curve radii limitations) and with no tutorials to back it up (other then ones on obscure websites), it makes it hard to come to terms with the environment, when there's no ability to import DEM (Digitally Elevated Maps) or grey scale height maps (surely they would be important enough to be able to import, so you wouldn't be wasting your time creating custom landscapes using tools which should be only used for polishing off the finished map).In terms of AI, it seems very, very limited, even in terms of trainz 2006's capabilities.In trainz railway simulator 2006, you could use triggers and rules to append orders onto trains / trigger events and all of that lovely stuff to create more in-depth game play, whereas in rail works, it's purely an A-B method, there's no dynamics in the orders what so ever which could give real potential to how AI could be used like in trainz railway simulator 2006. (yes, I just did compare a game created in 2014 with a game created 8 years ago, although, technically, it got implemented in TRS2004, passenger service pack).The passenger movements are all nice, but it's not that big of a deal, compared to what I've listed here, which would be core game elements.Derailing within tunnels... Yeah, your train gets thrusted upwards... Great job at making trains fly.Payware content, there simply is too much of it, I mean $2K on steam, it seems a little excessive.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
r 4, 2016
												This game is great when you spend a fortune of money for all the DLC. But come on, this game looks unfinished.PROS:Graphics Quality: Stunning, better than other train simulators I came across.Amount of DLC: There is a lot to complete your collection, but there are gripes with this (see below), but overall there is a variety.Workshop: The Community pays so much attention into detail in their scenarios, some of them even replicate a real life service.CONS:DLC Prices: Probably my biggest gripe out of everything. Seriously, we have to pay £1000+ to get all routes and trains. Well a lot of the routes are good, but it comes to the trains. The recycled sounds, train physics. The DLC contains little effort for such a high price.DLC Layout: You get less than 1/4 of the DLC when you buy the base game which means you have to spend a fortune for all DLC. All other games I played have their DLC in a bundle (Yes I know some DLC is bundled, I mean like there should be bundles for parts of countries (London and South East England, South West England, Anglia, Midlands etc.) Settings Control: You can't tune settings whilst in a scenario which means you have to exit the scenario to change settings. Come on, no other game has this.Bugs: Some of the older routes have bugs that have persisted into present time and have never been fixed.Simulation Accuracy: The train physics aren't very realistic, to slow/fast breaking and slow/fast acceleration, the class 466 included in the Sheerness Branch Extension route is the worst of all. Come on, stop rushing on your DLC and take your time to get the simulation accuracy excellent, in which I have to say, third-party developer Waggonz is the best of all. Also a lot of the trains don't have functioning destination displays (unless you go into Scenario Editor and change the destiination) and fully functioning headlights (You only get Day Head/Marker Lights and Tail Lights) and I know DTG have recently started this.Train Sounds: A lot of the sounds of the trains are recycled from other trains and don't sound like the real thing. Please take the time to perform a recording session so you can record the exact sounds just like what Armstrong Powerhouse is doing.OVERALL: A fairly good game, if only DTG wouldn't price so much for literally low-quality DLC and actually make it a proper, realistic simulator rather than do things enough to get a train moving.Do I recommend it?: Only in a sale of at least 40% off.Rating: 6/10

content:
y 20, 2016
												First of all, please note I would only recommend to an avid train enthusiast but not to an individual that knows nothing about trains. The base game itself is quite positive for those looking to have a realistic driving experience (3rd or 1st person), but the reason i advise non-train buffs to not purchase it is because of the amount of facts and figures you will come across and the fact that if you are not into it, then the DLCs are useless. The total DLC cost is well over a £3000 which makes it an incredibly over-priced game for what it is; a simulator. For £3000 you could buy a real train. Although, being an enthusiast myself, it is excellent to have a wide range of locomotives, routes and skin packs to be able to customize your fleet. A real con is where they sell you a train for £11.99 and call it new even though it has only been re-skined. Of course you do not have to buy every single DLC, but for instance I have spent over £150 on DLCs alone, way too much for a simulator. A good feature of this game is the create your own route feature. This is very complex but once you have learnt the basics, an excellent way to plan out a model railway. There are also modes such as free-roam (self-explanatory), scenario based, career scenario based and quick drive. Quick drive was added in quite a recent update and is one of my preferred modes; you are able to select any locomotive on any route, setting the time and day etc... Comparibly the scenarioes are excellent and with the addition of the workshop are seemingly endless. Overall, not a great game but don't allow the 200 and something hours tell you otherwise; please note, this was a big waste of my life and I do not want it to be yours. This game (even though I stated it was good for enthusiasts etc...) makes dept a real issue and if you're stupid enough to add all of the DLCs to the cart then you might as well get another bank account. I may play it an awful lot, but honestly the outdated graphics may be the best for a train simulator, but the development company to take over this game hasn't evolved since the 1998. The trains do look excellent, but the AI are all the same in effect only retextured to the time period or the characters gender. I'd say a 4/10 would be being pleasant to the developers but it isn't a good choice for Christmas. I would plead you not to purchase an absorbing 2009/10 based sim that hasn't been updated (as in the bugs fixed or graphice improved) since its release.

												Ok, just don't buy this game. It sucks on every aspect. It's not worth your time. You'll be judged by everyone. It's horrible, I run this game at 20 fps with all graphics turned up with a dual gtx 780i... If you can see this, leave this page and never come back!Out of the 10 hours I have played the game, I simply cannot find ANYTHING that is beneficial. Dovetail got everything wrong... here's a few I saw:GRAPHICS: The graphics engine sucks, I have a high-end gaming PC, with 2 GPU's, and I can't get over 60 fps, I swear... I don't know if it's me, because I cannot find a solution on the internet. Also, I have noticed countless bugs, the background and the environment look ugly, and there is barely any effort in any of the level design, it's plain,  and boring .PEOPLE: The Ai for the people is worse. Way worse. People in the game FADE in an out of the trains, they don't bother to walk in and out, they go through walls, walk off platforms, and some of the models (including the driver) give me nightmares. They are creepy as f***SUPPORT: The support for the game is bad enough, the facebook page is spammed with it, and according to the comments, they have had to remove and download the 6 GB of space this game takes up, and nothing works for most people. I have had countless crashes when launching, nothing worked, but 2 weeks ago it started randomly working again, and i don't think there was any kind of patch. I also had a review before this, and the delevopers replied:"To clarify the features of TS2015:-Amazing trains and locations to drive-A stunning carrer mode-An easy-to-use development kit"This, I can say is bull. You have barely any trains and locations at the start, the carrer mode is boring, and I dont know how to operate the flipping DK! And I'm a 3-D modeller!!THE DLC, OMG THE DLC: When you spend $40 on a game, surely you should get everything the game offers you? Nope. This game gives you 6 trains and 3 lines off the bat... WITH DLC ABOUT $20 EACH!!![/b] Appauling. If you want everything, you'll have to spend about $20,000 for the lot... Noteven worth it if you are a quarillionaire, since none of them even work... This is the worst part about it.[/list]In Short...Get off this page, don't even think about buying it... I'm saving you money... Be Grateful!!

content:
ber 17, 2015
												I have owned this game on Steam for about four years, I think.  Been awhile anyway.  I have enjoyed it, although every year when they update, the experience has tended to deteriorate as apparent inefficiencies and bugs are introduced.   It's fun if you enjoy train simulators and is probably the best on the market from that perspective.  Yes, there is a lot of DLC, and yes getting it all would cost a small fortune.  This really hasn't affected me a great deal since it is still far cheaper than the model trains and accessories I collect.  There is absolutel no requirement to buy any DLC to enjoy the game as intended.  DLC is just an expansion, much like a new set of tracks and models is an expansion to a model rail display.That said, I do not recommend this game to new players.  As noted, its quality is getting worse.  Support is essentially non-existent.  The community can be toxic.  It's not fun anymore.With the release of 2016, I can no longer play any part of the game except the part where you fill out a marketing survey.  Every route is a blackscreen, and the game eventually gives up and crashes.  I am too tired to fight a battle with ignorant techs and seemingly intentionally unhelpful support people so I can do something I should find relaxing.   That's not relaxing; it's infurating, and I am done.So, uninstall it is, and I'll consider my experiences an expensive lesson in how not to carry on your train hobby once your model set has become too large for your living space.

content:
er 22, 2013
												Train Simulator places itself in a very strange middle ground between game and simulator, and it doesn't seem to come close enough to being either one to please very many people. The user interface is very simple and easy to use, but lacks quite a few details that would make the experience more capable and realistic, in other words closer to the "simulator" that it's claiming to be. In-cabin interaction is kept to a bare minimum with many dials, levers and buttons except only the most critical locked away as background decoration.Games are long, but that's to be expected with any simulator. Most casual players will quickly find themselves getting bored however, since the driver's usual job is essentially just a speed regulator. If you can be entertained enough by the sound and look of your engine as it cruises down the track for an hour or so, then you're golden.I've been debating with myself whether or not to bring up the downloadable content, since it's something that's always brought up in other reviews, but I guess I might as well while I'm here.The average price for a new locomotive is $20 USD without sale. It's a famously bad deal and one that's never been addressed or remedied by Dovetail. They only feature so many engines in the game itself because they expect people to pay for their ludacrisly overpriced DLC to compensate. Because of this association, I believe that it comes as a detriment to the game itself.Rail fans and sim fans alike deserve better than what they were given. As someone who's both, I'm disappointed to say the very least.

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 2, 2016
												I once wrote a positive review then I realized that this game is a scam. Why? Because the developers are lack of every aspects of striving for good, because Dovetail probably has no quality management and it's marketing department are made of greedy liars. Let's cut to the chase...+ Oh, there is a train simulator out there and it looks beautiful- The game itself isn't optimized a bit. Don't tell me, that this outdated graphic and simulation has so much appetite, that a GTX 750 VGA, a Phenom X2 CPU and 8Gbyte RAM is not enough! On bigger railway stations even with this configuration the FPS drops measurably. To be honest the FPS drops without any input even on high-end desktops and it is probably because of the sloppy programming and the lack of testing and quality inspections. Did I mention loading time? Oh, you can have a dinner but if you are a smoker, one slim cigarette is guarenteed even with the recommended system specs.- The simulation could be fun until you realize that most of the locos are lack many of the essential controls and most of the switches, buttons are inactive textures serves only for design purposes. Don't tell me that a simple loco has only brakes and throttle, pantograph and headlight switches! - In many cases the HUD's speed limit signs are not in syncron with the actual railroad tracks vica versa. I don't really use the HUD because it's buggy but if you are driving in career mode with enabled scoring system you are f**ed up, because the game sometimes follows the HUD's speed limitation not the actual railroad signs and again vica versa. - In most cases PZB is bugged too. PZB (german train control system) is quite hard to master and this game makes it even harder. And by the way sometimes Sifa doesn't work either.- There are mostly only german, us and british routes available, and it is getting boring. Especially the US routes, those locos are totally inactive ones.- The greed of the company is unmatched in the game industry. They overprice their DLCs and lie about the features and developements. The whole company is based on low-down marketing. They even delete negative comments from their community forums. What they did with the release of the 2016 edition is the most shameful episode in the history of gaming. They even made a 20 minute youtube video about a new menu which basically is a re-colored one. What an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, really! :-DYou shouldn't buy this game unless you are a railfan! Despite all the negatives it can give you some pleasant time but it's absolutely overpriced and doesn't worth even 10 euros.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
23, 2014
												Lets clear the air right now. I dont like a simulator that is so real it feals like work when you use it. Also I am not now nor have I ever worked on a railroad. I enjoy ts because its just real enough for you to get an idea about how trains work but not so real you could go out, hop in a train and drive it away. The realism level of this program is on the same level of farming simulator. If you are Mr. Ultrarealsimulation Do NOT get this. You will be disappointed. If you are a railfan who enjoys casual train operation you will probably enjoy this. With that said, if you are the casual railfan, The DLC is mind blowingly expensive. You cannot even begin to comprehend how much money you could spend purchasing enough DLC to make this more enjoyable. If you think you  will get the vanilla version and call it good, you are mistaken. The standard version comes with three routes and only a handful of locomotives and no steam engines at all. If you want any more routes or locomotives get your wallet out and dont bother putting it away. Even if you want any of the free crap avaliable at the steam marketplace you will first need to have the necessary DLC and that will cost you dearly. If you are new to the franchise, there is a pretty steep learning curve. It doesnt help that the ingame tutorials suck as well. Support? What Support? I have not had one good experiance with the support team. All I got from the support team was a standard response and no fix to my problem. I emailed them back a second time and they essentially told me, Too bad for you, we wont be fixing anything any time soon.Even with all the issues, I still very much like the game and I do not regret getting it. I wish there were fewer problems with it and I wish it was cheaper to get the DLC. But like they say Deficate in one hand wish in the other see which one gets filled first. That is why I cannot recommend this. There is no intent on fixing known issues and bugs. I am willing to overlook these bugs, but, unless you really like trains, there are too many problems and the staff doesn't care about these problems. On top of all that, the thing is stupidly expensive. You would think for such an expensive product, there would be fewer bugs but that is not the case. Its a shame though because this title has so much potential.EDIT: 10/14Got the new update. I now use TS 2015. What the folks at TS did to update the simulator was to make my PAID FOR content vanish like a fart in the wind. DO NOT BUY. Instead of fixing problems they released a new version and now there goes several of my hard earned bones. This is a title with much potential but the developer keeps getting in the way of what could be a wonderful simulation game.

content:
19, 2016
												I had high expectations for this game when I first purchased it, but it seems those expectations were never met.The gameplay and graphics seemed better than what I had experienced playing older versions of Trainz as well as the variety of scenarios and equipment. However, Trainz runs fine on most regular PCs and they don't make you pay ridiculous amounts of money for more routes and content to add to the game. The DLC for this game is expensive for what it is and when you buy the base game you're not given many routes or equipment thus forcing you to buy the proprietary Dovetail DLC from their store or from Steam. The dynamic lighting feature is tied directly to locomotive headlights that actually produce light, so if you turn it off you get the wonderful sensation of driving a train without being able to see what's ahead of you. The game also has ridiculous system requirements in order for it to run properly. The sensitivity of the scenario scoring is also quite ridiculous as well as some of the ways that the in-game physics work. I still play this game because I payed good money for the base game as well as the DLC, but I have mixed feelings playing it as well as paying any more money for their expensive DLC. If anything I find playing the other steam games to be better value for game play than this or even just any of my other hobbies compared to this game. Don't buy this game unless you have a powerful computer and are willing to spend tons of money on actually buying enough content to fully enjoy the game. If anything it'd be better to try and find a different train simulator to play other than this one.

content:
5, 2015
												I had Train Simulator a few years ago and loved it. I saw it in the summer sale with a bunch of DLC at a great prince thought to myself "great deal here", so i bought it. Now I'm regretting it a little. It has its moments where it's really good, but lots of flaws. First off, the vast amount of DLC is amazing, I can't knock the amount of DLC available i even bought a good few packages in addition to the summer sale stuff i got. Customer service "stinks" though! Recently the game just refuses to load. Gets as far as "Dovetail games" splash screen then crashes. I Opened a support ticket thought "oh no problem will get back to me in a day or two....." That was 4, maybe more days ago, still no answer. Still no working game. I uninstalled it, reinstalled it. It Worked got an hour or two out of it. Closed it to go out. Come home started it up doesn't work again. Same Problem.   I agree with a lot of other comments for devs. Stop throwing DLC out or rehashing some existing with different liveries and make patches. There are so many buttons that do not work. Please sort it out! It can't be a simulator if half the stuff doesnt work. Also undocking the HUD would be great as well or at least a lot more customisable layouts. Also answer your support tickets or even at least read them! Gameplay wise its ok, controls are easy to learn etc but still majority of the buttons in the cab don't work. Also reduce the cost of DLC some of it is so overpriced and you only get 1 maybe 2 scenerios out of it. Also the driving is a little too perfect.... What happened to keeping drivers alert? No emergency cord pulls, nothing running out onto the tracks, random broken down trains. You know realism day to day things that could happen. The only thing keeping drivers alert is the fact the EWS screams when you go through amber lights. I would reccomend this, but not with the current level of customer service. That needs drastic improvement.

content:
1, 2015
												PROS:- good game if you are a train enthusiast.- intro video is neat- i really cant say much. just too much wrong with this gameCONS:- game is very unpolished. things like the narration dialog boxes feel cheap and the additional hud controls seem like they can be so much better.- train horns suck. you can hear the looping, which is dead obvious on certain engines, and it doesnt even play back as you intend most of the time.- zoom mechanism is very shoddy when in 3rd person. if you 'ram' the camera down into the car behind the engine in focus, it'll push the camera location out and away. yet when you scroll, it basically crops and zooms the visible area of the camera without actually moving it TO the engine in focus.- - not only 3rd person, but it really needs to be improved in general. it seems too constricted to pre-set areas. especially when going through tunnels and such.- the headlights seem nearly ineffective. like the only thing it's doing is giving the engine a lit up look.- and my biggest complaint: so much expensive DLC yet every one i've tried has an issue with it. things like a train coming at you head on whenever you get to a certain point, with no way to avoid it or complete the scenario. or improperly set timings. or random unmarked speed zones which slaughter your points, forcing you to restart if you want to make gold. or any metal for that matter.- objectives seem unclear or confusing at times- just general bugs, inconsistencies, problems, unpolish.CONCLUSION:dont buy this game unless you mind the bugs, unpolish, and are willing to research good packs that dont have any issues.OTHER THOUGHTS: most companies release software (not just games) on a 2 step cycle: new features, then bug fixes. they push out new features one update, then fix all the bugs the next. rinse and repeat. this company fails to do so. they're more worried about pushing out content as fast as possible than they are about giving us a quality game. its a shame this is the best train sim that's out there. sure, they updated to *better* menus and looks a few times. but its still confusing to navigate. it took me forever to find the community content section within the game, and i wouldnt be able to remember off hand from not playing it for a while.BEST SOLUTION: redo the whole damn game. and dont come out with any more DLC until you do. and work on fixing and testing the DLC (yeah, its a lot. which is why you shouldve been doing this in the first place). game test a lot and think "how can i make this better?" "would i personally play and enjoy this?" "would this be easy for everyone? or just me?"PS: i dont mean for this to sound negative. i genuinely do want this game to get better. but if they keep going their same path, it never will and itll just get worse and worse.

19, 2014
												Trainsimulator 2014 is a simulator in the "driver's ed" sense; there is no crashing, no disobeying the rules, and you are penalized for going slightly over the speed limit.  Worse, the controls are weak; the throttle snaps to various large-increment amounts forcing you to babysit your speed on real-time journies - some exceeding an hour in length.  The graphics are reasonably pretty and there are various facilities to make your own assets, but ultimately, this is no game, it's a substitute for steel and resin model trains.  Except you can crash those, if you like.

number of helpful: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
10, 2015
												I grabbed this ages ago on hefty Steam discounts... And, that's honestly where the value is.+ 2015 version has great UI+ Fun to drive trains+ Interesting tutorials+ lots of workshop content+ started with 2013 edition, free upgrade to 2015+ some free DLC (known as Classic Routes in the workshop)+ career system seems interesting so far- some tutorials need better explanations (ie: when breaking, explaining what wheel slippage is and why it happens would be nice.. or the right time to start slowing down when a speed limit is changed, etc)- even with beefy spec'ed machine I still lagged out in certain areas- graphics could be plenty better or at least better polish- riddled with bugs- insane base price- insane DLC pricesMy positive and negative bullet points basically sum it all up. It's a neat game, and there's a lot of great stuff here. But is it worth $60CAD? Heck no, not compared to so many other titles out there. Why is that? Because for AAA prices, I don't want to see "ID Not Found" when trying to create my profile. I don't want to see lag or framerate drops on my high-spec'ed machine every time I pass through a town - and all the other little bugs. This is further worsened by the DLC prices - when they are priced the same as full-version titles, and I can read about how they have the same craftsmanship (aka riddled with bugs), I'm just not going to take the chance at getting burned. And that is disapointing, because I like sinking my teeth in detailed sims; and I'm not afraid of opening my wallet and investing considerable sums into a game to support it... But when the title is riddled with bugs, the content (such as the tutorials) need further ironing out and so on, you cannot justify these prices - no matter how niche-market the title is.I guess I can conclude this all by saying that in the end, I am enjoying it. A) because I did get the base copy and some DLC for cheap, and B) because my base copy keeps getting updated for free; so it's hard to really feel ripped off. So I am enjoying it - but I'm disappointed because I feel like my replay value is going to be capped until I can get some more DLC for cheap; because I won't be paying their regular price that's for sure. I wish I could say maybe on the reccomendation... but it has to come down to this: until they drop their base prices for the game and the dlc to something more fitting the quality of the game you're getting right now, my reccomendation has to be no.tl;dr; Great Steam Sale buy if it's dirt cheap (60-70% off or more I'd say). Game is nice, but buggy. Insane DLC prices will likely hurt replay value.. but I'm still enjoying it (since I did get it cheap ages ago) so far.

content:
4, 2014
												This game could be so much fun. Instead, the user interface is clunky, the camera control is very limited and makes you feel locked down, and the game comes down to just one thing: watching the tracks go by, without much interaction.In my mind, I want to be an engineer who controls the train, can check for news on delays, weather, last minute changes, all while trying to get the train where it needs to be on time. I was looking forward to changing off the back end of the train cars, as they would be going to a different location. I was hoping to have interaction with the train crew notifying me about trouble with cars, requiring me to pull over at a non-scheduled station stop. I don't want to just pick my engine and cars, I want to make it matter which engine and cars I pick, because maybe Amtrak only uses specific cars. Maybe the track I'm traveling on is the only track open due to construction, and there's another train coming. Will I crash? Will I cause hundreds of people to have a very bad day? I'll never know!This game so far is ironically like a train wreck. Good luck getting that to happen in the game, though.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
er 22, 2013
												Train Simulator is representative of a franchise that seeks to offer a semi-realistic representation of what it would be like if you were a conductor. The thing is, there isn't really a game here. There is very little to keep you interested for more than a few minutes unless you're playing the game ironically for some sort of media-review or livestream event.There is very little to guide you ingame as to what you're supposed to do and simply getting a game going in career mode is relatively unintuitive. The game tries to push paid DLC at you at every turn (charging extraordinary amounts of cash for things that should have been in the game from the get-go) often times disrupting the obvious methods by which you actually initiate a game session.If you can get this for really cheap (we're talking under 10 dollars) it might be worth checking out purely for the irony (and if you're planning on playing it ironically to an audience that values your suffering at the helm of ridiculous/broken games).

content:
er 10, 2014
												I would really love to be able to give this the thumbs up.....and yet I can't. The potential is certainly there; in fact, it's not that far from being a good game. But at the end of the day you are just met with frustration.The graphics, considering that this game is 75% about the visual experience, are nothing special though that is hardly surprising given the age of the graphics engine. The physics....well, not knowing what driving a steam engine would really feel like I cannot say that it makes me think I am. But despite these deficiencies I find it strangely compelling to drive a commuter train and there is a real sense of achievement when you have kept it to time.Then, however, comes the frustrating part. The latest annual update made a whole mess of the game; an unwieldy and counter-intuitive menu system, scenarios which now no longer work, graphical glitches galour and achievements which can now no longer, well, be achieved. And a company which basically does not listen to its customer base but prefers to bury its head in the sand.A new version with a brand new graphics engine is apparently in the pipeline which will then become the flagship. We are promised that support for this version will continue but I have to ask myself.....given DTG's track record is that really likely given that profits seem to be the be all and end all with customer service rather well down the list?

number of helpful: 24 of 40 people (60%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												Train simulator 2016 has been released a few months ago and so it is time to give it a proper reviewFirst things first, this review will not be about prices, I can't give a rats ♥♥♥ about the price of either the game or the DLC. This game is mainly sold on Steam as is the official DLC and Steam has enough sales each year that the price of a game or DLC means diddlysquat. You find the prices to high, wait a few weeks and chances are they drop 50 to 80% for a few days. You are never more than 3 months away from a good deal.The goodThe current incarnation of Train Simulator is Train Simulator 2016. Personally I think it is one of the best yearly updates I have seen for those that bought the new edition. It has some very nice content coming with it, the new menu look is great, the new search works finally like a search should work and the content I played so far is of the better quality. My personal favorite in this years edition is the Union Pacific Gas Turbine also known as the GTEL. The new DB BR155 is a nice German engine as well and the new Riviera in the fifties route with its 5 Steam engines is one of the better route add ons I have seen in a long time. Ok, Sherman Hill and Cologne to Koblenz are reruns but if you didn't already own them they are two good additions for your collection. the Steam edition also packs the Norfolk Southern Coal District and the SD60M. The last one was added a bit later to the pack but everyone that bought the game got the engine regardless.Also good is the TS rewards that are new this year. If you updated/upgraded to TS2016 you got a pop in after first launch where you could sign up for a newsletter which also signed you up for these rewards. Officially the first rewards are for TS2016 related content but the first reward was given to everyone that signed up even if they had the free update and it was a rather nice yellow boxcar. as extra bonus they added a 20% off coupon for the game for those that had not bought the new addition. The boxcar looks nice and imo stands out from the normal rolling stock you see but I couldn't resist making a reskin for it (as well as for the GTEL) and making a bit of fun with the yellow theme it has. You can find the reskins at http://www.wolfdenmedia.nl/download/the-minion-pacific-full/The new support system. Not really a TS2016 addition as it is in place for a few months now but my recent dealings with this new system and the people have been... satisfactory. Ok it took you long enough to actually post the correct info on tailsimulator.com and the Steam support topics but I think it is an improvement over the email system you hadThe community:  Simply an amazing bunch of people. You will find them on Steam and on several "fan sites" like railworksamerica, UKTS, Railsim.de and many other country related sites. they are providing the players with first line support, reskins, fixes, mods etc. Do visit the sites, get involved, have funThe badYes, the bad. Let's start with the fact DTG managed to ruin the update once again especially for those that did the free update. First there was no loading screen which made many players think their game had frozen and/or just didn't work anymore and when a hotfix was released it resulted in people not even being able to start the game at all. This somehow affected the free update only so I think personally that it had something to do with the fact that the new menu is now a DLC pack just like the academy for example. Yes it is part of the game but at the same time it is not. I think it is a wrong move by DTG, you want a new menu look, fine (it looks great) but release it for everyone as part of the core and not as a paid feature. It is ridiculous and doesn't make sense at allBugs ... it wouldn't be a DTG release if it didn't have at least a few bugs. The new drivers assist function for Steam engines for example does not work like it should. I have tried it and the tips it gives do not make any sense. It resulted several times in me running out of water, it told me to give more on the reverser and followed that up (after you followed the advice)  with less reverser, and more, and less, and so on. It basically made me nuts and ditch the use as quick as I could while having the idea it was at least tried out properly by me to give an opinion on it. Mind you, the driver assist only works (for now) on the new Riviera in the fifties Steam engines. I consider this a work in progress for DTG and it should not have been added yetRailfan mode....... really DTG? you dare to call that a "new feature" ? ok, I give you that you added an option in the editor to set points along the track for this railfanning but common, this is for the rest just a career scenario without a player train. It can be fun for a few times but a new feature?  maybe you guys should check the workshop and see how many of your talented players have created very nice railfan scenarios without the need of a "railfan" marker. Take with that, that the Sherman Hill, Sherman Hill  railfan scenario is broken, not bugged... broken and I rest my case, what a useless addition that isThe UglyYou thought I was done? HAH no no my friends, there is "the ugly" as well and boy oh boy it is uglyBigBoy: You decided in your "wisdom" to repack the bigboy (and the challenger) in the Ap file compression format. In itself not a bad idea, it makes for less 'clutter" on your system although reskinners and modders are less thrilled that they have again another ap to unpack thus adding to the size of their installs but.... YOU FORGOT TO PACK THE SOUNDS.... and... you completely miscoded a bin file that has the references to said sound files as well (a fix can be found at http://www.wolfdenmedia.nl/download/big-boy-sounds/ , you are most welcome) Which numskull has been responsible for that? how on earth can you forget a part of the setup of an engine. Worst thing though is the fact that there is still NO OFFICIAL PATCH, excuse me? it took me half a night and I am not even a game developer to get it fixed (again, you are welcome, see the link I posted, grab it, pack it and make the people happy, you are even allowed to take credit if you wish)BNSF: Do I have to go there? hell yes I have to go there. HOW has it been able to come to this, HOW could you not see this coming. You were ordered by BNSF about a year ago to remove all BNSF content and what do you do? you remove all content that have BNSF in the name, leave the rest in place, don't inform your players of what is happening and think you are done. Then suddenly BNSF comes telling you they ordered you to remove BNSF content all together, you remove WITHOUT AGAIN INFORMING YOUR PLAYERS this content which by the way contains two very important routes. Refuse to replace those routes, refuse to replace the engines that are NOT BNSF in the other removed packs, basically flip the finger to your non US player base and when I take action and rally the community you play the innocent and one of your devs even sends me an angry mail on how I dare to talk about DTG, a certain site and "question his integrity"? Well, actually I didn't question his integrity but your response to me actually proves what I said on "that site". YOU are free to respond if you like although I don't think you will. I will not reveal your name as this is not my style. However my comments remain the same, your company simply has been screwed if not blackmailed in this, Trainz and run8 are proof of this as they clearly show the "official BNSF and DTG response" is a load of bullpoo.  review to long, read the whole thing at http://www.wolfdenmedia.nl/howling-down-the-track-a-ts-and-dtg-review/

content:
, 2011
												I used to recommend this game:"For those who have always wanted to drive a steam train!"But much has changed since then...The game has been hijacked by Nvidia, if you own an AMD graphics card avoid this game - it looks terrible (anti-aliasing doesn't work - a killer on a game that is based on parallel lines vanishing into the distance), and the performance is terrible.Also they keep dumbing down the user interface...It used to be really fun challenge to drive a steam train - personally the only reason I bough the game - but in each of the last two major updates they have reduced the supposed "expert" control system to the point where it is unusable.I can understand that they may have had some complaints from people unwilling to take the time to learn how to drive the trains properly (steam trains are far more difficult to drive properly - that's kind of the point), but to cripple the game to the point where those that want to cant anymore is just plain dumb.So for the time being I just cannot recommend this game to anyone.

content:
1, 2014
												Not even close to the real thing.Edit: Thought I'd elaborate a little since I wasn't too pleased when I played the game. The game is very pretty, and the trains look very nice. However, the physics are way off, trains lose speed at an extreme rate as soon as you lay off the throttle, and anyone who's ever driven a train know's that is not what happens. Also, even though most many trains today use electronic break systems that can initiate all breaks simultaneously, all freight trains and also passenger trains that are pulled by locomotives still use air powered break systems. These do NOT react with lightning speed as it does in this game.These two issues are to me game breaking and totally pulls me out of the immersion that the game would otherwise have. If the development team could focus on making the actual driving of the trains more realistic, and by extension fun, they could have a great game that I would probably immensly enjoy. Who knows, maybe then I'd actually buy some of all those million DLC's they keep throwing at us.

content:
7, 2014
												In the state that this game has been in for years, I could not recommend this to any body.They introduce more bugs with every "Update" of the main game and never fix the old ones. Most of them are game breaking, as in you CAN NOT complete the scenario.I have spent a few hunder on this game due to the DLC, which are outragously over priced. As with the main game, they have no quality control. They keep releasing buggy DLC / Expansion one after another, knowing people will pay the over inflated prices.I have put out numerous requests to the developers to fix thier game, everything has gone unheard per thier operating policy.An example of a game breaking bug that has been plaguing the base game and expansions for years is the AI collision bug. A scenario made by the developers can not be completed due to this. What happens is that you'll be cruising along the track and always at the same portion of your progression an AI train will get into a collision with something. There are work arounds by removing the train yourself by editing mission. Why would I pay to edit my own mission when I paid to have to not to make my own mission. This bug has been in the base game and majority of expansions, even the newer ones for YEARS!Other things like dynamic brakes and air brakes not working properly are just some of the things that have never been fixed. Poor signage a long tracks, the signate not reporting the track speed in game(Sign/Signals will tell you speed you are support to go and the game will tell you a different speed, causing you to go 'over-speed' on routes. When playing career mode it makes it really difficult to make stops on time and maintain a high score as the speeding fees will eat away at your score). I have owned this game since it was called Rail Works 2.As you can note, I have invested a very significant of time and money to this game. I have not been able to put up any longer with the persistant state of neglect and extremely poor customer service.I can not in good heart recommend this game to anybody. number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
er 20, 2015
												Disclaimer: I so badly want to give this game a recommedation but I just can't right now, but I am willing to change that if things get better. I bought a boxed copy of TS2013 in 2013 for like $12 on sale, at Target or Wal-Mart, and have spent more than I'd like to admit in DLC overtime. It's been good, but things arent getting better. I do like playing, it just there are a lot of areas that would make it leaps and bounds better. I will Continue to play this game and buy its dlc(on sale) because I do enjoy it and I am a sucker.At the time of writing 12-19-2015 I have basicly no access to content that is currently advertised and that comes with ts2016, which I find quite appaling. The only route I do have is Sherman Hill, but It came with my boxed copy. I use the word route intentionally, because thats just I only have the route, not the trains advertised, namely the UP GTEL. which is new and as far as I can tell can only be obtained by buying the Sherman Hill Route, which I already have.Every year they "upgrade" my base game. Which has effectivly added nothing to my game. they have changed the UI and Splashscreen every year, with ts2015 I was really happy with the intro video, its got Sean Bean <sidenote>how is that pronounced its it bean or baun?</sidenote> voicing it if you know who he is.But no, with this latest "upgrade" I got some crap video rubbing it into my face all this content I dont get with the base game. Oh and dont expect the graphics to look like that, It's never going to happen.(Since I bought this I have made some improvement to my computer, mainly better graphics card. all of which has made little or no change in the frame rate of this game, which currently runs at about 15-20, with very frequent lag spikes. I have seen massive improvements in graphics and framerates in other games such as Skyrim, Euro Truck Sim2, Kerbal Space Program)Quite often there is an almost utter lack of attention to detail in everything. For instance in the Locomotives, no two trains are held to the same standard of quality. blurry interiors, horid sound quality, poor lighting effects, near complete lack of interior control many trains have no interior lighting, makes night driving not fun at all. Most have no control over exterior lights I.e. running lights, although on some trains step lighiting, number lights etc. (both of which you really never have control because a complete lack thereof) Effectivly there is three light settings On(FWD), Reversing, which should show red light on the front of the Locomotive, but for all intensive purposes this is an off setting, and then off, no lights anywhere.I'd say 80% of the locomotive I have don't have a bell.Old content(and customers) get left behind and abandoned in this game. With every "update" there's more bugs, more crashes, and longer loading times. Old content never gets updated, fixed, redone, just left to rust like an old locomotive. Just look at me heretofore mention "Sherman Hill" story.  It seems to me the only people they care about, are people who havent given them money yet.My Biggest grip is the Editor I start with the consist(Locomotive and cars) editor, Crashes 75% of the time, if you can get it to load, its not bad.<Parental Advisory>The Scenario Editor, holy ♥♥♥♥. Acutually Un-holy ♥♥♥♥, because thats what it is an unholy abomination in the eyes of whom ever you worship. It is so incredibly hard and frustrating to use or even understand. It uses some terrible GUI system that makes no sense and often just doesnt work, unless you do it precisely a certain way with less than a .0001% margin of error. Nothing has label, unless you hover over it for like 5 seconds. I want to know what DTG uses to make the routes, because there is no way in hell that is what they use to pump out their DLC. I lose my sanity and swear profusely at my screen everytime I try to use it.</Parental Advisory>Oh and fyi, the listed system minimums lie.I might add more to this later, but I'm just so frustrated right now writing this up, I need to take a break.Again I hope that one day I can redact all this and write a positive review, because of my love for trains and simulator games, I really hope that day comes and soon.

content:
er 31, 2013
												I purchased Holiday Express to see if I could run TS 2014 and it worked very well, not one issue. I purchased TS 2014 Steam edition with Pacific Surf-liner route. At first the tutorial would crash after starting, with only 2gb (Windows 7 32bit, Quad core) of ram I could see the game would use it all and then crash. I upgraded to 4gb of ram and the game worked for awhile, tutorials, scenarios. Pacific Surf-liner will run for about 15 minutes and crash with either a dump message or a vertex message. I have the game running as low as it possibly can but the issue persists. After searching I have found dozens of people like me who have this experience with little to no help given. Solutions are all over the place from 3gb ram switch for windows to reinstalling everything from .net to flash player. Its rare that I feel cheated by a steam game but when 99% of my library works without a crash and this game generates them within 5 minutes I feel like I deserve a refund.Please DO NOT ever buy this game or anything made by these people, its a mess that will keep you up nights trying to figure out why the 1 hour long scenario crashes every 15 minutes. I wasted 17+ dollars but you don't have to.Afterthoughts: After running the game in a window at 1024x768 (previous was 1440x900) it ran on Low detail with very little fuss. I have completed quite a few scenarios and even bought 2 more DLCs before the sale expired (4.49 each, 75% off). I would still not recommend this to people BUT and its a big BUT, if you have a nice gaming rig, a real love of trains and a descent amount of patience you can squeeze some fun from it but for the average person, you have been warned.

ry 23, 2014
												Go buy Trainz 12 from N3V instead. You will be glad you did. This simulator looks good. Ill give it that. But my praise ends there. Once you look at the extremely pricey content, the lack of easily usable scenario creators, and iron fist control, you realize that they should be paying you to use this game. Lets start at the beginning, This simulator is not cheap, $20 for two locomotives and a set of passenger cars, that is absolutely free for trainz users. In fact, a peruse through the store finds that there is no free content besides user made scenarios that use the content that isnt free... you get the point. Its obvious that the creators did not want you building scenarios, because the process is daunting and more frustrating than the videos above make it sound. Mainly because you are unable to use any content not specifically slated for use on that route. For example, you wish to use a P42 and Phase IV superliners (that you paid $20 for) on Donner Pass to model the California Zephyr. Well, those P42's (While completely common on Donner) are only accessible on the $40 Marias Pass route, so you can forget about a Zephyr. Unless of course you wish to fight the scenario creator and go in via quick drive yada yada yada... The point? Dont buy this game. Seriously, dont.

												This game is great if you like trains. Really, you can't go wrong with this game if you like trains! You will have to pay for the routes and trains you want but it is a good thing because it means you can customise your collection! You do get a lot of scenarios with the base game which are all good and they are worth the £24 I paid.Pros:-Good graphics-Train design-Routes-Scenarios-The community-Sounds-RealismCons:-Loading times-Optimization isn't great-Sometimes doesn't tell you when speed limit is dropping-Takes too many points off for speeding (only applies to you if you like getting maximum points so be aware of speeding)Overall, I would give the game an 8/10 because it is a train simulator. I see all these reviews about the price of DLC but they never review the actual game. Don't let the negative reviews put you off, the base game is fantastic and gives you a train simulator. The DLC is there if you want to expand your experience!

content:
22, 2014
												I recommend this game because its a fun way (though not overly challenging) to drive trains of various types with more or less great realism. I think if you give the game a chance and u like trains, it will give you enough hours of fun. What I do not recommend about it and why it gets a thumbs down: The career mode scenarios are punishing mistakes too harshly and quickly.Moreover the prices of the DLCs are ridiculous, to say the least. Given the content delivered, paying almost 30 euros for a route and 15 euros for 1 (!) Loco is really a joke. If the devs want to make this game more attractive to people they seriously need to consider dramatically lowering the prices (ever noticed that the total TS experience will cost u almost 3000 euros??). I waited for some packs to be combined or to get on sale, because otherwise you just throw money out the window.Also I think compared to Trainz and MTS the variety of train networks and routes is a joke, too. Britain (of course) is overrepresented, and then you have Germany and some west and east coast US routes. Would be nice to see French, Italian, Dutch and other European country's rail networks & Loco's.It's fun, but dont get any high expectations. And dont spend too much money on the DLC's. They are like 3 times as expensive as they should be.

y 28, 2016
												I had this game since I had bought the Big Picture Pack of Train Simulator 2013. It is not a bad game as many people would disagree because the price of DLC but you don't need all that DLC to play this. It is cheaper than buying a real model railroad set which is more expensive than the DLCs in this game. Some of the DLCs may sound terrible or the physics messed up. The controls are the same as MSTS (Microsoft Train Simulator) which is why I like this game.Most of the DLC prices like for example that the locos would cost you a good $20 like the P42DC, Acela Express, and the Union Pacific Big Boy. Routes would cost you a good $40 like the Weardale & Teesdale Network, North Jersey Coast Line, Marias Pass, and Soldier Summit. There's a lot of DLCs to choose from that you may want to get like Steam engines, maybe you want to drive some freight American trains, or a drive a UK passenger train. The DLCs are mostly focused on UK, Germany, and USA but there's third party DLC on Steam that there's routes outside those 3 countries you could get. Steam hosts sales for this game from time to time so you could wait to buy a add-on if you're on budget and buying the DLCs like in bundles would help too.PROS:Routes and locos are made from there actual aspects.Lots of add-ons to choose from.Good Visuals for an Old Game EngineSupports TrackIR and RailDriverHelpful CommunityA lot of things to do such as Rail Fanning, operate a Switcher, Freight Train, or a Passenger Train.CONS:Lack of Bug FixingContent with a lot of bugs, missing speed limits on the HUD on certain routes.Needs more advanced features while operating a loco.The DLC's are overpicedYou could get into a #rekt stiulation where your loco can derail, game will end if on a passenger train and then you get thrown a game over message stating that the doors are still open after the loading is done, or running out of water on a steam loco when in a good amount.Most DLCs would only come with a few scenarios but there's scenarios you can download from the workshop to explore more of the particular route or loco.

content:
ber 17, 2015
												(note: this is a review of Train Simulator 2014 / 2015; from a few hours with Train Simulator 2016 it seems extremely similar, mostly cosmetic changes)Although it's far from perfect, it's probably the best (most realistic) train simulator on the market. (other simulators are mostly glorified model railroad simulators)It seems to be derived from the Train Simulator that was sold by Microsoft in 2000.Good points:- various trains, routes and scenarios. High-speed, main line, commuter, freight, electric, steam, diesel, you name it.- you get a very good feeling of what driving a real train is like. Accelerating, respecting signals, braking, switching and handling minor incidents to stay on schedule.- adequate physics, graphics and sounds. Okay this is not up to par with some bleeding edge fantasy games, but frankly, who cares for that on a train simulator?- nice snow, rain, sunset, night, etc- realistic signaling on most routes. The software seems to allow a fairly good realism. Not all routes take advantage of that.-  The London - High Speed Line has a very nice depicting of the French TVM (cab) signalling.Bad points:- scenario quality and difficulty are very inconsistent between routes, even within the DTG routes.  For example the ECML route scenarios are realistic and playable (once you have understood the AWS speed checks at 20 mph on warning signal) with adequate spare time to make up for delays, whereas on the München-Garmish route you have to be at max speed all the time, and it's not always enough to be on time. On the Donner Pass scenario, I still haven't understood how to be on time, considering that being at full throttle the whole time doesn't seem to suffice.  Same for braking distances when you encounter a closed block signal: distances are realistic on the ECML route, whereas you just can't possibly brake fast enough on some closed signals in the scenarios of the München-Garmish route. So you have to redo the scenario from that point, braking before seeing the signal, which kills the whole experience.- you can only handle careers for 1 person. Too bad for families.- the save/resume system is primitive and doesn't save the whole cab state, some throttle or brake positions can be lost in the process. You can only save 1 point at a time per scenario. There is no way to find the list of saved games, you have to look for that scenario by scenario.- the French translation is awfully bad. So unbearable I'm hoping I would be able to revert to the English version, but it doesn't seem possible.- DLCs are waaay, way, way too expensive. Don't buy them, unless you're dying for a specific route or rolling stock. Only buy them in a pack with the game (such as the Steam Edition series) and/or wait for bargain Steam sales which happen about once a year. That way you get a pretty good value for your money.- the in-game keyboard help is incomplete.- the ETA system sometimes gives weird results (ETA in the past...). The documentation gives no detail on what computation it is supposed to show (based on max line speed? Current speed?)- the track display at the bottom of the screen is aged and buggy on some routes (some speed limits are incorrectly shown). The line speeds & ramps & map, etc should be part of the documentation, or accessible from a menu, like in the real world, not limited to the next 2 miles of track on the bottom-of-screen display.- documentation is lacking. It does a minimal job of presenting the game, routes, signalling rules and rolling stock. Many things you'll have to learn by trial-and-error (especially on scenarios). It is to be found online, when it exists. Supposedly the game provides direct access to it for the DLCs you have installed, but it doesn't seem to work. Plus, it would be nice if it was made available during play, but isn't.- can't reuse old MSTS 2000 routes and rolling stock. This is sad as there were tons of free routes in all countries.- not many routes other than UK/US/DE. See above, MSTS 2000 had tons of these.- no multi-player / online mode. In 2015. Really sad. Lots of fun to be had.- being able to play as a signalman would be fun, too (see multiplayer above :)

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												TS 2014 does have some good parts to it.  You get to, at least to some degree, experience driving a train.  The game has pretty decent realism, in the sense that it knows that as more and more rolling stock are coupled, the train gets heavier, longer to stop, slower to speed up, etc.  But I don't think the good parts outweigh the negatives.  For starters, the prices of the add-ons are outrageous.  And it's a total bait and switch, you buy a route, and ooops, you need to go buy a locomotive.  And you aren't buying quality add-ons either.  I think it's fair to say that between all the add-ons that I have purchased, there are not any 2 that deliver the same quality in terms of programming.  All have some bugs, some many bugs.  I have experienced bugs pretty much every time I open the game.  The last drive I just played, I was well under speed limit, on a straight track, and the train just all of a sudden derailed.  Of course, I was about 80% done with the 3 hour drive, and naturally the scenario just ended, so lost all that time.  That's what really sucks is you think you got a drive good, and wham, a big flaw hits, and you are looking at game over.  Anyway, for the money they charge for this game, and all the add-ons, they NEED to really invest into a QA department and not just pocket the profits.  This game could really rock if they actually paid more attention to detail.

, 2014
												Basically the same game like 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015 version of the game. No big difference at all. Sadly, the game still has enormous amounts of bugs and glitches that the developer of the game dont give a damn about. Instead, they keep pushing out new DLCs all the time and not improving existing trains or the game itself. Gameplay stability is as realible as peugeot-engines. Playing this game is like driving a car on just the rims. Something is missing, but Dovetail Games dont feel like fix it. The costs to buy new DLCs is very high (13,99 EURO) for a train and even more for maps. Addons are often half-made and very buggy and is sometimes broken. Even though DLCs are very expensive, their quality, especially train sound is very bad and you can hear some sounds looping and do not sound realistic. When an AI train passes you, the sound suddenly starts from nowhere and dissapers, without fading. Further on, Train Simulator features an editor that makes it possible for a player to make your own scenarios, but it do ALWAYS crash and all the work goes by by. Reversed Awesomness. I will not recommend this game to anyone because all the bugs and the terrible physics and sounds makes this game very boring to play, BUT if the developer starts to fix bugs and starts to push out proper updates, then this game may have potential.

content:
y 21
												This game is both good and bad. I came from playing TRAINZ 2010 and Trainz 2004. I bought this game partly for the Missions but mainly for my own Route/layout creation. Which is why I Don't recomend this game for building. If you want to operate it should be perfect. Some fairly light fixes from DEVs will improve or completelty fix some missions.<<This game is bound more closely to your CPU in my opinion.>>The Good;-Runs good on a GTX 1050Ti. -Detailed locomotives , wagons and stations-Long realistic runs (perhaps abit too realistic as you'll see)-Capped mininum of 15 fps in Cities - Uncapped Avg 30fps Rural - Setting; Medium 1080p (see below for my specs)The Bad;-Runs are realistic but in a extreme way; if you do 1 mph/kph over the limit points will be deducted. As a son of a railroader, the in world situationwould allow room for some play in this speed over the limit (~5mph) This allows for time to be made up if lost elsewhere. This also means that if you don't start moving your train on time it will only get farther and farther behind schedule; with no way to make it up. -The DIY route creation is a bit of a joke. It feels like they threw it in with little thought of the user interface. You'll have to navigate through different save screens to filp between placing rolling stock and track. Track laying is ridgid but in order to make it tighter you have to open up pannels in game to change that. (abit annoying)-DIY Route rolling stock is VERY limited; I bought the German pack it had; 3 different locos, 4-7 different passenger wagons and only ONE type of frieght wagon (in various paint jobs) is available for you to play with!!! At least throw the other 2 types of frieght wagons I saw in the missions. -Some track , assets, switches and rolling stock didn't load in the missions! I couldn't even play one mission because the switch stands and the Cargo wagons I needed to couple to didn't load.<<UPDATE>> 1/21/17 (later in the day)I experimented and noticed all of the rolling stock in DIY Routes is scrambled between the different routes youre required to copy from! Mann. to Karl. Route has more frieght wagons but lacks some passenger cars and the BR 218... Even the ICE 3 (the additional DLC ) is hidden within this route copy!! The game will be much better if they;X-Include 2 more types of frieght wagons free of charge (since it was in the mission)-Improve the scoring system In particular the speed limit penalty-Create a better, more fluid UI for DIY routes.... PLEASE!!-Improve loading of route assets, rolling stock. -Create a route creation tutorial-Put ALL of the Rollingstock and assets on one convient page!!!-Add a more obvious search bar for DIY Thanks for reading :)I'm so lost in this game... :'(Specs;CPU: AMD 860KGPU: EVGA 1050TiRAM: 8GB128 SSD Kingston

												Initial concept was great,the lack of further development in the game engine itself to bring it up to standards of 2014 lets this down in a big way,not to mention the constant $$$$$$ that this game requires.To clear things up pretty quickly,It's not a simulator,and should have never had that word in the title it's just confusing and insulting to simulator fans,it's a game with the emphasis on arcade.RSC,RSDL,DOVETAIL whatever they are calling themselves thesedays really need to get a grip,you might have the 10 year olds fooled,but not the old timers,a few raindrops and shadows IS NOT cutting edge these days,just take a few moments and visit SIMHQ,there are other sims that offer allot more in terms of visulas ect.How many years ago is it since the first conception of Rail Simulator?your still packaging the same old trees and vegetation from 7 years ago,that in itself is just unforgiving,not to mention users have to complete routes by adding occlusion themselves,to me this is just as sloppy as you can get.DLC OVERPRICED,SUBSTANDARD models and sounds,often requires another purchase of a soundpack per loco,so if you paid 10 pounds for a loco - BE PREPAIRED for ADDITIONAL COST.INGAME ADVERTISING...more pressure to buy,it's worse than YOUTUBE it's in your face 24/7It's kind of sad and pathetic when the new kid on the block are headlight flares,how about fixing someof the bugs instead of letting the community do it for you,faster than you!So in the 30 years Ive been simming,from the 48k spectrum 1984 to present day running a 4Ghz beast,this title is probably the biggest letdown/disappointment experianced over those years.TOTAL COST OF DLC --------- £2,159.43 ----------Tads rating on the sim-meter   1/10 - and thats being generous!

content:
ry 2
												Absolute waste of money.  I had bought this game in hopes that it would be, at the very least, a decent simulation of driving a train.  My initial go at this title had me learning operations and how to do what I needed to do, simple enough.  Once I was confident enough to take on my first job, I was constantly experiencing bugs, some of which caused me to fail missions or simply not complete them.  Considering that this game simply iterates upon itself, I was baffled by how small bugs like this continue to persist.  What's worse is the extremely spotty performance you'll get even on good hardware.  The only possible thing I could think of is that the game engine remains unoptimized, considering the graphics are pretty dated and mostly lackluster by current standards.The DLC is also equally insane.  If you don't like the base game, why on earth would you invest more money into it?  Dovetail seems to have a track record of putting out sub-par experience simulators with a seemingly endless amount of DLC, many of which are priced at the same mark of the game itself.  I understand that the DLC is simply for routes or areas you'd like to traverse so you can choose specifically what you want.  However, it bugs me that Dovetail seem to focus their resources on building new DLC rather than fixing their game or optimizing it.  I really wanted to like this game  but after 10 hours of frustration dealing with mission breaking bugs and unoptimized performance, I had enough.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
y 16, 2014
												I want to start by saying that I love playing with trains, coming from a model railroading background and TS2014 Steam Edition is my first Train Simulator / Railworks product. Previously, I had played a version of Trainz (maybe 2006'ish?). I do not have the benefit of knowing this product previously or having previous "included" content that may have come with TS 2012 or 2013 or whatever. My review reflects (for all purposes) a brand-new user of Train Simulator.My overall feeling towards this product is: Half-♥♥♥♥♥. There are just too many bugs, including impossible scenario timetables, career scenarios that require you to buy even more DLC content, and a marked lack of tutorials. The test track and whatever tutorials came with previous versions of TS is no longer included with TS 2014, so the tutorial only shows a couple of quick ICE 2 (German high speed train) driving tutorials only. There are a handful more tutorials, but they are not listed under tutorials, they are listed under the normal drive scenarios. How difficult would it have been to have tutorials show up under "tutorials?" I don't know, but it's that kind of general carelessness that mars an otherwise visually beautiful product.I have experienced scenarios with impossible timetables, stuck brakes, stuck signals, and the piece-de-resistance (for me): the Northbound Celle Intermodal Career Scenario (Hamburg to Hanover Rail Line). In that one, you have to wait some 20 minutes (!) at a signal (no, it's not stuck, it's just crappy scenario design), which will totally -- through no fault of your own, mind you -- blow your timetable to shreds. You will finally arrive at your destination some twenty or so minutes late and complete the scenario successfully...except for a teeny-tiny deduction of -17284 EXP (in my case) for tardiness. That's -17284 EXP on a scenartio that probably gives 1000 EXP if you're perfect at it. I've massed a couple of -7000 penalties in previous Donner Pass scenarios (almost all of which have broken timetables, BTW), but this was the first time that a scenario forced me to take a huge penalty so blatantly.I also don't understand why there is a discrepancy between the career, drive, and free roam scenarios. You'd think that if everything is made up for career, putting that scenario in the drive or free roam section wouldn't be much of an issue, yet entire routes that are in the career scenarios are missing from  the drive scenarios and, in my case, free roam only came with a handful of Donner Pass scenarios. No London Faversham, no Hamburg to Hannover unless I made the scenarios myself, which to the uninitiated such as I looks terribly complicated.I did purchase an additional rail route: the Pacific Surfliner Los Angeles to San Diego route, because it is my "local" route (I live in Southern California). Now, there is a gorgeous route with playable scenarios and nary a major bug that I could find. Why, oh why, couldn't the rest of what came in the Steam edition be like Pacific Surfliner? That was massively enjoyable.This game has so much promise and I will continue to muck around with it (I will even sink more money into it when a couple of routes that peaked my interest go on sale), but I cannot in good conscience otherwise recommend TS2014 in its present state. Unfortunately, from what I gather, Train Simulator has always had these kinds of bugs and apparently no one seems to be fixing them, just too busy producing more DLC, I guess.

content:
y 10
												I'm going to help squash some of the negativity that wanders the reviews. First off, for those who think it's boring, you don't get the point of a simulator. This is to SIMULATE running a full size train over many miles, taking in to account weather, tonnage, horsepower, braking power, grade percantage, speed, and timing. If that isn't your thing, don't buy it. You want to just run trains? Go buy TANE. Yes I'm aware there are many DLC, you have to take into account that some of these have been around since the beginning of the simulator when it was still Railworks, so as time moves on, the content has improved over the years. Plus there is a variety of locomotives and routes, the object isn't to buy them all, just buy what interests you. For me, it's US railroading, 40's to 50's. Plus there are many free engines and cars, just have to look depending on what you are looking for. Of course there are bugs, I don't know of a single game or simulator that doesn't have any bugs. Just report what you find. People report having FPS issues: Simple, upgrade your computer. Before you whine about "shouldn't need to upgrade a computer to run a program," tell me then what the definition of "progress" and "technology advancement." My computer runs the game on highest settings with no issues. I've been running train simulators since 2001 with the release of MSTS, then spent many years with the Trainz franchise from 03 to 12, then went to Railworks from there to now. During that time I've seen many advancements in the train sim world, I work on a real railroad and nothing else can compare overall like Train Simulator 2017* *Yes I know TSW will be released this year, however with no backwards compatability, I doubt I'll make the change anytime soon.

number of helpful: 24 of 42 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
er 22, 2014
												The Steam edition of Train Simulator 2015  is well worth buying, especially when on sale as you can get it as cheap as 80% off.  Each year since its release in June  2009  the game has been upgraded for free (so far); it started life as a game called Rail simulator, but was released on Steam with a name change to Railworks and later became Train Simulator.     If you're a train enthusiast, you'll want to expand the  game  by adding  more dlc; I highly recommend you wait until sales are on to get  most dlc for at least 50% off  or more.  You don't need every dlc to enjoy this game.  It would cost an absolute fortune if you were to buy all or most of the dlc  available, even  when you take account of all the   dlc being on sale; however , to  those of us who enjoy this sort of game, its well worth it.  It is the best  train simulator  available at this time and has been since its release back in 2009. (I don't know what the original Rail Simulator was like).  If you aren't bothered as much about the graphics then the Trainz series is probably the way to go as you get  loads more rolling stock, engines and   different  area's to explore in the  basic package. plus there's only about 10 dlc  available for the game.    I backed the latest version of Trainz via Kickstarter as I thought they were going to make  a much better looking  game this time, but I was wrong.  Engine cab details are appalling compared to the almost life like cabs you find in Train simulator 2015, plus you can use most of the controls  using your mouse, or touch screen. Also you have two ways you can drive your  trains in Train Simulator, either   using the quick drive controls, or  using the actual  controls in the train.  Trainz as far as I can remember doesn't include that option.  Since this game was added to the workshop, there are  masses of extra content available for free. Not all of it will be usable unless you have the appropriate dlc, but you'll still find loads for  the basic  Steam version of the game.Check out a few videos HERE, HERE, HERE, and HERE. Not the best videos, but I wanted to post  videos without adverts.
