												GAME IS BASICALLY DOVETAIL'S ADVERTISEMENT FOR THEIR DLC'S...I bought this game because I thought what I was getting was a 30 dollar game for half price...if this was ever a 30 dollar game then I pity those that paid that....this game is hardly worth 15...in fact considering this game solely exists to try to get you to buy all their other DLC's it should be free.  I think the simulation is not half bad in of itself, but its designed from the get-go to be a DLC money bait while masquerading as a standalone game with enough content to keep you occupied for more than a day. There are many DLC money bait games, but they don't also insult your intelligence by pretending not to be. Take for example the Digital Combat Simulator. You get a very good plane and a whole campaign to start, FOR FREE. I played at least a hundred hours on that free base game before dropping money on anything else of theirs, and by then I fully felt they deserved everything I paid and more. Take another example...War Thunder... You can play all of that FOREVER FREE, with the option of fast tracking your leveling up or buying a premium plane with some moolah. THOSE are how honest content baiting work, and should work, in my opinion. You know upfront that since the base game is free, they are going to be enticing you to pay for further content. But at least it's honest. Since what I paid for is supposed to be a 30 dollar game, I really expected much more. I do like the game, but I'm one of those people that hate to give money to people that I feel wronged me, so I will not pay any more money for anything Dovetail. This experience also convinced me to stick with my MicroSoft flight simulator instead of the Dovetail reiteration....PS (Edit) I also would like to point out that the front "cover" of the game features 2 trains, the American diesel locomotive on the left plus the steam locomotive in the middle, that is not included in the base game at all and is only (presumably) available as a paid DLC.

ber 9, 2013
												this game is fun but I have 4 issues with it train wise not game wise , other than that it runs perfectly  :-  My first issue is the fact that there is a lack effort to combat the many glitches this game encounters , just by adding a new name and textures dosen't mean that the game has improoved it just makes it worse .-My second issue is about the fact there arn't any undergroun , subway , metro and japanese maglev routes after all it is a train simulator thus meaning it should have many of these challenging high speed routes . until they add these routes and trains then what are we fans like me gonna look forward to the next upcoming year , cos when i play this game it feels like ' train sim 13 ' not 14 .- My third issue is about the lengths of the route and the route itself  30 or 50 miles ain't gonna cut it especially when we fans are limited to 3 countries 6 or seven would be perfect . the routes should be at most 400miles long and have some sort of danger like fallen powerlines or a train derailment or a tree in the middle to keep us train drivers on edge and some sort of music or sound to keep those newbies awake, afterall it makes the development team more money to develop and us fans entertained .my fourth and final issue is about the AI , this game has the worst AI ever . its clunky and unrealistic and don't show a visual image when they board a train you can spin , fly , walk and even chang camera and you won't see the AI board your train , its just the same people on the same train . other simulators and games show off their AI boarding busses boaring planes and other vehicles and they look extremely detailed and don't all walk like pimps with that wierd limp . It is very sad that a simulator of this nature and popularity lacks in these small but very notable problems would have thought by now it would look AMAZING with numerous routes that are at least 0 to 400miles long

As a game developer your first priority should be your customer's satisfaction but here it looks like their's priority is money. The game which was selling at $50-60 (TS 2012) is now selling at $1500-1700 (including all routes and content).

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
0, 2013
												After playing this for five years, I can't recommend it.So, upon my first runs on the sim, I was instantly hooked. Hell, I didn't even CARE at the time how much it was for a route. I remember being hyped for the TS2014 Update (at the time I had no idea what would become of TS). So around December 2013 (from what I can remember), RSC Rebranded as DTG, and around that point, The sim began it's ever so slowly fall. At first, I didn't notice, I was too busy having fun while reading over the other players problems via the forums (i'm no longer subscribed to them as they got annoying). Around mid May 2014, I finally started to note some issues, and finally decided to give in to a negative review. The review, did NOT last very long, as when TS2015 came out, I was instantly happy to see a Class 801 (which nowadays serves no purpose, YET) and the upgraded Acela (which has NOW been discontinued for some stupid reasons regarding it not being up to standards). This was the point I had met some friends who knew and had to deal with the current issues with the sim, something I started experincing around December 2014.When TS2016 was announced, I was nevertheless, expecting just a update, untill I found out you had to pay for it......... I ended up dropping $38 bucks to get it to work (as my TS kept crashing when the free TS2016 update came). Other than that, it was just a rehash of TS2015. The same goes for the TS2017 update.  Now, enough of this nonsense, let me just cut to the chase.One problem that REALLY annoys me is the costant dump files (when the game has crashed). Another problem is the  amount of money for DLC, some of which are just bad. I think i've spent over 1000 bucks on this game for bad DLC. DTG keep messing stuff up, like reusing Class 455 sounds on newer trains. Even with the newer DLC my friends have lag issues, one of mine can't even get his game working anymore, and had to go back to Run8.If you think that's not bad, wait till you meet the TS Community. Back in the day it was just 3rd party devs, but now we have the reskinners and the freeware devs. I'm not going into detail here on how much of an issue this is becomming (I'm looking at Just Trains and All those people who reskins of the same train to make theirs better [No offense to Superalbs, who's reskins are good]) To sum it all up, make sure you have a super computer, and try to have around $100-200 durring the steam sales, which is the best time to purchase DLC.Overall, it's a 0/17. I still enjoy driving trains, but I can't recommend it due to all the flaws, which may never be fixed, as DTG are most certianly going to put all their work into TSW around 2018...

content:
, 2014
												I would be able to recommend this game if we had a time machine and could travel back to 2012, which was before the company now known as Dovetail Games removed the majority of content and made it all DLC exclusive. As a result you will have to fork out massive amounts of cash in order to get your moneys worth of the full asking price of $54.99 USD. The basic game without any DLC comes as barebones as possible and you will almost definitely be looking at which DLC you fancy within an hour or two, and of course having you to spend much more than the already ridiculous base price of $54.99 USD.Aside from the DLC issue, there are two other blatant problems that have not been addressed by the developer. The first is the unrealistic acceleration and braking, which makes this simulator feel much more like an arcade game. The second issue is that you will be left asking where your money's worth is going with the numerous DLC you will undoubtly purchase since the developers rarely patch or update any routes or locomotives that have bugs. You will see cars driving in the air for example, alongside the road.Since I've bought over 50 different DLC routes and locomotive packs my copy of the game actually has a decent amount of content, but since I've had to spend tenfold on this game as I have on any other; it is simply impossible to recommend it. That said, having spent hundreds of hours on this game I can say that it is enjoyable if you have an interest in trains or trainspotting.

content:
ry 27, 2014
												Railcraft (a mod for minecraft) offers more, in terms of "working a rail line". Train Simulator is a point-to-point game of simply driving from location to location. It offers very little, in terms of actually doing something. Sure, there are passenger operations, but that is only a small portion of work available.The game is pretty. But it is boring and expensive. There is a lot of missed opportunity, with this game. If it offered more of a variety of things to do, there would be considerably more replay value.The editor is fairly powerful, though comes with absolutely no tutorial, whatsoever.Workshop is full of additional scenarios that people have made, but you are likely missing the majority of the DLC needed to play them. Much of the older DLC is no longer fully compatible with the game and there seems to be little effort to resolve this conflict.In the end, do I regret spending money on this product? No. But I wish the company was more up-front about what is included in DLC and that they put more effort in to exploring various types of work to be done by rail service. As well as included literature or tutorials for the editor (as  the official content is sorely lacking in scenarios. You are essentially purchasing assets, with DLC)

7, 2014
												This game is gorgeous, and a very detail rich simulation.  Driving a train and enjoying the scenery is a much slower gaming experience, which isn't a bad thing.But I can't recommend this because the developer nickle and dimes the customer to death.  Want different engines?  Prepare to pay.  Want more routes?  Pay again.  Want to use an engine that you bought in a route pack on another route?  Guess what.  If I buy an engine with a route, I want to be able to use that in any route in the game.  This just annoys me.I'm not hardcore enough a train fan to want to pay the $1,000+ they want to charge for all the DLC they offer, and I suspect that most gamers are going to feel the same way.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												Firstly, If all you can find in a few minutes of scrolling are negative reviews, you gotta know something's up.This game has very little actually going for it the way I see it. The stock game which I only purchased because it was 85% off, is very lacking, containing only three semi-decent routes and about a dozen different Locomotives. And while that may keep you busy for hours, I imagine most railfans, the audience I'm fairly certain this game is meant to appeal to, will not be satisfied. Driving a few select european trains and a few North American Diesels of the same road gets old relatively quickly. There aren't even any steam locomotives in the stock game, which is funny considering the game does clearly have steam locomotive functionality. Unfortunately for railfans, if they do get suckered into buying the game, they have to fork out another 10-25 dollars for additional content via DLC. And when I say 10-25 dollars, that isn't a package of items. It's like 15 dollars for a single locomotive. Like what gives? If you bought every DLC for this game I'm certain you would spend well over a thousand dollars. Content and lack thereof aside, the Game itself is disgustingly overpriced. I bought it for $8.24. That was 85% off. The normal retail price of this game is $55. Unless you've got money growing out of your ears, that and the cost of additional content is enough to make anyone grimmace. Another issue I have is that the game's sound effects are rather mediocre, the horns in particular. The engine sounds are at least half decent but none of the sound effects are very clean and  the levels are all wrong.Now, let's be clear, it still is one of the nicer looking rail sims out there, at least in my experience. The lighting is very decent and the textures, at least for Locomotives and rollingstock, are definitely what I would expect out of a modern game. The interface is fairly easy to use and relatively clean as well, and though I've heard otherwise, the actual physics simulation doesn't feel half bad. That being said, while I'd call myself a railfan, I'm certainly not an expert in the way of train physics.In the end, the measure of a game's worth relies upon how satisfying it is versus the price you pay, and in the case of TS 2014, It just isn't worth buying. Even at 85% markdown on the base game and 50%-60% on DLCs.

												This game is gorgeous, and a very detail rich simulation.  Driving a train and enjoying the scenery is a much slower gaming experience, which isn't a bad thing.But I can't recommend this because the developer nickle and dimes the customer to death.  Want different engines?  Prepare to pay.  Want more routes?  Pay again.  Want to use an engine that you bought in a route pack on another route?  Guess what.  If I buy an engine with a route, I want to be able to use that in any route in the game.  This just annoys me.I'm not hardcore enough a train fan to want to pay the $1,000+ they want to charge for all the DLC they offer, and I suspect that most gamers are going to feel the same way.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 27, 2014
												Railcraft (a mod for minecraft) offers more, in terms of "working a rail line". Train Simulator is a point-to-point game of simply driving from location to location. It offers very little, in terms of actually doing something. Sure, there are passenger operations, but that is only a small portion of work available.The game is pretty. But it is boring and expensive. There is a lot of missed opportunity, with this game. If it offered more of a variety of things to do, there would be considerably more replay value.The editor is fairly powerful, though comes with absolutely no tutorial, whatsoever.Workshop is full of additional scenarios that people have made, but you are likely missing the majority of the DLC needed to play them. Much of the older DLC is no longer fully compatible with the game and there seems to be little effort to resolve this conflict.In the end, do I regret spending money on this product? No. But I wish the company was more up-front about what is included in DLC and that they put more effort in to exploring various types of work to be done by rail service. As well as included literature or tutorials for the editor (as  the official content is sorely lacking in scenarios. You are essentially purchasing assets, with DLC)

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
r 7, 2014
												This game claims to be the ultimate train table train simulator.  By this I mean it advertises itself as being the ultimate digital model railroad software.Sadly, it is not.It fails to be a decent simulator, it fails to be a decent layout builder game, and it fails to be a decent game in general.In real life, if you build a layout, you can at least know, when you buy new rolling stock, if it's the right scale and the correct gauge, you can run it on your layout.Not so in Train Simulator.  There's a convoluted path to putting your new rolling stock on to the train table."But you're discounting free ride mode."  No, I'm not, because there's nothing immersive about driving a single train through a dead world with no other train but yours in it.  That's just dull and lifeless.One of the so-called advantages this game offers is the ability "to build a virtual layout."  Unfortunately, that's not as easy as they make it out to be, either.Cities In Motion 2, Train Fever, and Euro Truck Simulator 2 have much easier, more intuitive "world builder" tools than this game does.  And this is bad because:  Train Fever only generates random maps for you to play on; Cities In Motion 2 really isn't a builder game, either; and Euro Truck Simulator 2 not only has to be reconfigured to access the map building tools, but is not sold on the strength of a user's ability to create new worlds!As far as simulation?  While Train Fever currently lacks many simulation features, it still far superior in the simulation department than this game is - in spite of any ability to drive the vehicles - merely because they make the world feel "alive."  The same holds true with Cities In Motion 2, what with it's chronic traffic problems and what not.  And the Euro Truck Simulator 2 simulation is actually more forgiving than the simulation in this game.We can all agree, for instance, in real life, driving a train past a red signal is generally bad.  But there are conditions under which - even without dispatcher approval! - most railroads won't really object.  Specifically:  If you're not actually blocking other tracks!  Specifically, if one stops a foot or two too late in this game, it's enough to end the scenario.  I'm pretty sure real railroads don't work like that!In Euro Truck Simulator 2, you can sort of get away with things that would force a real life driver off the road, but it's a compromise, since alot of times, the world feels much less predictable (although it's really more predictable, once you learn it) than real life.Which brings me to general game play.I bought a Cab Forward for this game.  Beautiful model.  Beautiful locomotive.  But I can only drive it in two redneck-themed scenarios?  I can't challenge the Cajon Pass with such a beautiful machine - at least, not easily?  Wasn't the point of allowing me to buy this to give me more content to enjoy?  I have "The Empire Builder," which any rail fan recognizes as pretty much the standard configuration of any long distance Amtrak train.  Why can't I run that through something in the Cajon Pass without great difficulty?  Why is it easier to enjoy the new content in ETS2, Train Fever, and Cities In Motion 2 than in Train Simulator?In short, this game just plain fails.It has huge potential, but all that promise leads to horrible disappointment.I can not recommend this game.

content:
5, 2014
												I completely agree with you there 'over_nine_thousand', I bought the 2012 version of the game anod now it is currentyl at the 2014. What I find most annoying is the pricing of DLC and the game itself. Sure £40 is to be expected of a new game but to repeat that same charge EVERY year just so you can use the next version, don't you think they should perhaps give you a discount if you already own a version of the game, instead of making us pay another £40 just to unlock the new stuff where someone new gets everything (I don't know that fully but I have not tested this). The DLC... wow... I mean really. It is now the 2014 Summer Sales and Steam does a VERY good job at luring us in with these reductions on up to 80%! I was hoping then to maybe go to this game and buy a cheeky Locomotive Add-on with what money I have left over in my Steam Wallet. Oh but wait! Even at prices of up to 60 and 75% off on the DLC, they STILL come out at £7?! What even is that? For DLC I would expect either pennies for the cost of whats in the DLC or at that price, more from the DLC.I will only keep playing the game till I have racked up enough hours I think to have recieved my moneys worth but in other words I am really dissapointed with this game.Another point. Yes this game does do very well to amaze us with the graphics of their locomotives... but that is it. If you go into Free-Roam camera view and stray more than 5 metres away from the track, you will find a terribly under textured enviornment that is plain and boring. The same goes for towns, cars and anything else that is not a train. I would expect much more from a simulator as I do not just expect the experience of the train very good but everything around it to make the mise-en-scene.

content:
ber 26, 2014
												I am most dissapointed in this game, It's called "Train Simulator" yet there is nothing to do other then the small things that only last for 20 to 60 mins. (the longer ones are only longer due to extended tracks and you hardly need to make any stops) Once the thing is done... Game Over... No replayability here. It's just the same old same old. You cannot even drive the train for as long as you want. making stops when needed to pick up or let off passengers.Free Roam.... Is non existant as there is none. The the game is called "Train Simulator" is a laugh as you have only a limited trains to drive. They made all the other Trains DLC that are overpriced and SHOULD HAVE BEEN APART OF THE GAME.This is a like a copy from DCS Worlds. You get a few planes to try out and if you want to fly something else buy it from the DLC. At least their main game was "FREE" to try out. YOU DO NOT MAKE TAKE AWAY CONTENT THAT IS MEANT TO BE APART OF THE GAME AND PUT THEM AS DLC YOU MONEY GRABING RETRADS!! It's called "Train Simulator" TRAINS ARE MEANT TO BE IN IT.. Not all but ALOT!! Not just one, two or three. but 30 or more. and put the Special trains in as DLC. AT LEAST THAT WOULD BE BETTER!.Simulate the live experiance.. Lies. Passenages just fade in and out as they either enter or exit. I do not see a passenger entering my train and walking in the passenger car to find a seat or a seat they want. Nope. It's just pre-coded taken up seats and never gets anywhere. The train will always feel lifeless. The stations will always feel Lifeless. COMPLETE GARBAGE!And if your thinking. "Oh hey, lets just add more useless people into the station that will sort this problem out." then you are just a plain simple minded RETARD. Have you ever been the a train station? Ever been to a metro tunnel? I have and I admit, I was a little paranoid in the Metro cause of so many people. (When I visted London it was packed and noisey and very very lively.) In this game. it's just..... silence... People do not wait they just walk like idiots and dance like idiots. At least allow them to *Look at the timetable for the train, or buying drinks at the sides, or even sitting down on chairs reading newspaper or something. When train arrives they can board the train.. RATHER THEN FADING OUT!* Wanting to see people board the trains and watch it slowly fill up is APART OF THE FUN OF DRIVING A TRAIN.I do not recommend buying this game unless you really really really, want to drive just four or five different trains and even then find out that the trains do not even feel alive.To me this game feels like it is VERY MUCH DEAD.Thank you for your time in reading this rant.(I am expecting this to be taken down should the rumors of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ taking down these negative remarks on their game be true. It's a harsh world, running from it or hiding it will not make it go away. Fixing it and improving it does.)

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I'm sorry but this game is utter garbage, and it's NOT worth the money !! -Short version: The game looks ok, feels more like an arcade that a simulator (which i kind of like), has a nice concept, but is completely unoptimised! It crashes randomly, has major lag spikes and overall feels like an unfinished product rushed for a release. The devs need to make either a major update to it, or make sure TS2015 isn't anything like this game is (which I doubt, considering what I constantly read about this game) -Long version:I bought the game on the summer sale, since I had kept an eye on it for quite some time, and even though I have ~60h of playtime at the time of writing this, I actually have more that 200h of playtime but not on my steam account. Anyway, I bought it mainly because of the editor - the whole google maps overlay, the SRTM terrain data you can use and the tools the editor has alow to make incredibly accurate routes with overall very good detail. That is if the game didn't crash randomly so often. I have lost hours of content due to it not being saved and the game crashing. To counter this I started saving my route every 20-40minutes, but today, after the 4th or 5th crash for the day of the game all my layout's track had disappeared, which made me absolutely mad. Hours of my work was gone! Now, before someone says I'm doing a "rage review" or something I want to say that that was just the tip of the iceberg, which made me write this. The game is completely unstable and unoptimised and the lag spikes I get are even more often than the crashes. Yes, I could have done a backup file, but that is no excuse for a game to be this broken!! Also making your own assets is frustrating and requires you to read A LOT on the forums or other websites just so you have a basic idea of what to do.And I'm not even go on the topic for the unjustified price of the game or it's DLC...

I expected so much moreI was chasing this game for over a year. When I finally got it I was so happy. But then the horror started. Took ICE-T for a spin and I noticed it's way more bugged than it was in TS 2012. I switched to High-Speed train in UK. It was very good ride, finished scenario with Silver star. Tried another one, scenario is bugged. Thinking it's one time thing, i restarted game and tried again, same thing happened. Checking forum I saw that it's known bug but nobody is fixing it. Eventually I got stuck with only one scenery I like. At last I deleted game. Two days ago, after few months, I installed it again. I immediately remembered why I uninstalled it in the first place. I was more flexible this time, I gave chance sceneries that didn't amuse me at the begining. I took one route in Germany with DB train. Out of sudden -1800 penalty points for speeding! And limit wasn't even marked. It allowed me to go 140 and invisible limit was 60. Tried another one with Acela Express, train derailed due to intersection changed while I was passing. This is absurd. Don't buy it. I regret it.Perfect description of Dovetail Games thinking:https://i.imgflip.com/o6ykl.jpg

content:
9
												This simulator has a route that I have taken countless times in real life. They did a great job recreating not only the route but the surrounding area. I traveled the streets to look around and took a screen shot of a house. The houses look like the houses do in that area in real life. With that level opf detail in places that have nothing to do with the train or simulating it, you can imagine the quality of the actual tracks, station, loco, passanger cars, people on the platform, lights, sounds etc. The immersion is good enough for me that I no longer want to build a model of that route. I can ride that route at will. That revelation led me to wanting more routes and trains as opposed to model railways taking up space I should not be using in my house. I recommend this to anyone who has seen a train track and wondered where it ended. If that route is in Train Simulator 2017 or it's Add Ons, You will find out where that track goes and more. I also recommend this to those who would like to make their own scenery to drive the train through. From steam trains to mag-levs, the choice is yours.

content:
r 4, 2016
												I have mixed opinions about this game. First off, it isn't really a game, but a simulator. Even then the quality of simulation varies from locomotive to locomotive (will talk about this later) One thing that a lot of people here mention and what has been picked up by some tech "journalists" is that there are a couple of thousand dollars worth of DLC. At first glance, this seems insane, and it is. If you are buying all of the DLC's you are insane. What I and others believe the intention of the thousands in DLC is for users like you and me to select routes and locomotives that we like. For example, you might want to simulate the North West of England during the early 80's, and it's possible to do that. Others may want to simulate the modern day North East of the united states and it's possible to do that. If all of the DLC's were included in the base game, it would be a $2,000+ game that's over 100 GB and people would say it's too expensive and too bloated. In concept, I believe this system of fine tuning your experience is fine, and works out for everyone. If you paid attention, I used in concept instead of in practice. I've had Train Simulator since before it was even called Train Simulator and was called Railworks. In that time, it hasn't really changed that much. There have been some improvements here and there, but nothing game changing. With the DLC's though, its a different story. Once a DLC is made, that's it. It's never updated. Ever. I personally don't have them, but there are reviews of some locomotives today from people who've had the DLC since it was relaeased two years ago complaining about bugs that it's had since day 1. Another problem is the consistency of the quality. You'll find that some locomotives are super realistic, with many of the buttons and controls actually doing something like guard buzzers and windows opening, the modelling being super accurate along with the sounds. Then you'll have ones that have throttle, brake, reverser, horn and light control being on, off, or red and that's it. The models will be OK, and the graphics will be photorealistc, in the sense that someone has taken a photo of a gauge cluster in poor light and from far away, and then cut and pasted that photo on to the model. I think the real kick is that in a year or two, Dovetail will be releasing a new Train Simulator on a new engine and they will be opening up to hopefully increase the variety of DLC's

content:
r 9, 2014
												This game has so much potential but unfortunatly the developers failed to hear the rail fain suggestions.  When I went to play it for the first time the screen went black and I got an error.  Ok, this isn't a problem and I'm sure they already know about it and do a patch on it.  Well the next day it worked for me and so far it's working fine.  Which is good but they fall short on other things.  For an example the in game tutorials to teach one how to drive a train and learn everything else that goes into driving the train.  I have been noticing a lot of the tutorials seem to cut short and don't even give you a chance to finish doing the last step and it automatically congrats you and ends it.  They could easilly add train chatter into the game making it even more realistic.  Like you're heading into a yard and need to find which track the yardman wants you to dump off your cars instead of just having text or when you ask permission to let you through you could have a voice asking permission instead of having silence.  The graphics are nice and the details and the physics of each train and their variables are good.  They have major potential and I hope the developers do listen to the fans because the game does have strong potential.  But so far it seems that the developers are really missing the point with the rail fans and if they continue to not listen it'll be like shooting themselves in their own foot.  Also, to me right now the price tag for this game isn't worth it.

content:
2, 2016
Product received for free
I made a ♥♥♥♥-brained review before, now I'm being serious.Also rewritten the review, read again then consider changing your rating...This review is made as an example and may not be considered a review. Comments are much welcome as to point out any errors or to state opinion.This game would've been great...I would've said, "This game has potential..." but no. Too cliche, and this game will never get better.This game can be put as "half-baked" or that it's almost there.What this game should be like...SCS's Euro Truck Sim 2. The game has a decent amount of content already. Most of it's DLC is really cheap, and are visual, like paint jobs and acessories. You can find free counterparts of DLC on the workshop including extras like trucks, trailers, visuals (HUD elements, bloom removal, FX, etc.), buildngs, economy, and logos.For comparison, the Workshop items in this game requires atleast 2 DLC each, and are limited to the cliche scenarios (drive this, look at traffic, then some text to spice it up or potentially give a story, and thats the usual) and if you're lucky, a basic route.Another one:There is a franchise called "Trainz" where the content are in MILLIONS and many of them are FREE. While you get none in updates, you can chose to download all you want. How they make money? Charge for the games themselves (like most games do), and provide a paid subscription service to boost DL speeds. They also include third-party paid content as official DLC. Many which you get free in certain version (similar to this game). Compare this to DTG. There a very few third-party free items, and DTG hasn't released official free content (not including the yearly versions). You might get some free reskins (of DLC trains) and a rocket train (you derail alot).ConclusionMany reasons why this game is bad.1/10 almost there.

												I am not one who normally writes a review. I recently grabbed MSTS from the shelf it has sat on for over 10 years. I bought it and never used it. I found it to be fun and an enjoyable break from sim racing. My wife wanted to get Train Simulator 2014 for me so I would have something that worked better and could add content to easier.What a mistake this has been. One of the tutorial missions/ task running the 395 high speed train I have never gotten it to work. I ALWAYS fail at the end. I even got a video from YouTube and the guy that posted it said that he usally fails that task as well. He also said that TS 2014 was VERY buggy. I had heard that before purchasing as well but chalked it up to the usual gripping that I found so often in forums. I should have listened. The problem with the 395 train was just the beginning.I tried, and just completed a career job, and not only failed it didn't really give me any possibility of not failing. The train coming down from Donner Pass would just take off even though I'm on the brakes. The dynamic brakes don't work. Go ahead and apply them, you will only speed up. They did it in MSTS and they do it here as well.The bottom line is this. Unless you just have to have this title, OR you just HAVE to run a train simulator save your money and go and get a different game. I was going to add in quite a bit of extras during the Steam Summer Sale that is going on now until June 30, 2014, that will not be happening now. I guess I'll just take the money and go and get some more stuff for FSX or more sim racing equipment. There is a lot of gear from Fanatec that I wanted to get.

content:
ry 6, 2014
												Hello,This game have a nice idea, but implementation - just a pile of something very unappealing. Problems:1. Game load. It is ultimately slow. About 1 minute to load save/track (for comparison: on my system it takes about 6-7 seconds to load Skyrim save in the worst case).2. You can't have more than one save at a time. Yes, really, just one save point. Forgot about possibility to play short 20 min race when long 2h is ongoing.3. Image quality. I've played TS at 2008. Really, nothing changed. Same boring non-interesting picture. Skyrim at the High+ settings at the same hardware just flights. TS at Medium became sluggish. And looks like game from year 2000.4. Tons of errors. Did you see this "max speed is 60" sign? Don't believe, really it's 40 and have you speed penalty, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! Do you see this green semaphore? It's red, really. So, have automatic emergency brake + penalties, of course. Also train can stuck at station at any random moment, and you will be unable to move. Only one workaround - load saved game (1 minute to load and only one save point, you remember).5. Track builder. Worst ever seen. Developers should pray to the picture of Chris Sawyer 3 times a day, before, in the middle and after work, may be it helps.6. Actually, it's not a game. It's a store. Game trying to force you to buy a some DLC at the any screen, any moment of the time. Very annoying. I want to play. I do not want to buy this forsaken "Latest offer"! As a consequence, very poor initial set of tracks and vehicles. Wanna play a steam loco? Welcome to DLC. Wanna play "This nice track from game review"? Welcome to DLC again. And price tags... mmm... from 13 and up to more than 20 euros per single vehicleor single track? Easily.Conclusion:Just a junk game. Wasted time, money and bytes of your hard drive. It feels like developers just want to gain as much money as possible from this game, but they do not want to make good game at all.Have a nice day,--P.S. May be my review is too offensive, but I'm really disappointed. My expectations was too high for this game.

content:
y 14, 2012
												This game is absolutely amazing. The five minute loading screens are such a great aspect because it allows you to become moist and wet for the trains. And when the trains arrive, it's like the pope rose from the grave and gave everyone high-fives. The gameplay is absolutely amazing, the simple mode is a little easy, so Expert is where this game really shines. The expert mode uses three levers, movement, direction, and brake and it also comes with an amazing usage of nine camera angles. That's right, NINE CAMERA ANGLES. WHERE DO THEY EVEN HAVE TIME TO PROGRAM ALL THESE ANGLES?! The anti-piracy script put into the game during the loading screens is honestly needed, a game such as this needs to be protected from those nasty pirates that try to ruin game businesses with their cheap ways. Waiting three extra minutes per loading screen for a two minute gameplay is a small price to pay to make sure the pirates don't steal an amazing game such as this. Have I mentioned the graphics? 11/10 GOTY

content:
19, 2016
												I highly recommand you to not get this game, because after the 2016 update they now tell you that to get more of the fun such as steam trains and other addons you have to pay around $30 to get the full game. That is not worth it at all because other trainz, like trainz 2006 or such has more of options of steam, desiel, electric trains and you dont have to pay extra from them. Now many would say you dont have to buy the DLCS since it update for "free", well sure that is true but what diffrence does it make when nothing much changes because from the start of 2013 on this game, no steam and till now, no steam and not much diffrent maps. This is supported by OfficialNerdCubed in his recent video of this game. He mentioned that one of that maps havent changed since 2011, and it surely isnt like that today, so he had to go buy some DLCS just to make it more monder. What is the point of buying this game, when it doesn't give new things just for free. There are many and I mean many DLCS, but if they just keep it the same like no new engines or maps even updating them for free, it just gets dull. What I mean by it is that there a fourmula to every game and adding new things with new ways to play. Such as Fallout 4, it had a few new things such as crafting and building homes and etc, when you see TS.2017 not much of a changed. This is one or maybe more of the many reasons why this game is hated alot. And the Workshop isnt so great either you have to buy a certain model for the workshop item to work. Other trainz just let you download it free on any website that makes trains and you dont have to buy anything extra or such. And the map making in this game is just part of the problum in this game, maybe even half of it. Like i said downloading custom maps in workshops dosent do any good if you dont buy the maps for it in the game. Trainz new era is something I haven't got yet but I bet you its alot more better than this game.  Now I would changed my thoughts if it just let the game have the new things in it and not just put it as a addon you have to pay. This game really give up and started to be a cash grab simulator, a single train like at tank engine shouldn't be 25 or 30 dollars. It really put this game to shame like no other, its sad enough that it cant have the same feel of what is like in the older trainz games. Sure maybe they run out of ideas and dont know what to do, or give up completly, but thats no way to just end a wonderful franchise it had in the past. And the one thing I will be sure of that this game won't get a single penny out of me, but if time goes on and if something great might happen to this game then ill rethink about it. Till then im leaving this game to the unstalled ones. And I highly recommend you guys to get trainz new era or go back to the old trainz games, and try it out and see what I was talking about. Sure it might have lower graphis or not great realizim, but its better to play a game thats about 30 or 40 dollars than paying a thousand dollars for many DLCS in this game. Lets hope things will get better and if not, then no hope trying to give this game another run.

content:
er 14, 2014
												I have mixed feelings for this game. I want to be in love with it,but I just can't no matter how hard I try. Although the game looks amazing and the selection of trains is rather good,there are just too many things wrong with it. First,all the missions are SUPER picky. You could have a 100% perfect scenario and only make one little mistake,and the game forces you to try again if you want to truly complete it. Also,the train controls are weird and it never seems that your train can hold a constant speed,which makes it difficult to maintain speed limits.But by far the biggest problem with the game is DLC. Oh. My. God. This game is upwards of $60,so you would think you would get an exstensive amount of content included,right? Wrong. You get only a few trains and routes,and you have to pay for everything else. Which would be fine...if it wasn't so damn expensive! Most DLC is priced between $20-40,and the fact that I have to pay that much for one thing after I've already payed quite a bit for the game is absurd. This is the main killing factor for me and it prevents from enjoying Train Simulator as much as I could.Don't get this game. If your looking for a good train simulation game,try the Trainz series. All of them are fun,have loads of content right out of the box,have free community created DLC,and are a one time purchase. Maybe if my problems with the game were resolved,it wouldn't be so bad. But for now,I stand by my opinion strongly.

content:
7, 2014
												I don't expect a train simulator to be a work of visual art, on par with things like Bioshock or Far Cry.The graphics?  Uninspired.The game mechanics?     It's definitely not going to win any awards for fidelity.But when we (my son and I) manage to pick a switch trying to get something moved in a freight yard.... and watch a passing intermodal train fly off the rails as if picked up by an invisible unrendered tornado?    Yeah, we lost it.     The fact that the game engine allowed something to happen like that?     I'm just done.   I can't take the game seriously anymore. This is the first game I regret buying.     I'm sorely tempted to ask for a refund, and list "The game just sucks" as the reason, but I know that's insufficient justification for such actions.Even at Steam Sale prices I feel cheated, and I can't see how the developers justify their normal prices for the base game, let alone the DLC.\

content:
ber 2, 2014
												I grew up playing Southern Belle on the C64 and I remember when MS Train Simulator was released and I imported it from America to the UK to play it on\close to release date (where it was released in America before the UK).For me the biggest problem with this game is it does not fully support the Raildriver Train Controller and only half the trains I have work properly with it. The company which makes raildriver acknowledges the issues and hopes this game will be better supported in future releases, but also recommends a competing train simulator which does have full native support built in for Raildriver (perhaps thats why native support is not included with this game, which is a huge shame). The company who create Train Simulator just ignore you and the entire rest of the people who buys this game and its add ons it seems.The game is buggy to say the least and some of the official routes are supplied with scenarios that just don't work or were created for earlier versions of Train Simulator and have been broken in later version with no fixes or updates. For example I bought GEML London to Ipswich - two of the supplied scenarios do not include the needed trains to play the route and at some stations passengers are walking inside the platform. Some platforms are not long enough to fit all carriages of 12 car trains and many of the branch lines on the route have not been included. Many of the free scenarios on the workshop require you to purchase other routes and trains, and for buggy and broken content the game DLC is far too overpriced with some routes costing the same as the game costs, and items rarely appear in steam sales. Every so often you will find mis-matched bundles including a route and a train which includes scenarios designed for a different route - A very cheeky way to encourage people to then buy more trains which contain scenarios for the route they have just bought and the route for the train they have just bought.Compared to modern games the engine is beginning to look slightly dated as well, but instead of spending time on improving these (I read somewhere the next version will have big improvements to the skies!) the developer should listen to the community and its players and fix broken scenarios and known bugs. I am sure the game has lost fans and community due to its flaws and them being ignored, which is a shame for everyone.There is another 3rd company creating routes for this game which they are listening to feedback and creating fixes for their products, so I am going to try a few of them.I's buy this in a sale if you like this kind of a simulator, but only pay full price if you really love train simulation and are prepered for the issues.

content:
ber 2, 2014
												I was lucky in that I bought this game when it was owned by Railworks. Back then the game worked very well, or at least I never ran into any issues with the game.Unfortunately TS has had the misfortune of being bought by a company that is all about breaking games and charging people for those broken games. Now, a lot of career scenario's, especially the older ones and the ones that come with the base game, are not possible to complete satisfactorily. Scheduling is unrealistic now so that even if you can control your speed to minute precision, it's impossible not to run later and later as the scenario's progress.If you want a hideous reputation for timekeeping and an occasional speeding penalty because the overlay doesn't accurately display the speed limits, then this is the game for you.If, however, you want a realistic train simulator that you don't have to treat like a real life Formula One on tracks, wait until another Rail Simulator is released, hopefully by a company that has an interest in the railway experience, and take your chance with that.

												I like this game. Decent graphics, good gameplay if you like trains.. alot.Why am i giving this a thumbs down? Some bread crumbs and a raw peice of meat. The game comes with 3 maybe 4 maps to drive around on, i was so disgusted with this game i refuse to play it now so i cant be quite sure how many maps.Engines. I expected this game would have a good selection of enigines to explore but i was left in shock with the EXTREMELY limited content.Do you know how to get more engines and maps to play on? WHO IN HELL WANTS TO LAY OUT THAT KIND OF MONEY TO DRIVE ONE TRAIN?!?!?Well, maybe you think it is worth it, okay fine. BUT answer me this, how do you feel about laying out $1,889.15 in money just to enjoy all the features that another game will give you for the cost of less than $60? Oh let me be clear this price was posted during the holiday sale when ALL dlcs are half off or more.Wait, what is that other train game you are talking about? That other game is Trainz simulator 12. content:
ber 2, 2014
												I grew up playing Southern Belle on the C64 and I remember when MS Train Simulator was released and I imported it from America to the UK to play it on\close to release date (where it was released in America before the UK).For me the biggest problem with this game is it does not fully support the Raildriver Train Controller and only half the trains I have work properly with it. The company which makes raildriver acknowledges the issues and hopes this game will be better supported in future releases, but also recommends a competing train simulator which does have full native support built in for Raildriver (perhaps thats why native support is not included with this game, which is a huge shame). The company who create Train Simulator just ignore you and the entire rest of the people who buys this game and its add ons it seems.The game is buggy to say the least and some of the official routes are supplied with scenarios that just don't work or were created for earlier versions of Train Simulator and have been broken in later version with no fixes or updates. For example I bought GEML London to Ipswich - two of the supplied scenarios do not include the needed trains to play the route and at some stations passengers are walking inside the platform. Some platforms are not long enough to fit all carriages of 12 car trains and many of the branch lines on the route have not been included. Many of the free scenarios on the workshop require you to purchase other routes and trains, and for buggy and broken content the game DLC is far too overpriced with some routes costing the same as the game costs, and items rarely appear in steam sales. Every so often you will find mis-matched bundles including a route and a train which includes scenarios designed for a different route - A very cheeky way to encourage people to then buy more trains which contain scenarios for the route they have just bought and the route for the train they have just bought.Compared to modern games the engine is beginning to look slightly dated as well, but instead of spending time on improving these (I read somewhere the next version will have big improvements to the skies!) the developer should listen to the community and its players and fix broken scenarios and known bugs. I am sure the game has lost fans and community due to its flaws and them being ignored, which is a shame for everyone.There is another 3rd company creating routes for this game which they are listening to feedback and creating fixes for their products, so I am going to try a few of them.I's buy this in a sale if you like this kind of a simulator, but only pay full price if you really love train simulation and are prepered for the issues.

content:
29
												I started playing this years ago and it was fine. Today i started it up again and of course there is a new intro video. I must've missed a few yearly update of intro videos because this one looks so fine and impressive BUT it's stuttering like mad! Intro video stuttering? C'mon, i don't remember having problems with intro videos in any game that meets the minimum system requirements.Like i said, had no performance problems before. It seems to be a common problem now. Many people reported having the same issue and they have rigs many levels better than mine. I can only assume that all the updates are caused by either poor optimization or that the minimum specs have been raised or that the game engine is not suitable for large scale world maps.Wish i can opt for not receiving updates and roll-back to previous versions. As the state of stuttering now stands, i'm wary of spending any more time in this game. Sorry guys, i cannot recommend this game despite being the only game i know that offers free lifetime updates. Coupled with the fact that it's a DLC fest at high prices with inconsistent quality, i honestly cannot recommend this game to anyone except for elitist gamers and i doubt even they are free from stuttering issues.4/10 buy at your own risk.Addendum: I had thought of buying the Premium Upgrade DLC pack, that item is now removed from the cart.Update March 31 2017Guess what? Turns out the the intro video is only a 129 Mb ogv file found in the data\video sub-folder. OMG i thought it was a humongous 3-5 GB file with 50,000 kbps bit rate! VLC player is able to play it without any stuttering whatsoever. I had also thought that the game rendered the intro video in real-time with in-game engine and assets. Must be some kinda new conspiracy to scare potential buyers or some kinda prank?Anyway i went into the Tutorial again and it was smooth, no stuttering. So i'm buying the premium upgrade DLC pack after all and changing my recommendation to erm Maybe. Even though there might still be stuttering later in career mode or in some maps, i'm gonna take the risk because there's no problem so far in the Tutorial gameplay.Oh BTW, Quicktime is no longer supported by Apple as it's already built-in to Windows 7 and above and most modern browsers. It also has security vulnerabilities which prompted Mozilla to disable it in their Firefox browser. QT is not needed to play the intro video and re-installing it doesn't alleviate the stuttering issue so i dunno what's wrong with the game; probably inefficient code.Still not recommended though based on numerous reports by other users. Perhaps 6Gb GPU in SLI mode is required to eliminate stuttering and there's still the issue or DLC fest which can cost above $3k in total. Heck with that amount i could upgrade to a gaming desktop!!! and buy Star Citizen to boot. OK jokes aside, seems like the developers are trying to build the entire world rail network with all the DLCs.I'm bumping it up one notch to 5/10. Probably need a monster PC to get best results out of this game. No sorry it's not a game it's serious business.

content:
ber 3, 2016
												Unless it's on sale, don't get it. I've played it for going on 5 years now, and within the past 2 years, the quality of the game has gone down drastically. Pros - - When it actually works, the scenarios can be quite fun and challenging. - Community is quite friendly and helpful- Abundance of freeware available if you know where to look for it- SOME of the payware is worth shelling out 20 bucks over. (See "Cons" section)Neutral points - - Can run well if given 4 gigs to run on, but unless you're a hard core gamer, chances are you ONLY have 4 gigs to work with Cons -- Low FPS - Lags out whenever the graphic detail is turned up any higher than "lowest"- Graphical Details - Expanding on the FPS problem, the graphics aren't THAT good whenever you do have it set on the highest settings. Loading times are almost an hour as well- Expensive DLC - There's over $3000 worth of DLC in the store, most of it older than dirt, which would usually be under "TS Classics". A single locomotive model will usually run you about $20. Unless it's in the "TS Pro" range, do not get it unless it's on sale, and even at that, only if you REALLY want it. The routes may sometimes be worth it, but even then, look at the individual reviews before you even really contemplate buying it.- Horrible customer service - Outright ignored crash reports to the point where I was ready to throw my computer out the window and yell profanities at it. (Last time I did this was with No Man's Sky. My PlayStation still has to have weekly therapy sessions.)'- Game crashing - 99.9% of the time, it crashes to the point where I either: 1 - I have to restart my PC, or 2 - Wait for it to unfreeze and close it manually.Overall - .5/10 - DTG: Fix the bleeding game, and you'll make me and tons of people more happy. I don't have high hopes for Train Sim World with this game being in the state that it's in, or, even getting this game fixed, in all honesty. I also cast my vote for this game winning the "DLC costs more than a car award".

content:
ber 23, 2015
												Dostoevsky, in his grand work 'The Brothers Karamazov,' had a scene where a man comes out of a pub and fills his cart with drunkards.  His poor horse, who cannot lift the weight of the people, collapses.  The drunkard owner goes on to flog his horse to death, much to the entertainment of the drunken publicans on the cart.  They cheer him on as he whips, beats and curses the dying animal until it collapses and dies, straining to the bitter end. It is a difficult, unpleasant, indeed horrific scene to read.  But it is as nowhere near as shocking as watching Dovetail flog this dead horse.  This poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ should have been put down years ago, but it keeps coming back from the dead, uglier and more pathetic then ever.  Year on year Dovetail squats down and pinches off the same old turd, almost apologetically, shamefaced with cap-in-hand.  Each year it charges the same exorbitant price for its ropey addons.  The difference between Dostoevsky was that, despite the 'Brothers Karamazov' being a work of fiction, there was an element of real-world grit to it.  You could almost believe it was real.  There's nothing convincing or realistic about Train Simulator 2016,Its probably time to put a bullet in the skull of this poor animal.  Let it die in peace.

												Summing it up, yes, I do reccomend it. But now for the details. First of all, these American trains are made by a British company. I have noticed that by the work they have done both trains, they have seemed to do more detailing on the British trains. With the American trains, about 65%-70% of the sounds are recycled. They put the wrong horns on the wrong train types. Example, a K5L on a P32AC-DM. Their prices are highway robbery. $40.00 for a 31 mile route! On some trains, the braking systems take 1 minute and 32 seconds (Yes, I have timed it) to release which make a painful experience. I have also found that you will get multiple game crashes in less than 30 minutes. Now graphics wise, you have to have a beast of a computer to handle this at the high settings!

content:
12, 2016
												I'd rather leave a mixed review, but my advice is that you shouldn't pay full price for this game or its DLC, wait until it comes out on sale. The DLC tends to be quite glitchy and low quality, considering you could pay £20+ for some of the DLCs. The game itself runs OK, although it does drop frames even when graphics settings are turned down (that's with a GTX 960 2GB card) but that is probably due to my setup.So, bottom line is if you have to buy it, wait for the price to come down in a sale. If you do buy it, you'll be downloading DLC within about a week, since there's not very much to play in the base game. If you're considering getting all the DLC, you probably consider spending the money on becoming a real train driver, it would cost about the same!

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 17, 2015
												I have been using Train Simulator back since the original was release by Microsoft.  Many reviewers have voiced various complaints concerning physics, various content (sounds) and DLC costs.  I can understand purists with the dynamics and sounds, which I can take issue with as well, but with DLC, that is an individual choice. The basic game gives us different Country systems to try, and the DLC adds to that enjoyment. However, no one says you have to purchase EVERYTHING. I am from the US and only purchase items that interest me, mostly American units and routes , although a couple of others that look interesting. Folks from other countries I would imagine do the same, so the argument the the DLC is outrageously expensive is subjective to those that want everything in thier collection. The only concession is the reskinning charges which should be minimal or provided as an update to already purchased items.I am not so much a hard core player as a casual player, so with that being said, I do like Train Simulator enough to upgrade my computer when necessary. I found no faults with casual railroading, and since space limited me to not have a model railroad, this is the next bext thing, and better in some areas.Train Simulator is enjoyable and a great pasttime,  if you enjoy railroading. Thanks to the Dovetail folks for providing a very pleasant way to spend some hours.

er 22, 2016
												Even though it has its minor problems once in awhile it has brought me hundreds and hundreds of hours of pure entertainment in the contrary. Having no other experience with other train simulators I’d still have to say this is well built when it comes to doing tasks in a scenario, enjoying a quick drive with your choice of train and its consist or even creating your own routes and scenarios and sharing it with the respectable community. Also when it comes to some of the DLCs they might be overpriced but this is a hobby, if you want more the options are there so you spend as you please. Plus sales are a thing and if a DLC is a rip off then it can still be refunded so I don't see the problem.People tell me it’s just a waste of money and then they go spend much more than I have on their favorite game/hobby that I would deem a waste so their point is a bit invalid. But they can think what they want because riding the rails is what matters to me.

content:
r 3, 2015
												Just dont. Remember the days of MSTS and Trainz, fun right. This is a sub standard game at a beyond premium price. A cash cow. I hope all involved starve and get cancer. Go on, kill yourselves you greedy slimy ♥♥♥♥♥♥s!EDIT/Clarification: (12 of 21 found it helpful prior to this next bit) This game is really Railworks, very little has changed since 2009.The basic bundled content has not been improved, only year on year they will bundle a couple of different locos with matching stock and a route. The main problem with this is again its not improved. At all! Plants are 2D and follow facing you as you go past, enter a tunnel and a mear shadow is cast.Smoke is unaffected by a bridge, it just floats through the texture. This is all very very outdated, early 2000s stuff.The world has moved on a lot, it's simply unacceptable for this price.Secondly, considering the poor quality of the game with its ancient engine. It is not fair to charge per single DLC, as they are basic, at that price. I stress that not long ago at all we had modding communitys making anything and everything at a incredibly reasonable monthly subscriptions, this was dial-up days. A lot was on par with what this game is selling as DLCs. Its a locked eco system. And when they do update the game engine or finally write one worth the price tag all of these DLCs will be worthless. The developers have you by the balls, and mark my words unless they intend to just rebrand this forever, your £10 per train route whatever is going to be worthless and you will need to start again. The game is far from a product, but while people have a passion and money to burn I guess they are sitting happy at the expense of us. 765,611 people own this game, they have 709 DLCs, profiteering is not the word!https://steamdb.info/app/24010/

content:
ry 17, 2016
												I really tried... I really tried du have a good experience with this game. Being an experienced Trainz Simulator 2012 player, I quickly saw how flawed the physics engine in this game was. There is sooooooo many things that don't work, frankly. sometimes I have passengers on my platform, sometimes not. The objects, house, trees, etc. doesn't even snap to the ground so you have to put evey single object you place down to the ground, and then if you decide to morph the terrain, you have to arrange the objects AGAIN! ... sigh... When I lay tracks down they are completely fixed. It is almost impossible to join two sets of track with eachother, and why are the tracks not flexible? Only God knows why... Furthermore the palette is rubbish, how am I to paint realistically when the brush paints in big squares so the ground looks all jagged up. One thing, you can only place turnouts on completely straight track, which makes the route making even more tidious, bordering to impossible. Where in the world today are there not turnouts on curved track??? This game advocates 2016 in it's title but it functions worse than the 2012 equivalent. The ONLY good thing to come out of this game is the beautiful locomotives. In the end you sit there and think if only you could move the trains to another game so you actually could have some decent play time. That's how bad this game is.I am so disappointed. I had high hopes for the game, but my expectations where shattered.I don't recommend buying this game

content:
ber 25, 2014
												Ok, so I just recently purchased this game after watching the Youtuber DaSquirrelsNuts play this and at that time it looked absolutely brilliant.  Excited, I quickly purchased, installed and started playing. Initially, it was all well, until the next morning, after rebooting my computer the checkmarks for my career was missing. The points and XP were still there, so does the badge you collect as you drive more trains, but with the missing checkmarks, it's hard to keep track of which scenario you've had and hadn't done yet! So I skimped over that small blunder, assuring myself that it's an unimportant non gameplay intruding problem, and oh boy was I wrong. So on the second day, as I was playing in career mode in a Class 801 (Scenario: The 801 at 8:01), the game started out fine, but my nightmare began once I've reached a red light in Welwyn Garden City Down Fast (opening up the maps indicated an unpowered Class 365 on the tracks). So I waited, and waited (all while spamming the TAB key to request permission to pass) until roughly 30 minutes of waiting before I got the permission to pass. So I told myself, all should be fine now, and I was wrong, again!. Due to this massive delay with the red lights, the timeliness penalty I had was approximately -109000 (can't quite remember the exact figure). Again I told myself, maybe there shall be a big sum of bonus points near the end to neutralize this blunder, so I pushed ahead.  So as the train was thundering to it's final stop, the lights were all green with a breathtaking scenery to sooth my rage, all is once more well in the world of TS2015. Until suddenly, right on my tracks, slowy emerging from the foggy snowy weather was a stationary Class 365.  As I was sitting there, the train approaching it's inevitable end, I pondered, WHAT THE HELL IS WRONG WITH THIS GAME!!!! There was no warning from the lights nor the AWS system! The lights were all green for goodness' sake! Get this game at your own risk honestly, I do have the save file for the 801 mission stated in this review if you think I was pulling you leg. Dovetail, GET YOUR S**T TOGETHER!!!!

The US First Class Edition includes as follows: "Includes 4 items: Train Simulator, Train Simulator: Feather River Canyon Route Add-On, Train Simulator: North Jersey Coast Line Route Add-On, Train Simulator: Soldier Summit Route Add-On"  Great...  Then you look at the BASE GAME, the FIRST THING LISTED IN THE DESCRIPTION!!!  Train Simulator on it's own is supposed to include 4 different routes, says so in the Steam description.  TS2017 INCLUDES LGV MARSEILLE - AVIGNON, NORTH JERSEY COAST LINE, HAMBURG - LUBECK RAILWAY, SOUTH WALES COSTAL.  And on the next line states "Train Simulator 2017 Standard Edition includes four fantastic real-world routes:" etc, etc.  Where are my other 3 routes?  The non-US routes are nowhere to be found.  So I have to choose UK or US at time of purchase?  That isn't right!!  Have I been ripped off?  Yes, I believe so.  $6000+ in DLC?  You have got to be kidding.  Give me what I paid for and leave me alone.  Not to mention that the 3 routes missing are $39.99 each in the Steam store.  I am sorry train fans.  Spend your money on a model railroad.  Not this.

content:
y 1
												English(Deutsch weiter unten):Train Simulator aka Railworks - the name doesn´t matter, the program is out for some years and still hasn´t become better, but even worse.Where to begin with?At first there would be the power hunger for just average graphics. My PC is not the issue - with i7 6700K, 16GB RAM, R390X and SSD drive it is strong enough to handle newer games.However Railworks makes it necessary to reduce the graphics by a large amount so that it even looks more mediocre than before. And it is still plagued by ugly aliasing.Maybe the game works better on Nvidia GPUs - but then it is just impudence as AMD is an equal competitor to Nvidia.But graphics is not everything.No, the program is also a joke in other aspects. Some versions ago they added this ridiculous shaking of the cab which you can´t turn off - this is NOT realistic and would make any real train derail. Guys, it is a train on rails, not a plane!Then there is the steering of the program. Using the keyboard feels unresponsive and mouse steering is just mere moving of the cursor. Yawn.Also the scenarios aren´t good. You only get a very basic set of them and they aren´t exciting. And especially the german routes are the same old stuff already released years ago for the MSTS, but then much better.The activities are also nonsense and badly scripted, so not enjoyable at all.The carrier mode is just a joke, who cares about a score for driving a train?The rolling stock is also of bad quality. We got diesel locomotives that sound like a lawn mower and the class 143 sounds even worse than the oldest one for MSTS - like some air conditioning.Railworks wants to follow in the steps of the Microsoft Train Simulator, but it will never reach that goal.It will never have this large base of routes and rolling stock as the classic.Also because of the outrageous pricing. 13,99 € for a single locomotive(!) or nearly 30 bucks for a route with small size are rip-off.In MSTS times you paid 19,99 € for a route and it was much bigger than these for Railworks.No wonder that there aren´t any good developing companies like German Railroads interested in making content for this.You can buy a TGV route with 30 minutes of riding time - laughable. There is another TGV route with nearly 3 hours travel time available for free(!) for MSTS/Open Rails.Overall this game and it´s content aren´t even worth buying it when on sale.I rather recommend(especially for people interested in german routes): Get some addons for the MSTS and Open Rails(freeware) as modern MSTS version, then you have better graphics, performance and much more fun as this half-hearted collection of mediocre undersized routes and lackluster rolling stock with it´s bad controls and performance including the noddy-shaky cab view. And if you want more realism get the freeware Loksim 3D or the more expensive but even more detailed Zusi.----------------------------Deutsch:Train Simulator aka Railworks - egal welcher Name, das Programm dümpelt schon seit Jahren vor sich dahin und wird nicht besser, eher schlechter.Womit fange ich an?Da wäre erstmal der enorme Leistungsbedarf für allenfalls mittelmäßige Grafik. An meinem PC liegt es nicht - der ist mit i7 6700K, 16GB RAM und einer R390X nebst SSDs durchaus stark genug für anspruchsvollere Titel, die ansonsten ja auch gut laufen.Nur Railworks erfordert die Reduzierung der Details um ein beträchtliches Maß, damit es überhaupt erträglich läuft. Dennoch ist die Grafik von häßlichen Aliasing-Artefakten geplagt.Ob es eventuell daran liegt, daß das Programm eher Nvidia-affin ist? Wenn ja, ist das eine unfaire Benachteiligung von Käufern von AMD-Grafikkarten, schließlich ja ein gleichberechtigter Wettbewerber.Aber Grafik ist nicht alles.Nein, das Programm ist im Großen und Ganzen auch so unbrauchbar und macht keinen Spaß.Vor einigen Versionen hat man z.B. das lächerliche Führerstandsruckeln eingefügt - wir sitzen hier aber nicht in einem Flugzeug! Das Ganze ist unrealistisch und unpassend. Bei dem Gewackel würde ja jedes Fahrzeug entgleisen.Dann wäre da noch die Steuerung. Tastatur ist viel zu schwammig, Maussteuerung reduziert das Ganze auf Hin- und Hergeschiebe von den immer gleichen Schaltflächen. Gähn.Auch die Szenarien überzeugen nicht. Standardmäßig enthalten sind nur wenige Strecken, davon sowieso einige der Marke Asbach uralt, die schon zu MSTS-Zeiten umgesetzt wurden - und schon damals deutlich besser.Die vorhandenen Aufgaben sind ebenso Quarks - schlecht geskriptet und alles andere als vergnüglich.Der Karrieremodus ist derbe unnötig, wozu sollte man Punkte für das Fahren eines Zuges bekommen?Das Rollmaterial ist ein Witz, die Dieselloks hören sich an wie ein Rasenmähertraktor und wann es endlich mal eine 143 mit anständigem Sound in der virtuellen Eisenbahnwelt unabhängig vom Programm gibt, steht wohl auch in den Sternen. Die von Railworks hört sich auch nur an wie eine Klimaanlage auf mittlerer Stufe.Railworks möchte quasi in die Fußstapfen des MSTS treten, was jedoch nicht mal im Ansatz gelingt.Das Programm wird nie den Umfang und die Spielbarkeit des Klassikers erreichen.Dazu trägt auch die dreiste Preispolitik bei. Man läßt sich ja jeden Kleinkram vergolden, eine einzelne Lok für 13,99 € ist echt unverschämt und daß Addons in der Regel sowieso knapp 30 Tacken kosten, ebenso. Das kann man nur als pure Abzocke bezeichnen.Früher für den MSTS waren eher 19,99 € pro Addon die Regel, und dafür bekam man in der Regel auch wirklich was geboten.Es wundert nicht, daß sich z.B. Qualitätshersteller wie German Railroads bislang gar nicht für Railworks haben blicken lassen.Wenn ich sehe, daß man hier eine TGV-Strecke vom Umfang von einer halben Stunde kaufen kann - lachhaft. Für den MSTS gibt es eine andere und sehr gut gemachte TGV-Strecke mit ca. 3 Stunden Fahrzeug als Freeware(!).Der ganze angebotene Krempel ist es nicht mal im Sale wert, gekauft zu werden.Es gibt jedenfalls deutlich bessere Alternativen zu Railworks. Holt euch lieber die MSTS-Addons für wenig Geld und Open Rails(kostenlos) als moderne MSTS-Alternative, das ist grafisch dann auch im moderneren Look und macht deutlich mehr Spaß als diese halbgare Ansammlung von mageren Strecken, schlechtem Rollmaterial mitsamt miserabler Steuerung und Wackeldackel-Führerstand. Und wer realistische Zugsicherungssysteme will, findet mit Loksim 3D(kostenlos) und Zusi(anspruchsvoller und kostet auch was) auch bessere Alternativen.

												The game can be fun to play, especially to try and understand how boring some parts of driving a train can be, and then realising why trains crash on occasion - if I had to sit there doing that all day, then I think even I would speed round corners; just for the hell of it.  And there is an element of skill involved in the game that takes some learning, for which you need to take time and put in the effort.  Overall, I enjoyed the small amount of gameplay that I have put in, but cannot recomend the game fully because it is incomplete - to have a usable game, and really progress as a driver, you have to have the relevant tracks, and maybe even the trains.  However to get these, you have to pay extortionate amounts of money through extra purchases, and then, BUYER BEWARE, you purchase some items that, in the small print, has a section that says you need another line to be able to play the line that you just purchased !!! Yes, I fell into this trap, paid £12, or thereabouts, for an 8 mile section of track that I wanted to try - only to find out that I need the £25 main section to be able to play it - this despite the fact that I have a retail version of the game - but that retail pack does not include that specific section of mainline - SO BE WARNED, THE GAME CAN ACTUALLY BE FUN, BIT ITS THE EXTRA CHARGES, REQUIRED TO GET A REAL GAME PLAY GOING, THAT WILL PUT YOU OFF.

er 5, 2016
												Got this from humble bundle in the one dollar category. +1Beginning cinema is 2 minute advertisement of TS patting its own back for what a good job its done. -1Loading screen is a 3 minute advertisement for Train Sim World and related products. -1Settings menu can't be accessed while in game, so after you realize the 720p default setting cuts off an inch or so of your HUD, you'll have to restart the first mission. -1My game crashed from an alt-tab out, but refused to fully close for about 10 minutes, ignoring alt-f4 and end task commands . -1Highest quality graphics setting looks like it was rendered with the half-life engine. -1First mission has a 50/50 chance of glitching if your train comes to a complete stop where the throttle no longer works. -1(yes, I double checked-it's not in neutral, pressure brakes are released, hand brake is also released. throttle correctly displays, makes the start up noise, but the train is frozen).This game had real potential. ...which makes me all the more disappointed. : (

content:
4, 2015
												Brought this game as the screenshots and videos seemed to do it justice...but no, sorry they didn't.I'm so glad steam started doing the refund option! Because I would be gutted and so dissapointed with the purchase otherwise and it would not get played. I did give it a chance however (clocked 4 hours of gameplay most of that spent on the loading screen)The actually gameplay was okay, and the graphics were good but.. there was something missing. If you are a true train enthusiast this would appeal to you highly, but I like simulators but really didn't like this one found it very slow and  boring.Took ages for the game to actually load I must of waited 10 mins and still did not load (and no, its not the hardware in my computer), on top of that extremely annoying music on the load screen. Not the biggest issue but one of the nigly annoying ones, as well as I didn't like the fact that there were ads for Steam on the loading screens. You also rely heavily on the mouse at first, the tutorials never mention a keyboard alternative, Only until the point I actually looked at the controls and saw that you could use the keyboard this would of made the game even worse. So to conclude unless you are a massive train fan, and can overlook all that is mentioned above. I wouldn't recommend this title I'm afraid.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
y 18, 2015
												One of the most disappointing games I have ever played; and the most regrettable game I've ever paid money for.  DTG charges a premium price for something that doesn't even appear to be beta tested.  If you play this game for any length of time you will be alienated by the overwhelming number of game breaking bugs.  Each route is worth, at best, $5. The loading screens are full of ads.  The price to quality ratio is unforgivable and frankly insulting.  If you enjoy making regrettable decisions, buy this game...

												Bad if u like to drive in a ghost world. It's gettin bored after a while. Only in scenarios you wil see some trains passing but quick drive is really ghost drive. And all those wierd placements of stations and objects will not help you to enjoy. Some scenarios are not playable because there is no rails. I was a fan but it's starting to be a nightmare. The support is also bad. Buy it when it's cheap don't spend so much money for it. Don't let you fool with scenery it's fake quick made ..and some parts are really ghosty with the same objects and people who do all the same. Some walk on the rails instead on the station platform or cars are flying in the air or ground same with people and objects some objects like a ballons has mark poles bahhhhhh. Not a way to enjoy the scenery when u drive much tracks.
